GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 32.00  LIAISON WITH CITY COUNCIL.



   The City Council shall appoint one of its members to attend the
meetings of the Planning Commission and the meetings of the boards and
commissions established by this chapter and to serve as a liaison between the
Planning Commission and the City Council and such boards and commissions and
the City Council.



(Ord. 1916, passed 12-18-00)



§ 32.00.1  FILING OF AGENDA AND MINUTES.



   The agenda and minutes of every meeting of the Planning Commission and
of the boards and commissions established by this chapter shall be filed with
the City Secretary who shall distribute copies thereof the members of the
City Council. The agenda of every meeting shall be filed with the City
Secretary immediately after being posted and the minutes of every meeting
shall be filed with the City Secretary the next business day after being
approved by a quorum of the Planning Commission or the board or commission
established by this chapter, as the case may be, at the next subsequent
meeting thereof.



(Ord. 1916, passed 12-18-00)



§ 32.00.2  SUBMISSION OF REQUESTS AND REPORTS.



   (A)   In order to assure adequate consideration of the fiscal and
administrative consequences involved, all requests and reports submitted by
the Planning Commission to the City Council and all requests and reports
submitted to the City Council by the boards and commissions established by
this chapter shall first be submitted in writing to the City Manager.



   (B)   The City Manager shall review any request or report submitted
pursuant to the provisions of division (A), attach thereto any relevant data
or comments regarding the fiscal and administrative consequences involved,
and distribute such request or report to the members of the City Council. The
City Manager may delegate this duty to one or more members of the City
Manager's staff.



   (C)   In the event that the topic of any request or report submitted
pursuant to the provisions of division (A), or any part thereof, thereafter
appears on the agenda of a regular or special meeting of the City Council,
nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent any member of
the Planning Commission or of the other boards and commissions established by
this chapter, as the case may be, from addressing the City Council concerning
the same at such meeting.



(Ord. 1916, passed 12-18-00)



§ 32.00.3  RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING TRAFFIC.



   The Planning Commission shall perform the duties specified in § 70.10.



(Ord. 2004-2056, passed 7-19-04)



§ 32.00.4  REVIEW OF TRAFFIC AND ZONING ORDINANCES.



   Any ordinance affecting traffic or zoning shall be submitted to the
Planning Commission for review in its final form prior to being placed on the
agenda of the City Council for adoption.



(Ord. 2008-2187, passed 1-22-08)



§ 32.00.5  TERM OF OFFICE.



   The members of the Planning Commission shall each serve a term of two
years. Provided, however, two of the members of the Planning Commission
appointed during the year 2010 shall only serve a one- year term each.



(Ord. 2010-2250, passed 6-7-10)



BEAUTIFICATION, PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE



§ 32.01  CREATION; MEMBERSHIP.



   There is hereby created for the purpose of assisting the City Council,
the City Manager, and the Parks and  Recreation Department of the city in
establishing city-wide policies to enhance the scenic beauty of the city a
Beautification, Parks and Recreation Committee to be known as the
Beautification, Parks and Recreation Committee of the City of Freeport. This
Committee shall consist of seven members who shall be residents of the city
and who shall serve without compensation.



(Ord. 1730, passed 10-10-92; Am. Ord. 2001-1937, passed 6-4-01)



Cross-reference:



   Parks and recreation, see Ch. 98



§ 32.02  APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERM; EX OFFICIO MEMBER.



   Initially three of the members of this Committee shall be appointed
initially by the City Council for a one-year term each and four members of
this Committee shall be appointed for a two-year term each. Thereafter three
members shall be appointed in October of each even-numbered year for a
two-year term each and four members shall be appointed in October of each
odd-numbered year for a two-year term each. The Director of the Parks,
Recreation and Beautification Department of the city shall be an ex officio
member of this Committee, representing the City Manager, without the right to
vote.



(Ord. 1730, passed 10-10-92; Am. Ord. 2001-1937, passed 6-4-01)



§ 32.03  RESPONSIBILITY OF MEMBERS; REMOVING AND FILLING VACANCIES.



   Membership on this Committee shall be accompanied by active
participation in the activities of the Committee and any member who is absent
for three consecutive meetings of the Committee without valid excuse, as
determined by the vote of a majority of the members of the Committee present
and voting at any meeting at which any member is not present, shall
automatically be dismissed from membership. The Committee shall at once
notify the City Manager that a vacancy exists. Vacancies occurring in the
Committee, for whatever reason, shall be filled by the City Council for the
unexpired term only.



(Ord. 1730, passed 10-10-92)



§ 32.04  OFFICERS; RULES OF PROCEDURE.



   This Committee shall select its own Chairperson and Secretary and
establish its own rules of procedure which shall include the following:



   (A)   All meetings shall be conducted and notice given in accordance
with the Texas Open Meetings Law.



   (B)   A quorum shall consist of a majority of the Committee members.



   (C)   Only the affirmative vote of a majority of the Committee
members present and voting at any meeting thereof shall be necessary to pass
upon any question submitted for decision.



   (D)   The committee shall hold one regular meeting, each calendar
month, but special meetings may be called by the Chairperson, the City
Manager, or any four members. The date, time, and place of the regular
monthly meeting shall be determined by the Chairperson or, upon the failure
of the Chair-person to act, by the City Manager, and the date, time, and
place of any special meeting shall be determined by the person or persons
calling the same.



   (E)   Initially, the Chairperson and Secretary shall be elected at
the first regular meeting held after the initial members of this committee
are appointed by the City Council and shall serve until the first regular
meeting in November of the succeeding year. Thereafter, the Chairperson and
Secretary shall be elected at the first regular meeting in November of each
year, shall each serve a term of one year and may succeed himself/herself. If
the Chairperson is absent for any meeting, the members present shall elect a
Chairperson Pro Tem to preside over such meeting. If the Secretary is absent,
the Chairperson or Chairperson Pro Tem, as the case may be, shall appoint a
member to act as Secretary Pro Tem.



   (F)   The Secretary shall keep accurate minutes of all meetings and
submit a copy of the same to the City Council for its review within a
reasonable time after the same are taken.



(Ord. 1730, passed 10-10-92)



§ 32.05  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Beautification, Parks and Recreation Committee shall have the
following powers and duties:



   (A)   Work closely with the Director of Parks, Recreation and
Beautification Department, and when requested by the City Manager or City
Council, with the other city boards, commissions and committees toward the
continued improvement of the city.



   (B)   To develop and recommend in writing to the City Manager and
City Council goals and long-range plans, policies and programs for the
capital improvements to and the use of the city’s parks and recreational
facilities and for the beautification of the city.



   (C)   To prepare and maintain in a current status, for the
consideration of the City Manager and the City Council, a written list of
recommended capital improvements to the city’s parks and recreation
facilities and for the beautification of the city.



   (D)   To recommend in writing for the City Manager’s consideration
an annual budget for the Parks, Recreation and Beautification Department of
the city, which shall be included in the annual budget recommendation which
the City Manager makes to the City Council, with such additions or changes as
the City Manager may deem appropriate.



   (E)   To study and make recommendations to the City Manager with
respect to the acceptance of gifts, donations, and grants on behalf of the
city for parks and recreation facilities and the beautification of the city.



   (F)   To develop recognition programs for those involved in parks,
recreation and beautification projects within the city.



   (G)   To make annual reports to the City Council regarding the
operation of the Parks, Recreation and Beautification Department.



   (H)   To perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as
the City Council shall authorize from time to time.



(Ord. 1730, passed 10-10-92; Am. Ord. 2001-1937, passed 6-4-01)



HISTORICAL COMMISSION AND MAIN STREET ADVISORY BOARD



§ 32.20  ORGANIZATION AND PURPOSE; MEMBERSHIP; MEETINGS; PROJECT MANAGER.



   (A)   Established. In order to revitalize the Central Business
District of the city within the context of the preservation and
rehabilitation of its historic buildings and to perform the duties of the
historical commission required by § 155.046 of this code, there is hereby
established for the city a permanent commission and advisory board, to be
known as the Historic Commission and Main Street Advisory Board.



   (B)   Organization and membership. The Historical Commission and
Main Street Advisory Board shall consist of nine members, at least five of
whom shall be residents of the city.  Four members shall be appointed for a
two-year term each in odd- numbered years and five of whom shall be appointed
for a two-year term in even-numbered years.  Any of the members may be
removed by the City Council at any time, with or without cause.  Each member
shall, before assuming the duties of such office, take the oath of office and
sign the affidavit required by the Constitution of Texas.



   (C)   Officers; duties. At the first meeting in June of each
calendar year, or as soon thereafter as is practical, the members of the
Historical Commission and Main Street Advisory Board shall select one of
their number as the Chairperson, one of their members as the Vice
Chairperson, and one of their members as the Secretary. The Chairperson shall
call and preside at all meetings of the Advisory Board and the Secretary
shall keep minutes of each meeting. The Vice Chairperson shall be authorized
to act as the Chairperson in the absence or inability of the Chairperson to
act. If both of them are absent, a quorum of such Commission and Board may
select a temporary Chairperson to preside at any meeting. If the Secretary is
absent, the Chairperson or acting Chairperson shall designate another member
of such Commission and Board to keep minutes of that meeting as temporary
Secretary.



   (D)   Quorum; meetings; notice; rules of procedure. A quorum for any
meeting of such Commission and Board shall consist of a majority of its
members. Meetings of such Board and Commission may be held at any available
location, within or without the city, selected by the Chairperson. Notice of
all meetings of such Commission and Board shall be posted and all meetings
shall be open to the public in accordance with the applicable provisions of
the Texas Open Meetings Act, now codified as Chapter 551 of the Tex. Gov’t.
Code. At the discretion of the Chairperson or a majority of the members, such
Commission and Board may meet in closed or executive session upon complying
with the applicable provisions of such Act. The Commission and Board may
adopt such further rules of procedure, not inconsistent with the terms of
this section, the law of the State of Texas or the Home Rule Charter and
ordinances of the city, as the majority of its members deem appropriate.



   (E)   Main Street Project Manager. The City Manager of the city is
hereby authorized to designate an employee of the city to, in addition to the
other duties of such employee, coordinate and supervise the Historical
Commission and Main Street Advisory Board in the performance of the duties
required by division (F) of this section and to perform the duties of the
Historic Preservation Officer specified in division (A) of § 155.046.



   (F)   Duties. The Commission and Board shall have the following
duties and responsibilities:



      (1)   Those prescribed for advisory boards by the Texas Main
Street Program of the Texas Historical Commission.



      (2)   Those prescribed for the historical commission under §
155.046 of this code.



      (3)   Adoption of criteria for the designation of historic,
architectural and cultural landmarks and the delineation of historic
districts, which shall be approved by the City Council.



      (4)   Conduct surveys and maintain an inventory of significant
historic, architectural and cultural landmarks and all properties located in
historic districts in the city.



(Ord. 1633, passed 1-19-87; Am. Ord. 1100-91-2, passed 4-1-91; Am. Ord.
2007-2165, passed 6-4-07; Am. Ord. 2008-2205, passed 8-11-08; Am. Ord.
2009-2228, passed 9-14-09)



§ 32.21  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of the City Historical Commission shall be to identify and
preserve the history of the city and the surrounding area for the benefit,
education, and edification of all interested people and organizations.  The
Historical Commission may utilize the benefits, aid, and cooperation of
recognized local, state, and national Historical Commissions as well as other
public or private individuals and entities. Additionally, the City Historical
Commission shall explore, evaluate, and appraise the City Council in the
areas of establishing a City Museum, City Historian, City Historical
Districts, historical sites, or any special projects in this area, including
any fund-raising activities of benefit for these purposes. The Commission
shall perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the
City Council shall from time to time proscribe.



(Ord. 1633, passed 1-19-87)



§ 32.22  SUPERVISION.



   The City Council shall appoint an elected official or city staff member
to coordinate, assist, and act as liaison between the city and the Historical
Commission. The Historical Commission will meet in the city hall or in such
place or places as the Council may designate, which shall also be the
location for storage and assimilation of such history and memorabilia.



(Ord. 1633, passed 1-19-87)



LIBRARY BOARD



§ 32.35  CREATION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.



   (A)   There is hereby created in and for the city a Library Board.



('68 Code, § 18-11) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63)



   (B)   The members of the Library Board shall be appointed by the
City Council.



('68 Code, § 18-12)



§ 32.36  PURPOSE.



   The Library Board shall act as a liaison between the county library
system and the city to recommend improvements in library services to the
county and improvements in maintenance to the library building, equipment and
grounds to the city. The Board shall accept funds donated to the library in
the name of the city and determine disbursement of same.



('68 Code, § 18-19) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63; Am. Ord. 1388, passed
5-15-78)



§ 32.37  COMPOSITION.



   The Library Board shall consist of seven persons, five of whom are
resident citizens and qualified voters of the city, one of whom is a
nonresident of the city but a resident of the Stephen F. Austin Elementary
School or O.A. Fleming Elementary School attendance zones established by the
Board of Trustees of the Brazosport Independent School District and one of
whom is a non-resident of the city but a resident of the Velasco Elementary
School attendance zone established by said Board of Trustees. Ex officio
members of the Library Board shall include the librarian assigned to the
Freeport Branch of the Brazoria County Library System, the City Secretary,
and the Freeport representative to the Brazoria County Library Board, unless
such representative is an appointed member of the Library Board.



('68 Code, § 18-13) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63; Am. Ord. 1388, passed
5-15-78; Am. Ord. 2003-2017, passed 7-21-03)



§ 32.38  TERM OF MEMBERS.



   Each member of the Library Board shall hold office for a term of two
years or until their successors have been appointed and qualified. Vacancies
shall be filled by the appointment of a qualified person by the City Council
to fill the unexpired term of the person he is succeeding.



('68 Code, § 18-14) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63; Am. Ord. 1388, passed
5-15-78)



§ 32.39  ELECTION OF OFFICERS.



   The members of the Board shall elect from among themselves a
Chairperson, a Treasurer, and a Secretary. The City Secretary may serve as
the Secretary of the Board.



('68 Code, § 18-15) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63; Am. Ord. 1388, passed
5-15-78)



§ 32.40  RULES OF PROCEDURE.



   The members of the Library Board shall provide and adopt their own
rules of procedure for the conduct of their meetings.



('68 Code, § 18-16) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63)



§ 32.41  MEETINGS.



   The members of the Library Board shall meet on such dates and at such
times as they may provide.



('68 Code, § 18-17) (Ord. 1091, passed 6-17-63)



§ 32.42  QUORUM.



   The presence of a simple majority of the total membership of the
Library Board at any meeting thereof shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business.



('68 Code, § 18-18) (Ord. 1388, passed 5-15-78)



ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT



§ 32.55  CREATION.



   There is hereby established for the city a Department of Engineering.



(Ord. 1889, passed 1-3-00)



§ 32.56  CITY ENGINEER.



   (A)   The City Manager shall, with the approval of the City Council,
appoint a Texas registered professional engineer, residing within or without
the city, to be the City Engineer on a part time or full time basis. The City
Engineer shall serve for an indefinite term and may be removed from office by
the City Manager at any time with the consent of the City Council.



   (B)   The City Engineer shall receive for services rendered in such
capacity such compensation as may be fixed by the City Council from time to
time.



   (C)   The City Engineer shall be the chief administrative officer of
the Department of Engineering but responsible to the City Manager for the
administration of such department and the carrying out of the directives of
the City Council. The City Engineer shall provide on behalf of the city such
professional engineering services as may be requested by the City Manager
from time to time and shall assist the City Manager in dealing with any
project engineers retained by the city as independent contractors.



(Ord. 1889, passed 1-3-00)



§ 32.57  ADDITIONAL STAFFING.



   The City Manager shall provide such staff for the Department of
Engineering as may be necessary for the City Engineer to perform the duties
of such office either by utilizing the existing staff of other departments of
the city or, with the consent of the City Council, by appointing additional
staff specifically for the Department of Engineering on a full time or part
time basis.



(Ord. 1889, passed 1-3-00)



SENIOR CITIZENS COMMISSION



§ 32.60  CREATION; MEMBERSHIP.



   There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Senior Citizens
Commission, which shall consist of seven members, each of whom shall be a
resident senior citizen of the city and shall serve without compensation. 
The term “senior citizen” shall mean a person who is at least 55 years of
age.



(Ord. 2001-1946, passed 9-17-01)



§ 32.61  APPOINTMENT; TERM; REMOVAL; FILLING VACANCIES; EX OFFICIO MEMBER.



   (A)   Initially, three members of this commission shall be appointed
by the City Council for a one-year term and four members shall be appointed
by the City Council for a two-year term.  All subsequent appointments shall
be for a two-year term.



   (B)   At the request of a majority of the commission, any member not
attending three consecutive regular meetings may be removed by the City
Council.  Vacancies on the commission, for whatever reason, shall be filled
by the City Council for the unexpired term only.



   (C)   The Director of the Parks, Recreation and Beautification
Department of the city shall be an ex officio member of this commission,
representing the City Manager, without the right to vote.



(Ord. 2001-1946, passed 9-17-01)



§ 32.62  OFFICERS; RULES OF PROCEDURE.



   This commission shall establish its own rules of procedure, which shall
include the following:



   (A)   All meetings shall be open to the public and conducted and
notice given in accordance with the Texas Open Meetings Law.



   (B)   A quorum shall consist of a majority of the commission members
and the Chairperson may vote upon all questions.



   (C)   Only the affirmative vote of a majority of the commission
members present and voting at any meeting thereof shall be necessary to pass
upon any question submitted for decision.



   (D)   The Chairperson and Secretary of the commission shall be
elected annually by a majority of the members present and voting at the first
regular meeting following the appointment by the City Council of successors
for members whose terms are expiring. If either of these officers are absent
at any meeting, the members present by majority vote may select one other
member to perform the duties of such absent officer during such meeting.



   (E)   The commission shall hold one regular meeting each calendar
month, the date, time and place of which shall be determined annually by the
vote of a majority of the members at the first regular meeting following the
appointment by the City Council of successors for members whose terms are
expiring. Special meetings may be called by the Chairperson, the City Manager
or any four members of the commission. The date, time and place of a special
meeting shall be determined by the person or persons calling the same.



   (F)   The commission may exercise its powers and accomplish its
duties through subcommittees consisting of commission members and volunteers.
Provided, however, any volunteer appointed to a subcommittee must be approved
by majority vote of the members of the commission present and voting a
meeting of the commission at which such appointment is made.



(Ord. 2001-1946, passed 9-17-01)



§ 32.63  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   This commission shall have the following duties and responsibilities:



   (A)   Recommend to the City Council for adoption, legislative or
administrative changes in the code of ordinances and administrative policies
with regard to issues affecting or improving the quality of life for and
services to senior citizens.



   (B)   Encourage involvement and participation by senior citizens in
the government of the city.



   (C)   Initiate studies of and recommend to the City Council the
adoption of new forms of technology that will improve the quality of life for
and services to senior citizens.



   (D)   Develop and recommend to the City Council programs which will
aid in improving the quality of life of senior citizens.



   (E)   Make recommendations to the other boards, commissions and
committees of the city on issues affecting senior citizens.



   (F)   Report annually to the City Council on the activities of the
commission.



   (G)   Perform such other duties and have such other responsibilities
as the City Council may authorize from time to time.



(Ord. 2001-1946, passed 9-17-01)



PROPERTY DEPARTMENT



§ 32.80  APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES OF PROPERTY MANAGER.



   The City Manager shall appoint, on a part-time or full-time basis, a
competent person as the Property Manager of the city, who shall have the
following duties:



   (A)   To maintain records and files on land or interests in land
acquired by the city through purchase, sale, lease, exchange, donation, in
trust as a result of tax foreclosure sales and/or the exercise of its power
of eminent domain as well as land or interest in land conveyed, leased or
licensed by the city.



   (B)   To maintain records and files on all liens acquired by the
city, whether voluntary or by operation of law, and to issue appropriate
releases of such liens upon payment of the indebtedness secured by any such
liens.



   (C)   To maintain a current record of all annexations and
disannexations, platting and re- platting, zoning and re-zoning and see that
the same are reflected on the official map of the city and the official
zoning map of the city.



   (D)   To assist the attorneys representing the city in matters
involving ad valorem taxation, foreclosure of liens, the sale or purchase of
land and in the exercise of the city’s power of eminent domain.



   (E)   Perform such other duties as may be assigned from time to time
by the City Manager.



(Ord. 2008-2188, passed 1-22-08)



§ 32.81  COMPENSATION AND REMOVAL OF PROPERTY MANAGER.



   The Property Manager shall receive for services rendered in such
capacity such compensation as may be fixed by the City Council from time to
time and may be removed from office by the City Manager at any time with the
consent of the City Council.



(Ord. 2008-2188, passed 1-22-08)



CHAPTER 33:  MUNICIPAL COURT



Section



   33.01   Creation



   33.02   Jurisdiction



   33.03   Judicial notice of Charter, ordinances, minute orders,
territorial limits, speed zone signs and traffic control signals



   33.04   Duties



   33.05   Procedure



   33.06   Application of cash deposited with bonds



   33.07   Failure to return and pay fine



   33.08   Costs in addition to court costs



   33.09   Payment of jurors



   33.10   Warrant fees



   33.11   Notice to appear in court for violation of provisions of
code of ordinances; promise to appear; waiver of sworn complaint



   33.12   Definition



   33.13   Violation of promise to appear



   33.14   Appearance by legal counsel



   33.15   Procedure not exclusive



Statutory reference:



   Municipal Court, see Tex. Gov't Code  §§ 29.001 et seq.; Tex. Crim.
Proc. Code, §§ 45.01 et seq.



§ 33.01  CREATION.



   There is hereby created a Municipal Court in and for the city.



('68 Code, § 11-1) (Ord. 1015, passed 10-9-59)



§ 33.02  JURISDICTION.



   (A)   The Municipal Court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction
within the territorial limits of the city of all criminal cases that:



      (1)   Arise under the ordinances of the city; and



      (2)   Are punishable by a fine not to exceed: $2,000 in all
cases arising under ordinances that govern fire safety, zoning or public
health and sanitation, including the dumping of refuse; or $500 in all other
cases.



   (B)   The Municipal Court shall have concurrent jurisdiction with
the justice of the peace court of any precinct in which the city or any part
of the city is located in all criminal cases arising under state law that:



      (1)   Arise within the territorial limits of the city; and



      (2)   Are punishable by fine only, “fine only” being
defined to include the imposition of such additional sanctions as authorized
by statute, not consisting of confinement in jail or imprisonment, that are
rehabilitative or remedial in nature.



   (C)   The Municipal Court shall have jurisdiction in the forfeiture
and final judgment of all bail bonds and personal bonds taken in criminal
cases of which the court has jurisdiction.



(Tex. Gov't Code, § 29.003)  ('68 Code, § 11-2) (Ord. 1015, passed
10-9-59; Am. Ord. 1591, passed 9-10-84; Am. Ord. 1708A, passed 9-9-91; Am.
Ord. 1761, passed 4-4-94; Am. Ord. 1797, passed 3-18-96)



Statutory reference:



   Jurisdiction and powers of justice of the peace courts, see Tex. Gov't
Code §§ 27.031 through 27.033; Tex. Crim. Proc. Code, Arts. 4.01, 4.11



§ 33.03  JUDICIAL NOTICE OF CHARTER, ORDINANCES, MINUTE ORDERS, TERRITORIAL
LIMITS, SPEED ZONE SIGNS AND TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS.



   (A)   The Municipal Court shall take judicial notice of the home
rule charter, all city ordinances and the minute orders of the Traffic
Commission of the city which have been approved by City Council in accordance
with the Code of Ordinances of the city, as well as judicial notice of the
territorial limits of the city.



   (B)   In any prosecution in the Municipal Court, or in any other
court of competent jurisdiction, proof of the existence of any speed limit
sign on or alongside any public highway, street or road within the city shall
be prima facie proof of all facts necessary to establish the proper and
lawful designation of the speed limit thereon stated at such place and the
proper and lawful installation of such sign by competent authority. Provided,
however, that the prima facie proof herein provided for may be rebutted by
the defendant in any such prosecution.



   (C)   In any prosecution in the Municipal Court, or in any other
court of competent jurisdiction, proof of the existence of any traffic
control signal or other traffic-control device on or alongside any public
highway, street or road within the city shall be prima facie proof of all
facts necessary to establish the proper and lawful installation of such
signal or device by competent authority. Provided, however, that the prima
facie proof herein provided for may be rebutted by the defendant in any such
prosecution.



('68 Code, § 11-5) (Ord. 1761, passed 4-4-94; Am. Ord. 1797, passed 3-18-96)



§ 33.04  DUTIES.



   The judge of the Municipal Court shall perform all the duties incumbent
upon him by law and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by
law. By way of illustration, and not limitation, such judge shall perform
those duties appertaining to such office set out in Tex. Crim. Proc. Code,
Ch. 45 as the same exist or may be amended.



('68 Code, § 11-3) (Ord. 1015, passed 10-9-59)



§ 33.05  PROCEDURE.



   The Municipal Court and the judge thereof shall be governed by the
rules of procedure established by the Code of Criminal Procedure of the State
of Texas, and any amendments thereto, and by any other law thereto
appertaining.



('68 Code, § 11-4) (Ord. 1015, passed 10-9-59)



Statutory reference:



   Rules of justice of the peace court, see Tex. Rules of Civil Procedure



§ 33.06  APPLICATION OF CASH DEPOSITED WITH BONDS.



   (A)   Whenever any defendant charged with an offense over which the
Municipal Court of the city has jurisdiction deposits current money of the
United States in the amount of any bail bond returnable to the court in lieu
of having sureties sign the same and at the foot of such bail bond the
following appears:



“IN THE EVENT I FAIL TO SO APPEAR, THEN I HEREBY AUTHORIZE SAID COURT TO
ACCEPT THIS INSTRUMENT AS MY WRITTEN PLEA OF NOLO CONTENDERE (NO CONTEST),
WAIVER OF JURY TRIAL AND WAIVER OF RIGHT TO APPEAL PURSUANT TO ARTICLE 27.14
OF THE TEXAS CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE, AND TO RETAIN THE ABOVE MENTIONED
SUM IN CASH HEREWITH TENDERED IN SATISFACTION OF THE FINE AND ANY COURT COSTS
ASSESSED AGAINST ME UPON THE ENTRY OF SUCH PLEA IN LIEU OF REFUNDING THE SAME
TO ME.”



   (B)   The document shall be followed by the date and signature of
the defendant, and thereafter if such defendant fails to appear in said court
as agreed in such bond, if the judge presiding in said court so orders and in
lieu of refunding such funds to said defendant, such funds may be retained by
such custodian of funds in satisfaction of the fine and any court costs
assessed against such defendant.



(Ord. 1739, passed 2-1-93)



§ 33.07  FAILURE TO RETURN AND PAY FINE.



   (A)   Any defendant in the Municipal Court who is released from
custody by the judge thereof, after having been found guilty of an offence
over which such court has jurisdiction, on condition that such defendant
subsequently return and pay the fine assessed and any other lawful charges
which may be due and payable in connection therewith, commits a separate
offense punishable as provided in § 10.99 of this code if such defendant
subsequently fails to return at the times specified in the terms of such
defendant's release.



   (B)   It is a defense to a prosecution under this section if such
defendant has a reasonable excuse for the failure of such defendant to return
at the times specified in the terms of such defendant's release.



(Ord. 1761, passed 4-4-94)



§ 33.08  COSTS IN ADDITION TO COURT COSTS.



   (A)   Additional costs; exemptions; payment in spite of probated
sentence; payment of cost if person granted deferred adjudication.



      (1)   As permitted by Tex. Crim. Proc. Code §§ 56.31 et
seq., as amended, (Crime Victims Compensation Act), a person shall pay $12.50
as a court cost, in addition to other court cost, on conviction of a
misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $200.  A conviction that
arises under Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat., Art. 6687b, (Driver's, Chauffeur's and
Commercial Operator's Licenses; Accident Reports) is specifically excluded
from this division (A)(1).



      (2)   The court shall require a person convicted of an offense
listed under this section to pay the court cost whether or not the court
grants the person a probated sentence.



      (3)   If a person is granted deferred adjudication under Tex.
Crim. Proc. Code, § 45.54, 1965, as amended, the person shall pay as court
cost the amount that the person would otherwise have been required to pay
under this division had the adjudication not been deferred and had the person
been finally convicted of the offense.



   (B)   Costs for continuing legal education for court judges;
exemptions from additional costs.  As permitted by Tex. Gov't Code §
56.001, as amended (Continuing Legal Education for Municipal Court Judges), a
person shall pay $.50 as a court cost, in addition to other court costs, on
conviction of any criminal offense in a municipal court. A conviction arising
under a law that regulates pedestrians or the parking of motor vehicles is
excluded from this division (B).



   (C)   Collection. Court cost due under this section shall be
collected in the same manner as other fines or costs are collected in the
case.



   (D)   Keeping and handling of records. Each officer collecting the
cost shall keep records and handle the same as proscribed by state law.



   (E)   Special expense. A special expense fee of $10 shall be
assessed and collected for services performed in all cases in the municipal
court in which the laws of the state require that a case pending in the
municipal court of the city be dismissed because of actions taken by or on
behalf of the defendant in such case subsequent to the date of the offense
alleged in the complaint on file therein.  Such actions are limited to those
done in conformity with the provisions of Tex. Transp. Code §§ 543.101 et
seq.



   (F)   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Municipal
Court Building Security Fund. Each defendant convicted of a misdemeanor
offense in the Municipal Court of the city is hereby required to pay a $3.00
security fee as cost of court. Provided, however, such fund may only be
expended for one or more of the purpose specified in Tex. Crim. Proc. Code
Article 102.017.



   (G)   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Municipal
Court Technology Fund. Each defendant convicted of a misdemeanor offense in
the Municipal Court of the city is hereby required to pay a $4.00 technology
fee as cost of court. Provided, however, such fund may only be expended for
one or more of the purposes specified in Tex. Crim. Proc. Code Article
102.0172(d).



('68 Code, § 11-7) (Ord. 1577, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 1649, passed 1-4-88;
Am. Ord. passed  - -96; Am. Ord. 1802, passed 8-5-96; Am. Ord. 1858, passed
5-3-99; Am. Ord. 1873, passed 9-27-99)



§ 33.09  PAYMENT OF JURORS.



   Each juror in a case in the Municipal Court is entitled to receive the
sum of $6 for each day or fraction of a day that he serves as a juror, to be
paid out of the general fund of the city on the order of the judge of the
court.



(Ord. 1761, passed 4-4-94)



§ 33.10  WARRANT FEES.



   As permitted by Tex. Crim. Proc. Code, Art. 45.06, a special expense of
$25 shall be assessed as part of the cost of court for the issuance and
service of a warrant of arrest, and the same shall be collected in the
Municipal Court of the city and delivered by the judge or clerk thereof to
the City Treasurer for deposit to the general fund of the city within a 
reasonable time after receipt thereof by the judge or clerk.



('68 Code, § 11-10) (Ord. 1575, passed 12-5-83)



§ 33.11  NOTICE TO APPEAR IN COURT FOR VIOLATION OF PROVISIONS OF CODE OF
ORDINANCES; PROMISE TO APPEAR; WAIVER OF SWORN COMPLAINT.



   Whenever a person is found to be in violation of any provision of this
code or of any other penal ordinance of the city by an officer, as defined in
§ 33.12 of this code, who is authorized to enforce such provision or
ordinance, the officer may prepare in triplicate a written notice directing
that person to appear before the municipal court of the city, containing the
name and address of the person, the provision alleged to have been violated,
the date and location of such violation, the time and place when and where
the person so notified shall appear in such court, and such other matters as
the officer may deem appropriate. The time within which a person shall be
directed to so appear specified in the notice must be at least ten days after
the date of the issuance of the notice unless the person shall request an
earlier hearing. In order to prevent an arrest for the violation specified in
the notice prior to the date for such appearance as specified therein, the
person to whom such notice is given must give a written promise so to appear
in such court by signing in triplicate the written notice. A copy of the
notice shall be delivered to the person, a copy shall be retained by the
officer and the original of the notice shall be delivered by the officer to
the judge of such court or the clerk thereof. When the person has appeared as
directed in the notice, all proceedings in such court shall be the same as if
a warrant for the person's arrest had been duly issued and returned executed.
The notice to appear may serve as the written complaint as provided in Tex.
Crim. Proc. Code Art. 27.14(d), to which the person may plead 'guilty' or
'nolo contendere'; but if the person pleads 'not guilty' to the violation, a
complaint shall be filed that conforms to the requirements of Tex. Crim.
Proc. Code Ch. 45, unless the person waives the filing of a sworn complaint
and elects that the prosecution proceed on the notice alone by agreeing
thereto in writing with the prosecution, signing such agreement and filing it
with the court.



(Ord. 1835, passed 7-6-98)



§ 33.12  DEFINITION.



   As used in § 33.11, the term OFFICER means police officer, code
enforcement officer or animal control officer, as the case may be.



(Ord. 1835, passed 7-6-98)



§ 33.13  VIOLATION OF PROMISE TO APPEAR.



   Any person knowingly or intentionally violating a written promise to
appear in the municipal court of the city as provided in § 33.11 shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided in § 10.99.



(Ord. 1835, passed 7-6-98; Am. Ord. 2007-2153, passed 2-5-07)



§ 33.14  APPEARANCE BY LEGAL COUNSEL.



   A written promise to appear in the municipal court of the city may be
complied with by an appearance by legal counsel.



(Ord. 1835, passed 7-6-98)



§ 33.15  PROCEDURE NOT EXCLUSIVE.



   The procedure prescribed in §§ 33.11 and 33.14 shall not be exclusive
of any other method prescribed by the laws of the state for the arrest and
prosecution of any person for a violation with the exclusive original
jurisdiction of the municipal court of the city.



(Ord. 1835, passed 7-6-98)



CHAPTER 34:  MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS



Section




   34.01   State Law and Charter to govern





   34.02   Withdrawal of a candidate





   34.03   Voting districts





   34.04   Election of City Council members





   34.05   Residency of candidates





   34.06   Years of elections





   34.07   Terms





   34.08   Determination of election




Statutory reference:



   Elections generally, see Tex. Election Code



§ 34.01  STATE LAW AND CHARTER TO GOVERN.



   All elections pertaining to municipal affairs shall be governed by the
Election Code of the State and the applicable provisions of the City Charter,
when not in conflict with the State Election Code.



('68 Code, § 13-1)



§ 34.02  WITHDRAWAL OF A CANDIDATE.



   Any person eligible to the office of Mayor, Council, or other sworn
office who has filed his sworn application in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter shall have his name printed on the official ballots. Any such
person may cause his or her name to be withdrawn at any time before the
official ballots are actually printed, by filing in writing with the City
Secretary a request to that effect over his own signature, duly attested to
by a notary public. No name so withdrawn shall be printed on the ballots.



(68 Code, § 13-2)



§ 34.03  VOTING DISTRICTS.



   The city is hereby divided into four voting districts to be known as
Wards A, B, C, and D and which shall consist of the area within the
incorporated limits of the city as depicted on the map attached to Ordinance
1718, and labeled as Exhibit “A.” The census tracts which compose each of
the four districts are listed and described on Exhibit “B,” as attached
to Ordinance 1718.



(Ord. 1718, passed 3-2-92)



§ 34.04  ELECTION OF CITY COUNCIL MEMBERS.



   The resident voters of each single member district are entitled to
elect one member of City Council. The Mayor of the city shall continue to be
elected at large from the city.



(Ord. 1718, passed 3-2-92)



§ 34.05  RESIDENCY OF CANDIDATES.



   Candidates for City Council must be a resident of the district from
which they are elected.



(Ord. 1718, passed 3-2-92)



§ 34.06  YEARS OF ELECTIONS.



   The Council members for Wards A and C shall be elected in even-numbered
years beginning with the  election to be held in May of 1992. The Mayor and
the Council members whose terms do not expire until May of 1993 shall
continue to serve the remainder of those terms. In May of 1993 and every
odd-numbered year thereafter, the Mayor and Council members for Wards B and D
shall be elected.



(Ord. 1718, passed 3-2-92)



§ 34.07  TERMS.



   The members of Council shall continue to serve two-year terms or until
their successors are elected, which is consistent with the current City
Charter requirements.



(Ord. 1718, passed 3-2-92)



§ 34.08  DETERMINATION OF ELECTION.



   The candidate who receives the highest number of votes for each
position shall be deemed elected, which is consistent with the current City
Charter requirement.



(Ord. 1718, passed 3-2-92)



CHAPTER 35:  TAXATION



Section




General Provisions





   35.01   Adoption of state law relative to payment of taxes





   35.02   Tax lien created





   35.03   Occupation tax





   35.04   Display of tax receipt





   35.05   Homestead exemptions





   35.06   Goods-in-transit





Hotel Occupancy Tax





   35.15   Definitions





   35.16   Levy of tax; rate; exception





   35.17   Collection





   35.18   Reports





   35.19   Rules and regulations





Gross Bingo Receipts Tax





   35.30   Definitions





   35.31   Levy of tax




GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 35.01  ADOPTION OF STATE LAW RELATIVE TO PAYMENT OF TAXES.



   The provisions of state law applicable to municipalities shall apply to
and govern the payment of taxes due and owing to the city and penalties in
connection therewith, to the same extent as if such provisions have been, by
the terms thereof, made applicable to city taxed by ordinances of the city.



(‘68 Code, § 34-1)



§ 35.02  TAX LIEN CREATED.



   (A)   A lien is hereby created on all property, personal and real,
in favor of the city for all taxes, ad valorem, occupation, or otherwise.
Such lien shall exist from January 1 in each year, until all the taxes are
paid. Such lien shall be prior to all other claims and liens then existing or
thereafter arising and no gift, sale, assignment, or transfer of any kind or
judicial writ of any kind can ever defeat such lien.



   (B)   The lien for taxes created above shall attach to all property
of the taxpayer owned on January 1 and subsequently acquired, whether
assessed or not.



(‘68 Code, § 34-2)



§ 35.03  OCCUPATION TAX.



   There is hereby levied, and there shall be collected from every person
pursuing any occupation taxed by the general laws of the state, or which may
be hereafter so taxed, an annual occupation tax equal in each instance to
one-half the state occupation tax, which tax shall be paid annually in
advance except where otherwise provided by the state law, in which event the
same may be paid as provided by the state law.



(‘68 Code, § 34-3)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   For provisions regulating occupation taxes, see Texas Constitution,
Art. VIII, § 1



§ 35.04  DISPLAY OF TAX RECEIPT.



   No person shall pursue or follow any occupation, calling or profession,
or do any act taxed by law, or exhibit any machine or instrument, for which a
tax is required to be paid without exhibiting and displaying the tax receipt
issued to him in the manner provided by state law.



(‘68 Code, § 34-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 35.05  HOMESTEAD EXEMPTIONS.



   (A)   For the 1982 tax year and thereafter, 20% of the assessed
market value of the residence homestead of any married or unmarried adult,
including one living alone, shall be exempt from ad valorem taxation for all
city purposes; provided, that the amount of this exemption shall be not less
than $5,000 for any such eligible residence homestead; and provided further,
that an eligible adult under this division shall also be entitled to receive
other applicable exemptions provided by law.



   (B)   (1)   For the 2005 tax year, and all subsequent tax years,
$80,000 of the market value of residence homesteads of persons who are under
a disability for purposes of payment of disability insurance benefits from
the Federal Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance, or its successor,
shall be exempt from ad valorem taxes levied by the city.



      (2)   For the 2005 tax year, and all subsequent tax years,
$80,000 of the market value of residence homesteads of persons 65 years of
age or older shall be exempt from ad valorem taxes levied by the city.



   (C)   The exemptions provided by this section may be disregarded and
the Tax Assessor/Collector shall assess and collect any tax pledged for
payment of debt without deducting the amount of any such exemption in any
case where, prior to the adoption of the exemption, the city pledged the
taxes for payment of a debt and granting the exemption would impair the
obligation of the contract creating the debt.



(‘68 Code, § 34-5) (Ord. 1249, passed 12-18-72; Am. Ord. 1539, passed
12-20-82; Am. Ord. 1712, passed 10-21-91; Am. Ord. 2005-2092, passed 8-22-05)



§ 35.06  GOODS-IN-TRANSIT.



   All such goods-in-transit personal property as covered by Tex. Tax Code
§ 11.253 shall be, and are hereby declared to be, taxable by the City of
Freeport for the tax year 2012 and for every year thereafter, all as provided
for in accordance with Tex. Tax Code § 11.253.



(Ord. 2011-2298, passed 12-5-11)



HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX



§ 35.15  DEFINITIONS.



   The words, terms, and phrases used herein are as defined in Tex. Tax
Code § 351.103 or as may later be defined in said statutes.



(‘68 Code, § 34-10) (Ord. 1471, passed 10-6-80)



§ 35.16  LEVY OF TAX; RATE; EXCEPTION.



   (A)   There is hereby levied a tax upon the occupant of any room,
space or facility furnished by any hotel within the city or its
extraterritorial jurisdiction, where the cost of such occupancy is at the
rate of $2 or more per day, such tax to be equal to 7% of the consideration
paid by the occupant of such room, space, or facility to such hotel,
exclusive of occupancy taxes imposed by other governmental agencies.



   (B)   No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a resident of a room
who possesses the room for a continuous period of 30 days or more.



   (C)   No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon an occupant of any room
or space rented from a corpora- tion or association organized and operated
exclusively for religious, charitable, or educational purposes.



   (D)   All revenue derived from the occupancy tax imposed in division
(A) of this section will be used for the purposes permitted under state law
including Tex. Tax Code § 351.103.



(‘68 Code, § 34-11) (Ord. 1471, passed 10-6-80; Am. Ord. 1905, passed
7-10-00)



§ 35.17  COLLECTION.



   Every person owning, operating, managing, or controlling any hotel
shall collect the tax imposed in § 35.16 of this subchapter for the city.



(‘68 Code, § 34-12) (Ord. 1471, passed 10-6-80)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 35.18  REPORTS.



   On the last day of the month following each calendar quarterly period,
every person required in § 35.17 to collect the tax imposed herein, shall
file a report with the City Finance Director showing the consideration paid
for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of the tax
collected on such occupancies, and any other information as the City Finance
Director may reasonably require. Such person shall pay the amount of tax
collected from occupants during the period of the report at the time of
filing the report.



(‘68 Code, § 34-13) (Ord. 1471, passed 10-6-80; Am. Ord. 2003-2032, passed
11-17-03) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 35.19  RULES AND REGULATIONS.



   The City Finance Director shall have the power to make such rules and
regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied herein and
the City Finance Director or any City Auditor shall upon reasonable notice
have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the
correctness of any report filed as required by this subchapter and the amount
of taxes due under the provisions of this subchapter.



(‘68 Code, § 34-14) (Ord. 1471, passed 10-6-80; Am. Ord. 2003-2032, passed
11-17-03)



GROSS BINGO RECEIPTS TAX

CHAPTER 36:  EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS



Section




   36.01   Organization





   36.02   Emergency Management Director - powers and duties





   36.03   Emergency management plan





   36.04   Interjurisdictional program





   36.05   Override




   36.06   Liability



   36.07   Commitment of funds



   36.08   Offenses; penalties



§ 36.01  ORGANIZATION.



   There exists the office of Emergency Management Director of the city,
which shall be held by the Mayor in accordance with state law.



   (A)   An Emergency Management Coordinator may be appointed by and
serve at the pleasure of the Director.



   (B)   The Director shall be responsible for a program of
comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the
duties and responsibilities set forth in this chapter. He/she may delegate
authority for execution of these duties to the Coordinator, but ultimate
responsibility for such execution shall remain with the Director.



   (C)   The operational emergency management organization of the city
shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the
Director in the emergency management plan as well as organized volunteer
groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed
among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the
emergency management plan.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.02  EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT DIRECTOR - POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The duties and responsibilities of the Emergency Management Director
shall include the following:



   (A)   Conduct an ongoing survey of actual or potential hazards which
threaten life and property within the city and an ongoing program of
identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures
which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such
hazards if a disaster did occur.



   (B)   Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency
management plan for the city and shall recommend for adoption by the City
Council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation
of such plan.



   (C)   Authority to declare a local state of disaster.  The
declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven
days except by or with the consent of the City Council. Any order or
proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster
shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with
the City Secretary.



   (D)   Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations, or
directives which are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this chapter.
Such proclamations, regulations, or directives shall be disseminated promptly
by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general
public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede,
promptly filed with the City Secretary.



   (E)   Direction and control of the operations of the city emergency
management organization as well as the training of emergency management
personnel.



   (F)   Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility
that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city.



   (G)   Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district,
state, regional or federal emergency management organizations.



   (H)   Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment, or supplies
from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions
of the emergency management plan.



   (I)   Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid
agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other
local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if
deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which said city is
located and with other municipalities within the county, for the countywide
coordination of emergency management efforts.



   (J)   Supervision of, and final authorization for the procurement of
all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private
contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency
management within the city.



   (K)   Authorizing of agreements, after approval by the City
Attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes.



   (L)   Survey of the availability of existing personnel, equipment,
supplies, and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided for
herein.



   (M)   Other requirements as specified in the Texas Disaster Act of
1975, TEX. GOV’T CODE, Chapter 418.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.03  EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT PLAN.



   A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be developed and
maintained in a current state. The plan shall set forth the form of the
organization; establish and designate divisions and functions; assign
responsibilities, tasks, duties, and powers; and designate officers and
employees to carry out the provisions of this chapter. As provided by state
law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the
State Division of Emergency Management of the State of Texas. Insofar as
possible, the form of organization, titles, and terminology shall conform to
the recommendations of the State Division of Emergency Management. When
approved, it shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the
functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a
current state of readiness at all times. The emergency management plan shall
be considered supplementary to this chapter and have the effect of law during
the time of a disaster.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.04  INTERJURISDICTIONAL PROGRAM.



   The Mayor is hereby authorized to join with the County Judge of the
County of Brazoria and the mayors of the other cities in said county in the
formation of an interjurisdictional emergency management program for the
County of Brazoria, and shall have the authority to cooperate in the
preparation of an interjurisdictional emergency management plan and in the
appointment of a joint Emergency Management Coordinator, as well as all
powers necessary to participate in a countywide program of emergency
management insofar as said program may affect the city.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.05  OVERRIDE.



   At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and
promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede
and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar
as the latter may be inconsistent therewith.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.06  LIABILITY.



   This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions
for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the
city, the agents and representatives of said city, nor any individual,
receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, nor any of
the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting
to comply with, any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter shall be liable for any damage sustained to
persons as the result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real
estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to
the city a license of privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect,
designate, and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or
premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending,
or practice enemy attack or natural or man-made disaster shall, together with
his successors in interest, if any, not be civilly liable for the death of,
or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such
license, privilege or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the
property of such person.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.07  COMMITMENT OF FUNDS.



   No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the City
in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this chapter
without prior approval by the City Council, nor shall any person have any
right to bind the city by contract, agreement, or otherwise without prior and
specific approval of the City Council unless during a declared disaster.
During a declared disaster,  the  Mayor  may  expend  and/or  commit
public funds of the city when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection
of health, life, or property.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)



§ 36.08  OFFENSES; PENALTIES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct,
hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the
enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter.



   (B)   It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry,
or display any emblem, insignia, or any other means of identification as a
member of the emergency management organization of the city unless authority
to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials.



   (C)   Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other
device so as to simulate a warning signal, or the termination of a warning,
shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be subject to
the penalties imposed by this chapter.



   (D)   Convictions for violations of the provisions of this chapter
shall be punishable by fine as prescribed in § 10.99 of this code.



(Ord. 1822, passed 10-6-97)

CHAPTER 50:  SOLID WASTE



Section



   50.01   Definitions



   50.02   Collection of solid waste



   50.03   Accumulation and storage



   50.04   Placement for collection



   50.05   Affirmative defense



   50.06   Garbage collection and disposal rates



Cross-reference:



   Written application for garbage collection service, see § 52.10



§ 50.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CONTRACTOR.  Any person with whom the city has contracted for the
collection, conveyance, and disposal of solid waste within the city.



   DESIGNATED STREET or ALLEY.  The public street or alley adjacent to
any premises within the city which has been designated by the city or its
contractor as the street or alley on which solid waste generated on such
premises is to be placed for collection.



   GARBAGE.  Dry kitchen refuse (which shall mean the solids after the
liquids have been drained off), all meat, vegetable, and fruit refuse, small
dead animals and dead fowl, and small quantities of incidental rubbish or
trash typically included in household waste.



   HEAVY REFUSE.  Any metal rubbish other than small quantities of
incidental metal rubbish (other than small quantities of incidental metal
rubbish typically included among kitchen and household garbage) and any wood
or wood products other than those defined below as untreated wood products.



   RUBBISH.  Tin cans, bottles, glass, scraps of iron, tin, wire, or any
other metal.



   SOLID WASTE.  All garbage, heavy refuse, rubbish, trash, and untreated
wood products, as defined herein, generated on any premises within the city.



   TRASH.  Paper of all kinds, rags, old clothing, paper containers, old
rubber, pieces of wood, boxes, barrels, crates, feathers, weeds, grass,
and/or tree limbs.



   UNTREATED WOOD PRODUCTS.  Any and all raw, untreated wood products or
pulpy vegetation, including but not limited to raw lumber, tree limbs, and
brush-like vegetation.



(Ord. 1770, passed 7- -94)



§ 50.02  COLLECTION OF SOLID WASTE.



   All solid waste accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed,
and disposed of by the city or its contractor and it shall be unlawful for
any person to convey for hire over any public street or alley in the city any
solid waste generated on any premises not owned or occupied by such person as
the principal residence or place of business of such person.



(Ord. 1770, passed 7- -94)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.03  ACCUMULATION AND STORAGE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises
in the city to accumulate solid waste thereon so as to produce an unsightly
or ugly appearance or which may harbor reptiles or rodents, create a fire
hazard, or result in unsanitary conditions.



   (B)   All solid waste accumulated within any dwelling or other
building located on any premises in the city shall be stored by the owner or
occupant of such premises in a sanitary container.



   (C)   All solid waste stored outside of any dwelling or other
building located on any premises in the city shall be stored by the owner or
occupant of such premises in a container furnished for such purpose by the
city or its contractor and at a location other than within the easement or
right-of-way of any public street or alley adjacent to such premises.



(Ord. 1770, passed 7- -94)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.04  PLACEMENT FOR COLLECTION.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain any
solid waste on or adjacent to any public street or alley in the city except
in compliance with the provisions of divisions (B), (C) and (D) of this
section. In any prosecution under this section in the Municipal Court of the
city or any other court of competent jurisdiction, proof that any solid waste
was placed or maintained in violation of any provisions of this section shall
be prima facie proof that the same was so placed or maintained by the owner
or occupant of:



      (1)   The premises where it is so placed or maintained; or



      (2)   The premises immediately adjacent to the location on the
street or alley on which it was so placed or maintained.



   (B)   All solid waste must be placed for collection in that portion
of the easement or right-of-way of the designated street or alley not used
for vehicular travel.



   (C)   All garbage placed for collection must be enclosed in a
container furnished by the city or its contractor for such purpose, such
container may not be placed in the easement or right-of-way of the designated
street or alley before 6:00 p.m. of the day preceding the day designated by
the city or its contractor as the day on which garbage shall be collected and
all such containers must be removed from such easement or right-of-way no
later than 8:00 a.m. of the day following such designated day.



   (D)   Additional rules for the placement of waste for collection:



      (1)   Refuse, rubbish, trash and untreated wood may not be
placed in the easement or right-of-way of any street. All untreated wood
products must be cut into pieces of not more than five feet in length.



      (2)   Only waste connections polycarts may be used.



      (3)   Polycarts must be placed so that there is a three foot
clearance on all sides.



      (4)   No more than two cubic yards of debris of any kind may
be placed at the street. If more than two cubic yards is placed in the
street, the resident will be charged for the excess on the water bill at the
rate per yard defined by the city’s contract with waste connections. Any
debris of any kind placed at the street between Wednesday and Friday will be
picked up and the water account for the property from which it is removed
will be billed 100% of the cost of the removal at the rate defined by the
contract with waste connections.



      (5)   Tree limbs and debris must be cut to five foot lengths.



      (6)   Stumps and bagged debris must weigh less than 50 pounds.



      (7)   Property owners are responsible for any outstanding
balance for all charges on a water account for their property, whether such
account is in the owner’s name or the name of a tenant or lessee. No water
account will be opened at that property until such balance is paid in full.



(Ord. 1770, passed 7- -94; Am. Ord. 2016-2105, passed 2-16-16)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 50.05  AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE.



   In any prosecution in the Municipal Court of the city or any other
court of competent jurisdiction, it shall be an affirmative defense to a
violation of any subsection of this chapter if:



   (A)   The person conveying such solid waste is engaged in the
business of constructing new improve- ments or repairing or replacing
improvements already located on the premises in question pursuant to a permit
duly issued by the Building Official of the city and any solid waste
generated thereby is accumulated, stored, collected, conveyed, and disposed
of in accordance with written instructions there for issued by the City
Manager or the contractor; or



   (B)   The premises in question is not located in an area of the city
which has been designated by the current comprehensive zoning ordinance and
map of the city for single-family dwellings only and all solid waste
generated on such premises is accumulated, stored, collected, conveyed, and
disposed of in accordance with the written instructions therefor issued by
the City Manager or the contractor.



(Ord. 1770, passed 7- -94)



Cross-reference:



   Zoning code, see Ch. 155



§ 50.06  GARBAGE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL RATES.



   The following charges and rates shall be made and collected by the city
for solid waste collection:



   (A)   Residential: $22.78 per month for a residential size cart and
the collection and disposal of solid waste in such cart at each family unit
within the city and $14.37 per month for each additional cart at the same
family unit. FAMILY UNIT shall be construed to mean any one-family residence
or apartment, or any other one-family dwelling.



   (B)   Commercial or business: $22.78 per cart for the collection and
disposal of solid waste stored in each residential size container at a
commercial or business location within the city. The charge for each
additional container at such location shall be $14.37 per month.



(‘68 Code, § 37-21) (Ord. 1144, passed 9-11-67; Am. Ord. 1293, passed
9-16-74; Am. Ord. 1306, passed 9-8-75; Am. Ord. 1584, passed 7-16-84; Am.
Ord. 2001-1918, passed 1-8-01; Am. Ord. 2006-2148, passed 11-20-06; Am. Ord.
2007-2180, passed 11-5-07; Am. Ord. 2016-2105, passed 2-16-16)
