NO PASSING ZONES



§ 71.60  EAST SECOND STREET AND BRAZOS BOULEVARD.



   (A)   East Second Street, from a point 245 feet west of the 90º
turn to the left where it approaches and crosses the levee paralleling the
Old Brazos River, to its intersection with Brazos Boulevard.



   (B)   Brazos Boulevard, from its intersection with East Second
Street to a point 255 feet east of such intersection.



(Ord. 2001-1947, passed 10-1-01)



INTERSECTIONS CONTROLLED BY TRAFFIC SIGNALS



§ 71.70  GREEN, YELLOW AND RED LIGHTS AND COLORED LIGHTED ARROWS.



   The City Council designates as traffic control signal intersections
where traffic is to be controlled, 24 hours each day, by signals exhibiting
green, yellow and red colored lights and colored lighted arrows as defined in
the Texas Trans. code § 544.007:




   (A)   Brazosport Boulevard and Second Street.




   (B)   Brazosport Boulevard and Avenue A.



   (C)   Brazosport Boulevard and Gulf Boulevard.



   (D)   State Highway 332 and F.M. Highway 523.



   (E)   State Highway 332 and Oyster Creek Division Gate 9.



(Ord. 2001-1956, passed 11-5-01)  Penalty, see § 71.99



§ 71.71  GREEN, YELLOW AND RED LIGHTS ONLY.



   The City Council designates as traffic control signal intersections
where traffic is to be controlled, 24 hours each day, by signals exhibiting
green, yellow and red colored lights only as defined in the Texas Trans. Code
§ 544.007:



   (A)   Brazosport Boulevard and Skinner Street.



   (B)   Velasco Boulevard at Second Street.



   (C)   Velasco Boulevard at Avenue A.



   (D)   Velasco Boulevard at Gulf Boulevard.



   (E)   Second Street at Cherry Street.



   (F)   F.M. Highway 523 at Dow Levee Road.



   (G)   F.M. Highway 523 and Oyster Creek Division Gate 3.



(Ord. 2001-1956, passed 11-5-01)  Penalty, see § 71.99



§ 71.72  FLASHING RED LIGHTS ONLY.



   The City Council designates as traffic control signal intersections
where traffic is to be controlled, 24 hours each day, by signals exhibiting
flashing red colored lights only as defined in the Texas Trans. Code §
544.008:



   (A)   County Road 229 and F.M. Highway 1495.



   (B)   F.M. Highway 1495 and State Highway 36.



(Ord. 2001-1956, passed 11-5-01)  Penalty, see § 71.99



§ 71.73  DUTY WHEN TRAFFIC SIGNAL NOT FUNCTIONING.



   (A)   The operator of a vehicle approaching an intersection listed
in §§ 71.70 through 71.72 of this chapter where the traffic signal therein
authorized to be located is not functioning shall stop and yield right-of-way
in the manner required by the Texas Trans. Code § 545.153, at a designated
stop intersection.



   (B)   Appropriate signs conforming to the State Department’s
Manual and specifications and giving notice of the regulations adopted by
division (A) above shall be erected and posted by or at the direction of the
City Manager as soon as is reasonably practical after he or she becomes aware
that a traffic signal is not functioning.



   (C)   It is an affirmative defense to a violation of division (A)
above, if:



      (1)   The operator is directed to proceed without stopping by
someone authorized by the Transportation Code to give such direction; or



      (2)   The signs required by division (B) above have not been
erected and posted.



(Ord. 2002-1980, passed 5-7-02)  Penalty, see § 71.99



MULTIPLE LANE STREETS



§ 71.80  VELASCO BOULEVARD.



   Velasco Boulevard shall have four marked lanes of travel, two for
northbound traffic and two for southbound traffic, from its intersection with
Gulf Boulevard to its intersection with West Fourth Street.



(Ord. 2006-2140, passed 10-2-06)



§ 71.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor and upon conviction therefor assessed a fine not to exceed
$200; and each and every day such violation continues and each day or portion
of each day any such violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2001-1952, passed 10-1-01)



CHAPTER 72:  STOPPING, STANDING, AND PARKING



Section




General Provisions




   72.01   Emerging from alleys, private driveways, or buildings



   72.02   Obstruction of traffic



   72.03   Stopping, standing, and parking prohibited in certain places



   72.04   Parallel parking



   72.05   Angle parking



   72.06   Special parking



   72.07   Residential parking restrictions



   72.08   Unattended vehicles



   72.09   Parking for more than 48 hours prohibited



   72.10   Parking for certain purposes prohibited



   72.11   Starting parked vehicle



   72.12   Loading and unloading zones



   72.13   Vehicles exceeding 25 feet



   72.14   Designation of parking spaces for persons with disabilities
in private areas of the city




Impoundment




   72.25   Impoundment of standing or parked vehicles



   72.26   Liability of city



   72.27   Presumption that owner of vehicle illegally parked same



 



   72.99   Penalty



Statutory reference:



   Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, see
Tex. Transp. Code § 542.202(a)(2)



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 72.01  EMERGING FROM ALLEYS, PRIVATE DRIVEWAYS, OR BUILDINGS.



   The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building
shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or
sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yielding the right-of-way to any
pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision and upon entering the
roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the
roadway.



(‘68 Code, § 36-263) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62) Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.02  OBSTRUCTION OF TRAFFIC.



   No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked cross-walk unless
there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk
to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of
other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal
indication to proceed.



(‘68 Code, § 36-264) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62) Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.03  STOPPING, STANDING, AND PARKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN PLACES.



   No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, except when necessary
to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of
a police officer or traffic-control device in any of the following places:



   (A)   At any place where authorized signs or markings prohibit
stopping, standing or parking, including the following:



      (1)   Fourth Street, between its intersection with Dixie Drive
and its intersection with Brazosport Boulevard (SH 288).



      (2)   At any location on the southwesterly side of North
Avenue J, between Skinner Street and the southeasterly end of the 800 block
of North Avenue J.



      (3)   The south side of Eleventh Street, between its
intersection with Pecan Street and its intersection with Velasco Boulevard,
between 7:15 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. and between 3:15 p.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday
through Friday.



      (4)   The east side of Maple Street, between its intersection
with Fourth Street and its intersection with Eighth Street, between 7:15 a.m.
and 8:00 a.m. and between 3:15 p.m. and 4:00 p.m.. Monday through Friday.



      (5)   The south side of Fourth Street, between its
intersection with Maple Street and its intersection with Ash Street, between
7:15 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. and between 3:15 p.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday through
Friday.



      (6)   On the east side of Avenue B, between its intersection
with McNeil Street and its intersection Karankawa Street, between 7:15 a.m.
and 8:30 a.m. and between 2:30 p.m. and 3:30 p.m., Monday through Friday.



      (7)   On the south side of McNeil Street, between its
intersection with Avenue B and its intersection with Gulf Boulevard, between
7:15 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and between 2:30 p.m. and 3:30 p.m., Monday through
Friday.



      (8)   On the north side of Karankawa Street, between its
intersection with Avenue B and its intersection with Gulf Boulevard, between
7:15 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and between 2:30 p.m. and 3:30 p.m., Monday through
Friday.



      (9)   At any location on either side of the 1200, 1300 and
1400 blocks of North Gulf Boulevard.



      (10)   At any location on the north side of Seventh Street,
between Oak Street and Maple Street.



      (11)   Either side of the right-of-way of State Highway 332,
beginning at a point four-tenths (4/10) of a mile in an easterly direction
from the centerline of County Road 690 and ending at the bridge which carries
traffic traveling on State Highway 332 across the Intracostal Canal.



   (B)   On any sidewalk.



   (C)   In front of a public or private driveway.



   (D)   Within an intersection.



   (E)   On a crosswalk or within 20 feet of a cross-walk where signs
are posted or markings indicate this prohibition.



   (F)   In a safety zone.



   (G)   Within 30 feet of the approach to any flashing beacon, stop
sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of the roadway.



   (H)   Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing.



   (I)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.



   (J)   Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station.



   (K)   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure.



   (L)   In any tunnel or underpass unless signs or markings designate
the place and type of permissible parking.



   (M)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction
when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic.



   (N)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the
edge of the curb or roadway.



   (O)   In any alley or alleyway in such a manner or under such
conditions as to block the alley or leave insufficient width for free
movement of vehicular traffic. Under no condition is this width to be less
than ten feet.



   (P)   In any other place or manner so as to restrict the free flow
of traffic.



   (Q)   It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution for stopping,
standing or parking at a location specified in divisions (A)(3) through
(A)(9) above if such stopping, standing or parking occurs on a day when the
public school adjoining such location is not in session.



(‘68 Code, § 36-265) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62; Am. Ord. 1865, passed
7-2-99; Am. Ord. 1893, passed 3-6-00; Am. Ord. 2001-1950, passed 10-1-01;
2001-1955, passed 10-15-01; Am. Ord. 2001-1936, passed 4-15-02; Am. Ord.
2007-2172, passed 9-4-07; Am. Ord. 2011-2289, passed 10-3-11; Am. Ord.
2013-2057, passed 12-16-13)  Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.04  PARALLEL PARKING.



   Vehicles may be parked on all public streets or alleys in the city
provided the following conditions are met:



   (A)   The vehicle shall be headed in the direction of travel of the
nearest adjacent traffic lane.



   (B)   The wheels nearest the curb shall be approximately parallel to
and within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway.



   (C)   The manner of so parking such vehicle shall be in compliance
with all applicable provisions of this title and state law.



(‘68 Code, § 36-266) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62)  Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.05  ANGLE PARKING.



   (A)   Only angle parking of passenger cars and light trucks, as
defined in the Transportation Code, shall be permitted at the following
locations:



      (1)   The south side of the 100 block of East Fourth Street,
between the right-of-way for East Park Avenue and the intersecting alley
running parallel to East Park Avenue.



      (2)   Both sides of the 100 and 200 block of West Broad
Street, between West Park Avenue and Oak Street.



      (3)   The south side of the 100 and 200 blocks of West Second
Street, between West Park Avenue and Oak Street.



      (4)   Both sides of West Park Avenue, between Second Street
and Fourth Street.



      (5)   Both sides of East Park Avenue, between Second Street
and Fourth Street.



      (6)   Both sides of the 100 block of East Broad Street,
between East Park Avenue and Navigation Boulevard.



   (B)   No part or contents of a vehicle parked at one of the
locations described in division (A) above shall protrude into or cause a
hazard with other vehicles or pedestrians in the nearest adjacent traffic
lane, sidewalk or crosswalk.



   (C)   Every vehicle parked at one of the locations described in
division (A) above shall be parked entirely within a single designated space
and no part of such vehicle shall protrude into an adjacent designated space.



(‘68 Code, § 36-267) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62; Am. Ord. 2002-1962,
passed 1-7-02; Am. Ord. 2002-1970, passed 2-19-02)  Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.06  SPECIAL PARKING.



   (A)   The Chief of Police, with the approval of the City Traffic
Engineer, may issue special permits for a definite period of time to allow
parking of an unusual  nature which may be contrary to or in violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use this permit for
purposes, places, or times other than those clearly indicated in the written
permit.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person other than those named in
the permit to use the permit for any purpose whatsoever.



(‘68 Code, § 36-268) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62) Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.07  RESIDENTIAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of, owning or
operating a vehicle to allow, permit to park or store such vehicle habitually
on that portion of the street abutting residential property when such person
does not own or occupy the residence or a portion of the lot in front or
alongside of which such vehicle is habitually parked or stored; or for any
person or the occupant or owner of such residence to allow, permit to park or
store at any time any vehicle or any equipment in the front yard of any
single- family or duplex residence except on an improved surface.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for the operator or any person in charge
of a truck tractor to park or to permit or allow such truck tractor or any
trailer drawn there by such truck tractor to be parked on that portion of any
street in the city abutting residential property.



   (C)   As used in this section, the following words or terms shall
have the following meanings:



      DRIVEWAY. An area of a lot constructed, improved, maintained or
set for the primary purpose of vehicular access to a single-family or duplex
residence from a public street or the parking of vehicles at such residence.



      FRONT YARD. The area of an improved single-family or duplex lot,
excluding driveways, circumscribed by the front and side property lines of
the lot and an imaginary line coinciding with and parallel to the front
building line of the residential structure extending to the side property
lines. The front yard of a corner lot shall be determined by the street
address of the residence.



      HABITUALLY. Parking a vehicle on the same portion of a street for
parts of at least three consecutive days.



      IMPROVED SURFACE. Any area that, for purposes of this section, is
not part of a driveway and that has been paved for parking or storage of
vehicles or equipment owned or operated by the occupants of a single-family
or duplex residence in accordance with this section. An improved area may be
paved with concrete, asphalt, pavers, shale, gravel, crushed rock or other
material, constructed to a minimum thickness of not less than four inches so
as to lessen or prevent the seepage of any fuel, oil, or other chemical
substance contacting such surface from penetrating to the soil below the
area, and may not exceed 350 square feet.



      PARK or STORE. The parking or storing of a vehicle or equipment
for a period up to but not exceeding three continuous hours without removing
such vehicle or equipment from the parking area for a period of at least
eight continuous hours and shall not include the placement of any vehicle or
equipment on blocks, jacks or stands.



      RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY. Real property on which only a dwelling as
defined therein can be constructed or located as the principal structure
under the applicable provisions of Chapter 150 of this Code.



      TRAILER.  A vehicle without motive power of its own designed to
be drawn by a truck tractor for the purpose of transporting personal property.



      TRUCK TRACTOR.  A motor vehicle designed and used primarily to
draw another vehicle but which is not constructed to carry a load other than
a part of the weight of the other vehicle being drawn and its load.



      VEHICLE or EQUIPMENT. Includes but is not limited to house
trailers, mobile homes, motor vehicles, trucks, passenger motor vehicles,
motor homes, camper cabins, motorcycles, trailers, RV, and boats.



   (D)   Enforcement. The provisions of this section may be enforced by
any law enforcement officer, the Building Official, a building inspector or
any code enforcement officer of the city.



(‘68 Code, § 36-269) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62; Am. Ord. 2002-1986,
passed 7-15-02; Am. Ord. 2017-2141, passed 10-16-17)  Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.08  UNATTENDED VEHICLES.



   No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to
stand unattended without first stopping the engine, and effectively setting
the brakes thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front
wheels to the curb or side of the roadway.



(‘68 Code, § 36-274)  Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.09  PARKING FOR MORE THAN 48 HOURS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to allow,
cause, or permit such vehicle to remain standing or parked on any street,
alley, avenue, or public way, within the city for more than 48 hours
continuously.



(‘68 Code, § 36-275)  Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.10  PARKING FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES PROHIBITED.



   No person shall park a vehicle upon any street in the city for the
principal purpose of:



   (A)   Displaying such vehicle for sale.



   (B)   Greasing or repairing of such vehicle, except repairs
necessitated by an emergency.



(‘68 Code, § 36-276) (Ord. 1706, passed 7-1-91; Am. Ord. passed  - -96)
Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.11  STARTING PARKED VEHICLE.



   No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing, or parked
unless and until such movement can be made with safety.



(‘68 Code, § 36-272) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62) Penalty, see § 72.99



§ 72.12  LOADING AND UNLOADING ZONES.



   (A)   Designation. The Traffic Commission is hereby authorized to
determine and designate the location of passenger and freight curb loading
zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and
stating the hours during which the provisions therefor are applicable.



(‘68 Code, § 36-277)



   (B)   Use of passenger zones.  No person shall  stop, stand, or
park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the
expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a
passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to
such curb loading zones are effective; and then only for a period of time not
to exceed three minutes, except when such spaces are adjacent to and serving
a hotel or bus station, when such period of time may not exceed 15 minutes.



(‘68 Code, § 36-278)



   (C)   Use of freight zones.



      (1)   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any
length of time in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during the
hours so set aside except that commercial vehicles may so stop, stand, or
park for the expeditious unloading and delivery or loading and pickup of
material. In no case shall the stop for unloading, loading, pickup, or
delivery of material exceed 30 minutes.



      (2)   The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily
at a place marked as a freight curb loading zone for the purpose of and while
actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does
not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials
which is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone.



(‘68 Code, § 36-279)



§ 72.13  VEHICLES EXCEEDING 25 FEET.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle, trailer, or
combination thereof on the streets, alleys, or other public ways of the city
which shall exceed 25 feet in length.



(‘68 Code, § 36-280)  Penalty, see § 72.99



Cross-reference:



   Recreational vehicles; parking on streets, see § 120.02



§ 72.14  DESIGNATION OF PARKING SPACES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES IN
PRIVATE PARKING AREAS OF THE CITY.



   (A)   Designation. When the owner of a private parking area located
within the city determines to voluntarily set aside and designate certain
parking spaces for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting persons with
disabilities, such designation shall be enforceable under the Texas Trans.
Code § 681.011, which is hereby made applicable pursuant to subsection (f)
thereof, provided that said designation is made in the manner specified
herein and that such vehicles are identified by:



      (1)   Special license plates issued under the Texas Trans.
Code § 502.253 and displayed on such vehicle;



      (2)   Special license plates issued under the Texas Trans.
Code § 502.254 and displayed on such vehicle; or



      (3)   A disabled parking placard issued under the Texas Trans.
Code § 681.003 placed on the rearview mirror of such vehicle’s front
windshield.



   (B)   Method of designation.  All parking spaces in private parking
areas which are designated exclusively for vehicles used for transporting
persons with disabilities shall be designated in the manner specified by the
Texas Commission of Licensing and Regulation pursuant to Tex. Rev. Civ.
Stat., Art. 9102, § 5(i), relating to the identification and dimensions of
parking spaces for persons with disabilities.



   (C)   Assignments of designated spaces.  At least half of all
uncovered parking spaces designated exclusively for vehicles used for
transporting persons with disabilities in each private parking area shall be
assigned for the exclusive use of vehicles displaying a white on blue shield
disabled parking placard, except that if an odd number of spaces is
designated, only the number of spaces that is the largest whole number less
than half of the number of designated spaces must be so assigned. 
Van-accessible parking spaces shall be counted as assigned spaces under this
section.  These assigned spaces must be the spaces located closest to an
accessible route to an entrance accessible to a person with a disability. 
The remaining designated parking spaces may be used by vehicles displaying a
white on blue shield disabled parking placard, a white on red shield disabled
parking placard, or license plates issued under the Texas Trans. Code §
502.253.



   (D)   Blocking disabled parking space.



      (1)   No person shall stop, stand or park a motor vehicle at a
location which blocks access to a parking space designated in accordance with
division (B) above for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting persons
with disabilities.



      (2)   It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under
this section if such vehicle is identified by:



         (a)   Special license plates issued under the Texas
Trans. Code § 502.253 and displayed on such vehicle;



         (b)   Special license plates issued under the Texas
Trans. Code § 502.254 and displayed on such vehicle; or



         (c)   A disabled parking placard issued under the Texas
Trans. Code § 681.003 placed on the rearview mirror of such vehicle’s
front windshield.



(Ord. 2001-1941, passed 9-4-01)  Penalty, see § 72.99



IMPOUNDMENT



§ 72.25  IMPOUNDMENT OF STANDING OR PARKED VEHICLES.



   (A)   Any vehicle which shall be or remain standing or parked upon
any public street, avenue, way, alley, or other public place, may be removed
by or upon order of the Chief of Police, and placed in storage in a
privately-operated garage or other place designated or maintained by the
city, under the following circumstances:



      (1)   When any vehicle is found upon a street, avenue, alley,
way, or public place and a report has been previously made that such vehicle
has been stolen or complaint has been filed and a warrant issued thereon,
charging that such vehicle has been stolen or converted in violation of law.



      (2)   When any police officer of the city has reasonable
grounds to believe that any vehicle has been abandoned.



      (3)   When a police officer arrests any person driving or in
control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is or may be
required by law to take the one arrested immediately before a magistrate, or
if the arrested one is immediately taken before a magistrate, and when the
arrested one is the sole occupant or the owner of the vehicle and is
immediately placed in custody.



      (4)   When a vehicle is so disabled that its normal operation
is impossible or impractical and the persons in charge of the vehicle are
incapacitated by reason of physical injury or other causes to such an extent
as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or cannot be found or
are not in immediate vicinity of such vehicle.



      (5)   When such vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge,
viaduct, or causeway, or in a tunnel or tube and constitutes an obstruction
to traffic.



      (6)   When any such vehicle is illegally parked so as to block
the entrance to any private driveway and it is impracticable to move such
vehicle from in front of the driveway to any other point on the highway.



      (7)   When any vehicle constitutes a hazard, or interferes
with a normal function of a govern- mental agency, or by reason of any
catastrophe, emergency, or unusual circumstance the safety of the vehicle is
imperiled.



      (8)   When any vehicle is left standing or parked unattended
for more than 48 hours in violation of any applicable section of this code,
state law, or city ordinances, rules or regulations; provided, however, that
in the event such vehicle is parked or standing immediately in front of or
immediately adjacent to property owned by the owner of such vehicle, or
property rented by such owner, before such vehicle shall be removed, the
owner thereof shall be given written notice after the expiration of 48 hours
and shall be given an additional 24 hours to remove or cause to be removed
such vehicle. Such written notice may be given by depositing the same in the
United States mail, addressed to the owner at the address given on the
registration receipt of the vehicle, or his or her last known address.



   (B)   In order to obtain possession of a vehicle stored under the
provisions of this section, the claimant must produce satisfactory evidence
of ownership or right to possession within 30 days from the date of such
storage and, in addition thereto, must pay all charges for storage and
removal of such vehicle, in addition to any fine.



   (C)   If a vehicle removed under this section is not claimed within
30 days from the date of storage, the same may be sold by the city or the
garage where the same is stored, for storage charges, as provided by law.



(‘68 Code, § 36-270)



Statutory reference:



   Removal of illegally parked vehicles, see Tex. Transp. Code § 545.305



§ 72.26  LIABILITY OF CITY.



   The provisions of § 72.25 shall not be construed to relieve from or
lessen the responsibility of any person who shall leave his vehicle parked on
the streets of the city in such a manner that the same may be impounded; nor
shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of impounding
or causing to be impounded such vehicle.



(‘68 Code, § 36-271)



§ 72.27  PRESUMPTION THAT OWNER OF VEHICLE ILLEGALLY PARKED SAME.



   In any prosecution charging a violation of any ordinance or regulation
governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular
vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such
ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the
complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such
vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the
registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such
vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation
occurred.



(‘68 Code, § 36-273)



§ 72.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is otherwise provided shall be subject to the provisions
of § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person violating the provisions of § 72.03 (A)(2) through
(A)(11), § 72.05, or § 72.14 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction therefor, shall be fined not to exceed $200.  Each day any such
violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 1893, passed 3-6-00; Am. Ord. 2001-1941, passed 9-4-01; Am. Ord.
2001-1950, passed 10-1-01; Am. Ord. 2002-1962, passed 1-7-02; Am. Ord.
2011-2289, passed 10-3-11)



CHAPTER 73:  BICYCLES



Section



   73.01   Definition



   73.02   Parking



   73.03   Riding on sidewalks



   73.04   Municipal playgrounds and parks



Statutory reference:



   Authority of city to regulate operation of bicycles, see Tex. Transp.
Code § 542.202(a)(4)



§ 73.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter, BICYCLE shall mean every device
propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem
wheels, and including any device generally recognized as a bicycle though
equipped with two front or two rear wheels.



(‘68 Code, § 8-1) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62)



§ 73.02  PARKING.



   (A)   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon
the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the
bicycle or against a building or at the curb in such a manner as to afford
the least obstruction to pedestrian or vehicular traffic.



   (B)   No person shall leave a bicycle against a window, doorway,
exit, parking meter, mailbox, or any other object or passageway.



(‘68 Code, § 8-19) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 73.03  RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.



   (A)   No person shall operate a bicycle on any sidewalk within a
business district.



   (B)   Every person operating a bicycle on a sidewalk shall do so
upon the right side of the walk insofar as practicable, such person shall at
all times yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.



(‘68 Code, § 8-20) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 73.04  MUNICIPAL PLAYGROUNDS AND PARKS.



   No person shall operate a bicycle upon any municipal playground where
children are playing without the permission of the person having supervision
of the children.



(‘68 Code, § 8-21) (Ord. 1061, passed 1-28-62) Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 74:  RAILROADS



Section



   74.01   Definition



   74.02   Unguarded street crossing; stop and resumption of travel



   74.03   Speed limit



   74.04   Obedience to warning devices



   74.05   Swing-span bridges



§ 74.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the phrase UNGUARDED STREET CROSSING
shall mean any crossing within the city across a railroad track which is
commonly used as or known as a public street or right-of-way for use by the
public and which is unguarded by any automatically actuated gate or
electrical signal device indicating the approach of a railroad train. 
Further, in order to be a guarded street crossing, such gate or electrical
signal device must be actuated by the approaching train at a distance of not
less than 300 feet and must continue to guard the crossing by such gate
remaining down or by such signal device flashing a red signal until the
entire railroad train has passed such crossing a distance of not less than 50
feet. A railroad crossing is deemed to be unguarded if the electrical signal
device or gate warning of the train’s approach cannot be clearly observed a
distance of 300 feet in any direction.



(‘68 Code, § 30-1) (Ord. 1057, passed 11-6-61)



§ 74.02  UNGUARDED STREET CROSSING; STOP AND RESUMPTION OF TRAVEL.



   (A)   The person operating any railroad train within the city shall
be required to stop such railroad train at a distance of no less than 15 feet
nor more than 50 feet  from the  nearest street right-of-way line whenever
such railroad train is approaching an unguarded street crossing.



(‘68 Code, § 30-2)



   (B)   (1)   At all unguarded street crossings, a railroad train,
after stopping, shall not again commence its movement across such unguarded
street crossing until a flagger shall have been placed on either side of the
railroad tracks at such crossing equipped with red reflecting lights clearly
visible at a distance of not less than 300 feet.



      (2)   It shall be the duty of each flagger to wave the red
signal light to and fro from the time such train commences its movement
within five feet of the unguarded street crossing until the complete train
shall have passed such unguarded street crossing a distance of not less than
five feet.



(‘68 Code, § 30-3)



(Ord. 1057, passed 11-6-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 74.03  SPEED LIMIT.



   It being necessary to eliminate or reduce safety hazards which the City
Council finds exist at each such location, it shall be unlawful for any
railroad engine, motor car, hand car, coach, train or other similar railroad
equipment to be operated at a rate of speed greater than 15 miles per hour
when approaching or traversing any of the following railroad crossings in the
city:



   (A)   F.M. Highway 523;



   (B)   Gulf Boulevard;



   (C)   Avenue D;



   (D)   Avenue A;



   (E)   First Street;



   (F)   Broad Street;



   (G)   Fourth Street;



   (H)   Fifth Street;



   (I)   Eighth Street;



   (J)   Ash Street;



   (K)   Cherry Street; and



   (L)   Pine Street.



(‘68 Code, § 30-4) (Ord. 1057, passed 11-6-61; Am. Ord. passed  - -96;
Am. Ord. 1802, passed 8-5-96)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 74.04  OBEDIENCE TO WARNING DEVICES.



   (A)   Whenever any person driving a vehicle approaches a railroad
grade crossing under any of the circumstances stated in this section, the
driver of such vehicle shall stop within 50 feet, but not less than 15 feet,
from the nearest rail of such railroad, and shall not proceed until he can do
so safely. The foregoing requirements shall apply when:



      (1)   A clearly visible electric or mechanical signal device
gives warning of the immediate approach of a railroad train.



      (2)   A crossing gate is lowered or when a human flagger gives
or continues to give a signal of the approach of a railroad train.



      (3)   A railroad train approaching within approximately 1500
feet of the highway crossing emits a signal audible from such distance and
such railroad train, by reason of its speed or nearness to such crossing, is
an immediate hazard.



      (4)   An approaching railroad train is plainly visible and is
in hazardous proximity to such crossing.



   (B)   No person shall drive any vehicle through, around, or under
any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing while such gate or
barrier is closed or is being opened or closed.



(‘68 Code, § 30-6) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 74.05  SWING-SPAN BRIDGES.



   (A)   All railroad swing-span or drawbridges located over the Old
Brazos River within the city limits, shall be maintained in the open to
navigation position at all times, except when in actual use for a train
crossing, which time shall not exceed 15 minutes before or 15 minutes after
the actual crossing of any train, or for any necessary maintenance
purposes.  When any such bridge is to be closed for necessary maintenance
purposes for a length of time in excess of two hours, the owner or operator
of the bridge shall notify the Police Chief of the proposed length of time
when the bridge is to be closed, the purposes for which the bridge is to be
closed, and any other information which the Police Chief feels is necessary
for the safety of those vessels navigating the Old Brazos River.



   (B)   All railroad swing-span or drawbridges located on the Old
Brazos River shall be equipped with warning lights sufficient so as to warn
any and all harbor traffic whenever the bridge is being maintained in a
closed position because of the passage of a train or for necessary
maintenance. The lights shall be sufficient if they are as follows:



      (1)   There shall be at least three green to red navigation
lights located in the center of the bridge.



      (2)   At any time the bridge is being maintained in a closed
position, the lights shall be changed from green to red and shall remain as
such until the bridge is again opened to navigation, at which time the lights
shall be changed back to green.



      (3)   All lights required in this section shall be securely
attached to the structure and shall be of sufficient candle power as to be
visible against the background lighting at a distance of at least 2,000 yards
90% of the nights of the year.



(‘68 Code, § 30-7(a),(b)) (Ord. 1327, passed 9-20-76)



CHAPTER 75:  OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES



Section



   75.01   Definitions



   75.02   Overweight vehicles prohibited on the following streets or
portions thereof



   75.03   Affirmative defense



§ 75.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   GVW.  Gross vehicle weight.



   OVERWEIGHT VEHICLE.  A vehicle the gvw of which prohibits such vehicle
from being operated on a street designated in § 75.02 of this chapter.



   VEHICLE.  A device that can be used to transport or draw persons or
property on a street or highway other than a devise exclusively used on
stationary rails or tracts.



(Ord. 1879, passed 10-18-99)



§ 75.02  OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES PROHIBITED ON THE FOLLOWING STREETS OR
PORTIONS THEREOF.



   No person shall operate a vehicle having a gvw exceeding 6,000 pounds
on any portion of Varner Street between Brazosport Boulevard and Avenue L or
any portion of the 1700 or 1800 blocks of Avenue L.



(Ord. 1879, passed 10-18-99)



§ 75.03  AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE.



   It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under any division
of § 75.02 of this chapter if the overweight vehicle in question is:



   (A)   Owned by the city or firm or corporation having a franchise
from the city to provide utility services or to collect and haul solid waste
within the city;



   (B)   Owned by a firm or corporation having a contract to construct,
reconstruct, repair or maintain the public street or portion thereof upon
which such vehicle is then and there being operated; or,



   (C)   One on which there is displayed thereon a valid permit issued
by the City Secretary certifying that the owner thereof has posted with the
City Secretary  a bond in the principal amount of Fifty Thousand and no/100
($50,000.00) Dollars, with good and sufficient corporate surety licensed to
do surety business in the State of Texas and approved by the City Manager,
conditioned that the owner of such overweight vehicle will pay to the city,
within ten (10) days after request therefor is made in writing by the City
Manager, such sum as the City Manager may determine in this sole discretion
to be the annual cost, if any, necessary to maintain such street as a result
of the overweight vehicle described in such permit being driven thereon.
Provided, however, where more than one (1) such permit has been issued for
the same period of time, such excess cost shall be prorated between all such
permittees. Provided further, where the same person owns more than one (1)
overweight vehicle, only one (1) permit and only one (1) bond shall be
required for all such vehicles.



(Ord. 1879, passed 10-18-99)



CHAPTER 76: TRANSPORTATION OF FREIGHT AND HAZARDOUS MATERIAL



Section



   76.01   Definitions



   76.02   Restrictions on transportation of cargo



   76.03   Affirmative defenses



§ 76.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BULK.  Liquid or gaseous cargo other than hazardous material.



   CARGO.  Any property capable of being transported by means of a truck
or a truck tractor with trailer attached.



   FREIGHT.  Cargo other than bulk or hazardous material.



   HAZARDOUS MATERIAL.  Any cargo describedas a hazardous material in the
current edition of the Emergency Response Guidebook published by the U.S.
Department of Transportation.



   LIGHT TRUCK.  A truck, including a pickup truck, panel delivery truck,
or carryall truck, that has a manufacturer’s rated carrying capacity of
2,000 pounds or less.



   MOTOR VEHICLE.  A self-propelled vehicle.



   TRAILER.  A vehicle designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle to
transport property.



   TRUCK.  A motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily to
transport property.



   TRUCK TRACTOR.  A motor vehicle designed and used primarily to draw
another vehicle but not constructed to carry a load other than a part of the
weight of the other vehicle and its load.



   VEHICLE.  A device that can be used to transport or draw cargo on a
street or highway other than a device exclusively used on stationary rails or
tracks.



(Ord. 2002-1985, passed 6-17-02)



§ 76.02  RESTRICTIONS ON TRANSPORTATION OF CARGO.



   (A)   No person shall operate a truck other than a light truck, or a
truck tractor with a trailer attached thereto, for the purpose of
transporting bulk or freight on any public street in the city, or any portion
thereof, other than a street, or portion thereof, designated in division (C)
of this section for the transportation of bulk or freight.



   (B)   No person shall operate a truck, or a truck tractor with a
trailer attached thereto, for the purpose of transporting any hazardous
material on any public street in the city, or any portion thereof, other than
a street, or portion thereof, designated in division (C) of this section for
the transportation of hazardous material.



   (C)   The following streets, or indicated portions thereof, are
authorized for the bi-directional transportation of bulk, freight or
hazardous materials, as designated:



      (1)   Highway 332, within city limits: bulk, freight or
hazardous materials.



      (2)   Brazosport Boulevard (State Highway 288), within city
limits: bulk, freight or hazardous materials.



      (3)   Navigation Boulevard (FM 1495) between the south city
limits and FM 523: bulk, freight or hazardous materials.



      (4)   FM 523 from Navigation Boulevard (FM 1495) junction
north to Highway 332: bulk, freight or hazardous materials.



      (5)   Velasco Boulevard from FM 523 junction to South Avenue
A: bulk or freight only.



      (6)   South Avenue A, from Archer to Division Street: bulk or
freight only.



      (7)   Division Street, from South Avenue A to Gulf Boulevard:
bulk or freight only.



      (8)   Gulf Boulevard, from Brazosport Boulevard to Navigation
Boulevard (FM 1495): bulk, freight or hazardous materials.



      (9)   West 4th Street, from Brazosport Boulevard to Arbutus
Street: bulk or freight only.



      (10)   Arbutus Street, from West 4th Street to West 2nd
Street: bulk or freight only.



      (11)   Oak Street, from West Brazos to West 4th Street: bulk
or freight only.



      (12)   West 4th Street, from Oak Street to Navigation
Boulevard (FM 1495): bulk and freight only.



      (13)   East 4th Street, from Navigation Boulevard (FM 1495) to
Sycamore: freight and hazardous materials.



      (14)   Sycamore Street, from East 4th Street to East 2nd
Street: bulk, freight and hazardous materials.



      (15)   East Brazos, entire length: bulk, freight and hazardous
materials. Provided, all ingress and egress for fuel deliveries shall use the
East 4th Street exit from Navigation Boulevard (FM 1495) to Sycamore Street
to West Brazos.



      (16)   West 8th Street, from Navigation Boulevard (FM 1495) to
Cherry Street: bulk and freight only.



      (17)   Cherry Street, from West 8th Street to Highway 36: bulk
and freight only.



      (18)   South Avenue D, from Velasco Boulevard to Navigation
Boulevard (FM 1495): bulk and freight only.



      (19)   East 2nd Street, from FM 1495 to end of roadway: bulk,
freight and hazardous materials. Provided, however, all hazardous materials
deliveries shall ingress and egress using the East 4th Street exit from
Navigation Boulevard (F.M. 1495) to Sycamore Street to East 2nd Street.



      (20)   Zapata Street, from Brazosport Boulevard to end of
roadway: bulk and freight only.



      (21)   Skinner Street, from Brazosport Boulevard to North
Avenue J: bulk and freight only.



      (22)   North Avenue J, from Skinner Street to Varner Street:
bulk and freight only.



      (23)   Varner Street, from North Avenue J to Brazosport
Boulevard, bulk and freight only.



      (24)   Victoria Street, from Brazosport Boulevard to end of
roadway: bulk and freight only.



      (25)   Archer Street, from South Avenue A to South Gulf
Boulevard: bulk and freight only.



      (26)   Sailfish, from Highway 332 to end of roadway: bulk and
freight only.



      (27)   Tarpon, from Sailfish to Marlin Avenue: bulk and
freight only.



      (28)   Marlin Avenue, from Tarpon to the end of the roadway:
bulk and freight only.



      (29)   Casco, from Highway 332 to end of roadway: bulk and
freight only.



   (D)   All liquid and solid hazardous materials, including
precursors, are prohibited within a one  city block radius of the City Hall
of the city.



   (E)   Box or cargo vans delivering supplies and cargo within the one
block radius of the City Hall of the city are subject to a 15-minute or
one-fourth hour parking rule.



(Ord. 2002-1985, passed 6-17-02) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 76.03  AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES.



   It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under § 76.02(A)
if the truck or truck tractor in question is:



   (A)   Owned by the city or a firm or corporation having a franchise
from the city to provide utility services or to collect and haul solid waste
within the city;



   (B)   Owned by a firm or corporation having a contract to construct,
reconstruct, repair or maintain the public street or portion thereof upon
which such vehicle is then and there being operated;



   (C)   Is making a bulk or freight residential delivery from an
approved route designated in § 76.02(C) and the operator is ingressing or
egressing such residence utilizing the shortest distance between the approved
route and the delivery destination; or



   (D)   Is delivering fuel to an area outside of the approved
hazardous materials route designated in § 76.02(C) and the operator is
ingressing or egressing such area utilizing the shortest distance between the
approved route and the delivery destination.



(Ord. 2002-1985, passed 6-17-02) Penalty, see § 10.99
