necessary, shall make or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all
persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge
in relation to the matter under investiga- tion, and shall cause the same to
be reduced to writing.



('68 Code, § 14-19) (Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50)



§ 92.18  AUTHORITY TO SUMMON WITNESSES.



   The Fire Marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to
testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this
subchapter, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the
production of any book, paper, or document deemed pertinent thereto. The Fire
Marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and
affirmations to any persons appearing before him as witnesses.



('68 Code, § 14-20) (Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50)



§ 92.19  PRIVATE INVESTIGATIONS; SEPARATION OF WITNESSES.



   All investigations held by or under the direction of the Fire Marshal
may, in his discretion, be private, and persons other than those required to
be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held,
and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed
to communicate with each other until they have been examined.



('68 Code, § 14-21) (Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50)



§ 92.20  EVIDENCE OF CRIME IN CONNECTION WITH FIRE.



   If the Fire Marshal shall be of the opinion that there is evidence
sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with the attempt
to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal
conduct in connection with any fire, he shall cause such person to be
lawfully arrested and charged with such offense or either of them, and shall
furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with
the names of witnesses and all the information obtained by him including a
copy of all pertinent and material testimony taken in the case.



('68 Code, § 14-22) (Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50)



§ 92.21  MISCONDUCT OF WITNESSES SUMMONED.



   Any witness who refuses to be sworn, or who refuses to appear or
testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the Fire Marshal or who fails or
refuses to produce any book, paper, or document touching any matter under
examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the
proceedings of the Fire Marshal in the matter of such investigation or
inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter
under investigation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and it shall be
the duty of the Fire Marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted.



('68 Code, § 14-23) (Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.22  RIGHT OF ENTRY; INSPECTION OF PREMISES.



   (A)   The Fire Marshal shall have the authority, at all times of the
day or night, when necessary in the performance of the duties imposed upon
him by the provisions of this chapter, to enter upon and examine any building
or premises where any fire has occurred, and other buildings and premises
adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only with
reason and good discretion.



('68 Code, § 14-24)



   (B)   The Fire Marshal, upon the complaint of any person having an
interest in any building or property adjacent thereto, or without any
complaint, shall have the right at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of
examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the
city, and it shall be his duty, monthly or more often, to enter upon and make
or cause to be entered upon and made, a thorough examination of all
mercantile, manu-facturing, and public buildings together with the premises
belonging thereto. Whenever he shall find any building or other structure
which, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidated condition, or
for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to
endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that the fire would
endanger persons or property therein, and when-ever he shall find an improper
or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces, or other heating
appliances of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues, and pipes with
which the same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting
devices or electrical wiring, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of
explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals,
vegetable products, ashes, combustible, inflammable refuse materials,
waste-paper, rags, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or
liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to
firefighters combatting a fire or to occupants, he shall order the same to be
removed or remedied, and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the
owner or occupant of the building or premises. If said owner or occupant
deems himself aggrieved by such order he may, within five days, appeal such
order to the Mayor, who shall investigate the cause of the complaint and,
unless such order is revoked by the mayor, such order shall remain in force
and be forthwith complied with by said owner or occupant. Any owner or
occupant who fails to comply with such order within a ten-day period from the
date of such notice shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.



('68 Code, § 14-25)



(Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50) Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   Authority of city to provide for condemnation and removal of structures
constituting fire hazards, Tex. Loc. Gov't Code § 342.012



§ 92.23  RECORDS OF FIRES TO BE KEPT; MONTHLY REPORT.



   (A)   The Fire Marshal shall keep in his office a record of all
fires, together with all facts, statistics, and circumstances, including the
origin of the fires and the amounts of the loss, which may be deter- mined by
the investigation required by this chapter.



('68 Code, § 14-26)



   (B)   At the end of each month, the Fire Marshal shall report to the
State Fire Marshal all existing hazardous conditions together with a separate
report on each fire in the city during the month. 



('68 Code, § 14-27)



(Ord. 319, passed 5-10-50)



FREEPORT FIRE AND E.M.S. DEPARTMENT



§ 92.35  ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPARTMENT; DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   For the protection of property and lives within the city,
there is hereby established and there shall be maintained by the city a
department to be known as the Freeport Fire and E.M.S. Department.



('68 Code, § 14-39)



   (B)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the word E.M.S. shall mean
emergency medical service and the word DEPARTMENT shall mean the Freeport
Fire and E.M.S. Department.



('68 Code, § 14-38)



(Ord. 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed 12-21-98)



§ 92.36  ORGANIZATION.



   The Department shall consist of all firefighters and e.m.s. personnel
selected as provided in § 92.37, both those employed by the city as well as
those who serve without compensation and who, in this subchapter, shall be
referred to as "reserves".



('68 Code, § 14-40) (Ord. 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed
12-21-98)



§ 92.37  APPLICATION, APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.



   (A)   Any person who desires to be a firefighter or e.m.s. personnel
with the Department shall file with the Fire Chief an application developed
by the Fire Chief, with the consent of the City Manager, indicating thereon
whether such person desires to be a firefighter, an e.m.s. personnel, or
both, and whether such person seeks appointment as an employee of the city or
as a reserve.



('68 Code, § 14-41)



   (B)   Only persons whose ability, education, physical condition,
certifications and  personality assure that such person will, as a
firefighter or E.M.S. personnel, or both, be an asset to the Department may
be appointed.



('68 Code, § 14-42)



   (C)   The Fire Chief shall, with the approval of the City Manager,
appoint and may remove all firefighters and E.M.S. personnel, paid and
reserve.



   (D)   The City Manager alone shall determine which firefighters and
which E.M.S. personnel appointed by the Fire Chief with the approval of the
City Manager shall be employees of the city and which shall be reserves; but
where an employee of the city is appointed both a firefighter and an E.M.S.
personnel, such person shall receive only one salary.



   (E)   A qualified person who is an employee of the city but who, as
such, works in another department of the city may be appointed a firefighter
or E.M.S. personnel, or both, but only as a reserve.



(Ord. 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed 12-21-98)



§ 92.38  APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL OF CHIEF, ETC.



   The Fire Chief shall be appointed and may be removed by the City
Manager. With the consent of the City Manager, the Fire Chief may appoint and
remove such other officers as may be needed for the Department. The Fire
Chief shall be an employee of the city but any other officer may be employee
of the city or a reserve.



(Ord 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed 12-21-98)



§ 92.39  CONTROL OF ACTIVITY; ORGANIZATION.



   (A)   The activity and organization of the Department shall be
subject to the control of the Fire Chief, subject to the approval of the City
Manager.



   (B)   All firefighters and E.M.S. personnel, whether employees of
the city or reserves, shall perform their duties under the direction of the
Fire Chief and other officers appointed as provided in this subchapter,
without regard to whether any such other officer is an employee of the city
or a reserve.



   (C)   The firefighters and E.M.S. personnel of the Department may
form an association (other than a volunteer fire department or an emergency
medical service) and, if a majority of the members thereof approve, establish
the same as a non-profit corporation under the laws of the state. The
membership of such association shall be limited to persons selected to be
personnel of the Department as provided in § 92.37 of this code but
membership in such association shall not be required of such personnel. The
membership of such association shall elect their own officers and adopt a
constitution and by-laws which are not in conflict with federal or state law
or the home rule charter or ordinances of the city.



('68 Code, § 14-45) (Ord. 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed
12-21-98; Am. Ord. 2001-1919, passed 1-8-01)



§ 92.40  RULES, REGULATIONS AND POLICIES.



   The Fire Chief shall, subject to the approval of the City Manager,
adopt rules, regulations and policies for the Department not inconsistent
with this subchapter, the other provisions of this code, the Home Rule
Charter of the City, state law or any other ordinance of the city.



('68 Code, § 14-46) (Ord. 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed
12-21-98)



§ 92.41  TRAINING OF FIREFIGHTERS AND E.M.S. PERSONNEL.



   All firefighters and E.M.S. personnel shall, respectively, have the
responsibility of keeping all other firefighters and E.M.S. personnel trained
and informed on the subject of firefighting and E.M.S.



('68 Code, § 14-48)



(Ord. 1132, passed 8-1-66; Am. Ord. 1848, passed 12-21-98)



§ 92.42  VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTIONS; SPECIAL FUND.



   (A)   An opportunity shall be afforded to each customer of the
city’s water, sanitary sewer or solid waste services to make, when paying
the monthly utility bill, a voluntary monthly contribution to the city to
assist in financing the Department. The minimum requested amount of such
contribution shall be set by resolution adopted by the City Council from time
to time.



   (B)   All such contributions, as well as the revenue of the
Department from fees charged for services rendered as authorized by § 92.43
of this code, shall be deposited in a special revenue fund which may only be
used to make purchases for the Department.



   (C)   Anyone may make a voluntary contribution to an association
established as authorized by § 92.39(C) this code but such contribution
shall be paid directly to the treasurer of such association and shall not be
considered funds of the city or be subject to the control of the City
Council, the City Manager or the Fire Chief.



(Ord. 2001-1919, passed 1-8-01)



§ 92.43  FEES FOR SERVICES RENDERED; COLLECTION.



   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this section, fees shall be
charged for services rendered by the Department according to the fee schedule
to be adopted and which may be amended from time to time by resolution of the
City Council.



   (B)   No fee shall be charged for fire fighting services rendered on
behalf of the owner or occupant of any structure located within the corporate
limits of the city.



   (C)   No co-payment shall be required of any E.M.S. patient for whom
primary coverage is provided by an insurance policy, medicare, medicade or
other health plan and no payment shall be required of any E.M.S. patient for
whom primary coverage is not provided by an insurance policy, medicare,
medicade or other health plan if, in either case, such patient is:



      (1)   An occupant of any single-family conventional or duplex
dwelling or of any manufactured home separately connected to the water and
sanitary sewer systems of the city if the minimum requested contribution to
the Department is made each month when the city’s utility bill for such
single- family conventional or manufactured home or the portion such duplex
dwelling of which such patient is an occupant is paid; or,



      (2)   An occupant of a unit in a multi-family dwelling and
such unit is separately connected to the water and sanitary systems of the
city if the minimum requested contribution to the Department is made each
month when the city’s utility bill for such unit is paid; or



      (3)   An occupant of a unit in a multi-family dwelling which
unit is not separately connected to the water and sanitary sewer systems of
the city if the minimum requested contribution to the Department is made each
month for each of the occupied units in such multi-family dwelling when the
city’s utility bill for such dwelling is paid; or



      (4)   An occupant of any structure located in the
unincorporated environs of the city which is not connected to the water and
sanitary sewer systems of the city if such occupant or the owner of such
structure contributes each month to the Department in an amount equal to the
minimum contribution requested of the occupants of the single-family
structures which are connected to such systems but excluding any occupant of
a structure located in the extraterritorial jurisdiction of another
municipality with which the city has entered into a separate written
agreement to furnish emergency medical service to all of the residents of the
extraterritorial jurisdiction of such other municipality for an annual fee;
or,



      (5)   An occupant of any structure located within the
incorporated limits of any other municipality for whom such services are not
regularly provided by such other municipality or other entity located
therein  if such other municipality has entered into an agreement with the
Department whereby monthly contributions in an amount equivalent to the
minimum contribution requested of the occupants of single-family structures
which are connected to the water and sewer system of the city is made by such
other municipality on behalf of each of the residential structures located
therein but excluding any occupant of a structure located within the
corporate limits of another municipality with which the city has entered into
a separate written agreement to furnish emergency medical service to all of
the residents of such municipality for an annual fee; or



      (6)   Not within categories (1) through (5) above but is
determined by the Fire Chief according to written standards adopted by the
Fire Chief to be without sufficient funds to pay for such services.



   (D)   The City Council may by resolution authorize an agreement with
a third party to seek and collect, for a fee, compensation, reimbursement or
insurance coverage for the fees for services owed to the Department.



   (E)   All such fees, when collected, shall be deposited in the
special revenue fund established by § 92.42 of this code and may only be
used as provided therein.   



(Ord. 1850, passed 1-4-99; Am. Ord. 2001-1919, passed 1-8-01; Am. Ord.
2004-2066, passed 9-24-04)



INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE



§ 92.50  ADOPTION.



   (A)   The International Fire Code, 2015 Edition, published by the
International Code Council, together with the 2015 Fire Code Appendix, is
hereby adopted and incorporated and made a part of this chapter as fully as
if set forth at length herein. One copy of such International Code shall be
maintained at all times in the office of the City Secretary. Any person
violating such International Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on
conviction punished as provided in § 10.99 of this code.



   (B)   In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the
code adopted by this section and the provisions of this code of ordinances,
state law, or city ordinances, rules, or regulations, the provisions  of
this code, state law, or city ordinances, rules, or regulations shall prevail
and be controlling.



(‘68 Code, § 14-59) (Ord. 1333, passed 1-3-77; Am. Ord. 1733, passed
12-7-92; Am. Ord. 1776, passed 11-21-94; Am. Ord. 1884, passed 11-15-99; Am.
Ord. 2005-2098, passed 11-7-05; Am. Ord. 2012-2305, passed 4-16-12; Am. Ord.
2016-2124, passed 11-7- 16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.51  AMENDMENTS.



   (A)   Definitions.  For the purpose of the International Fire Code
adopted by § 92.50 of this code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



      CHIEF OF THE BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION.  The Fire Marshal.



      CONTAINER.  A vessel designed for the storage of flammable or
combustible liquids in small quantities.



      CORPORATION COUNSEL.  The City Attorney.



      DEALER.  A person, firm or corporation engaged in the business
of furnishing flammable or combustible liquids, or both, and the officers,
agents and employees of any such person, firm or corporation who deliver any
such liquids.



      FIRE LANE.  An area of the surface of a parking facility having
an unobstructed width of not less than twenty feet and located in front of
any business adjacent to and fronting on a parking facility.



      FIRE OFFICIAL.  The Fire Marshal.



      MARINE FUELING.  The fueling of a ship, boat or other
watercraft, whether floating or not floating.



      MARINE SERVICE STATION.  A facility located in the municipality
at which marine fuels and other marine related products are sold at retail to
the general public.



      MUNICIPALITY.  The City of Freeport.



      OCCUPIED PREMISES.  A platted lot on which there is located a
structure suitable for use, in whole or in part, for dwelling purposes.



      PARKING FACILITY.  Private property adjacent to and usable for
vehicular parking by the customers of any business the entrance to which
fronts on such parking facility.



      PARKING FACILITY OWNER.  The owner of a parking facility as well
as a lessee of such owner if such lessee is operating a business the entrance
to which fronts on a parking facility.



      RESIDENTIAL AREA.  Any designated block in any platted
subdivision, townsite or addition thereto if the majority of structures
located in such block are used, in whole or in part, for dwelling purposes,
regardless of the zoning classification of such block or structure.



      VACANT PREMISES.  A platted lot on which a structure suitable
for use, in whole or in part, for dwelling purposes is not located.



   (B)   Other amendments.  The International Fire Code adopted by §
92.50 of this code is hereby amended to add thereto a new Section 602.6.2.1,
which shall read as follows:



   The owner of any parking facility shall, if required in writing by the
fire official, have the curb or adjacent sidewalk, or both, of any portion of
such facility adjacent to any business the entrance to which fronts on such
parking facility painted red and legibly marked with the warning ‘FIRE LANE
- TOW AWAY ZONE’ in white letters at least three inches tall, at intervals
not exceeding fifty feet; and shall have such curbs or sidewalk, or both,
repainted and remarked whenever so directed by the Fire Official in writing.
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any vehicle in a
fire lane. It is an exception to the application of the preceding sentence if
such vehicle is an authorized emergency vehicle as defined in the
Transportation Code. All such writings shall be maintained by the fire
official as permanent records.



   (C)   The provisions of the International Fire Code adopted by §
92.50 to the contrary notwithstanding:



      (1)   Except as otherwise provided in this division of this
section, the location and installation of containers and other vessels shall
be in accordance with National Fire Prevention Association (NFPA) 30.



      (2)   Storage of flammable liquids in residential areas of the
municipality is limited to a closed container having a capacity of not more
than 15 gallons on any occupied premises.



      (3)   Storage of combustible liquids in residential areas of
the municipality is limited to a closed container having a capacity of not
more than 15 gallons on any occupied premises.



      (4)   Storage of flammable or combustible liquids is
prohibited on any vacant premises in a residential area.



      (5)   Marine fueling is prohibited except at a marine service
station. It is an affirmative defense to a violation of this prohibition if
the ship, boat or other watercraft being fueled is too large to be
accommodated at any marine service station in the municipality.



      (6)   The delivery by a dealer of flammable liquids or
combustible liquids, or both, to any container or other vessel located in a
residential area of the municipality is prohibited. In any prosecution for a
violation of this prohibition, proof that a structure is designed to be used
as a dwelling shall be prima facie evidence that such structure is being
used, in whole or in part, for dwelling purposes.



      (7)   The delivery by a dealer to any location in the
municipality outside of a residential area of flammable liquids to any
container or other vessel having a capacity exceeding 15 gallons or of
combustible liquids to any container or other vessel having a capacity
exceeding 15 gallons is prohibited unless a permit for such container or
vessel to be used for the storage of the liquid in question at the location
thereof has been issued by the Fire Marshal and such permit is in force and
effect at the time of such delivery.



      (8)   The delivery of flammable liquids or combustible liquids
to or from any vehicle located on a public highway, street or alley within
the municipality is prohibited.



      (9)   In any prosecution for a violation of the prohibitions
contained in divisions (2), (3), or (4) above, it shall be an affirmative
defense if the flammable or combustible liquid in question is contained in
the fuel tank of a motor vehicle, a watercraft or other motor-driven
equipment and:



         (a)   In the case of a vehicle, watercraft or other
motor-driven equipment which has been commercially manufactured, such fuel
tank is the fuel tank with which such vehicle, watercraft or other
motor-driven equipment is designed to be equipped by the manufacturer
thereof; or,



         (b)   In the case of a motor vehicle, watercraft or
other motor-driven equipment which has not been commercially manufactured,
such fuel tank is no larger than the fuel tank with which a commercially
manufactured motor vehicle, watercraft or other motor-driven equipment of
equivalent size is designed to be equipped by the manufacturer thereof.



('68 Code, § 14-60)  (Am. Ord. 1733, passed 12-7-92; Am. Ord. 1862, passed
6-21-99; Am. Ord. 1902, passed 6-5-00; Am. Ord. 1903, passed 6-19-00; Am.
Ord. 2005-2098, passed 11-7-05; Am. Ord. 2012-2305, passed 4-16-12) 
Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.52  ENFORCEMENT OF CODE; MODIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The International Fire Code shall be enforced by the Fire
Marshal. The Fire Marshal may appoint such inspectors as shall from time to
time be necessary to enforce the provisions of such code and the provisions
of this chapter.



('68 Code, § 14-61)



   (B)   The Fire Marshal shall have the power to modify any of the
provisions of the International Fire Code upon application in writing by the
owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical
difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code,
provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety
secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification
when granted or allowed and the decision of the Fire Marshal thereon shall be
entered upon the records of the Department and a signed copy shall be
furnished the applicant.



('68 Code, § 14-62)  (Am. Ord. 2005-2098, passed 11-7-05)



§ 92.53  APPEALS.



   Whenever the Fire Marshal shall disapprove an application or refuse to
grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the
code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been
misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the
decision of the Fire Marshal to the Mayor and City Council within 30 days
from the date of the decision appealed.



('68 Code, § 14-63)



§ 92.54  NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES, OR OCCUPANCIES REQUIRING PERMITS.



   The City Secretary, the Chief of Police and the Fire Marshal shall act
as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an
opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes, or occupancies which
shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in said code. The
Fire Marshal shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office, and
distribute copies thereof to interested persons.



('68 Code, § 14-64)



§ 92.55  INSURANCE REQUIRED ON INSTALLERS.



   Every fire sprinkler, vent hood, and fire alarm installer shall obtain
and maintain on file with the Fire Marshal at all times when working in the
city, certificates (in which the city is named as a certificate holder)
certifying that such installer has in force the following insurance issued by
an insurance company licensed to do business in the state:



   (A)   Worker's compensation insurance on each and every employee as
required and in accordance with the laws of the state.



   (B)   Public liability insurance to the extent of at least $50,000
for any one occurrence and $100,000 in the aggregate.



   (C)   Property damages insurance to the extent of $10,000 for any
one occurrence and $100,000 in the aggregate.



(Ord. 1737, passed 2-1-93)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.56  PERMIT FEES.



   The City Council shall adopt by resolution a schedule of fees to be
charged for the various permits issued by the Fire Marshal, such fees to be
paid to the Director of Finance of the city.



(Ord. 2005-2098, passed 11-7-05)



FIREWORKS



§ 92.65  APPLICABILITY; DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   This subchapter shall apply to fireworks, except as otherwise
provided in this subchapter.



   (B)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



      FIRE CHIEF.  Includes the Fire Marshal or his duly authorized
representatives.



      FIREWORKS.



         (a)   Any firecrackers, cannon crackers, skyrockets,
torpedoes, roman candles, sparklers, fire balloons, star shells, or any other
substance in whatever combination by any designated name intended for use in
obtaining visible or audible pyrotechnic display of any combustible or
explosive substance and such term shall include all articles or substances
within the commonly accepted meaning of fireworks, whether herein specially
designated and defined or not.



         (b)   The term FIREWORKS shall not include auto flares,
paper caps containing not in excess of an average 0.025 of a grain of
explosive content per cap manufactured in accordance with Interstate Commerce
regulations for packing and shipping, and toy cap pistols or devices to use
such caps.



      PERSON.  Means and includes any natural person, association of
persons, partnership, corporation, agent or officer of a corporation, and
shall also include all warehousemen, common and private carriers, bailees,
trustees, receivers, executors, and administrators.



   (C)   This subchapter shall be applicable and in force within the
area immediately adjacent and contiguous to the city and extending for a
distance outside the city for a total of 5,000 feet, and it shall be unlawful
to do or perform any act in violation of this subchapter within such area of
5,000 feet outside the city; provided, that this subchapter shall not apply
within any portion of such 5,000-foot area which is contained within the
territory of any other municipal corporation.



   (D)   Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed to prohibit any
resident wholesaler, dealer, or jobber to sell at wholesale such fireworks as
are not prohibited in this subchapter; the sale of any kind of fireworks,
provided that the same are to be shipped directly out of state, in accordance
with the Interstate Commerce Commission regulations covering the
transportation of explosives and other dangerous articles by motor, rail, and
water; or the use of fireworks (signal flares and torpedoes) by railroads or
other transportation entities or agencies or marine signal flares or rockets
in ships stores, or any political subdivision or its agencies for signal
purposes or illumination.



(Ord. 1669, passed 12-19-88)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.66  POSSESSION, MANUFACTURING, SALE, AND DISCHARGE.



   (A)   The manufacture of fireworks is prohibited within the city.



   (B)   Except as otherwise specifically provided in this subchapter,
it shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, assemble, store,
transport, receive, keep, sell at retail, offer to sell, or have in his
possession with intent to sell, give, use, discharge, cause to be discharged,
ignite, detonate, fire, or otherwise set in action any fireworks of any
description.



(Ord. 1669, passed 12-19-88)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.67  FIREWORKS DISPLAYS.



   It shall not be unlawful, upon a permit issued by the Fire Chief to any
person engaged in any fireworks display (subject to additional conditions
imposed by this subchapter), legitimate theatrical performance, circus, or
other shows designed for the amusement and edification of the general public
to use, discharge, or cause to be discharged and ignited fireworks as a part
of any show, act, or performance so long as such person does not also engage
in the retailing, wholesaling, selling, or distribution of any such
fireworks. The Fire Chief shall cause to be made an investigation of each
application made hereunder to determine whether the use of such fireworks as
proposed shall be of such a character that it may be hazardous to property or
dangerous to any person and he shall, in the exercise of reasonable
discretion, grant or deny the application for such permit. All applications
for permits shall be requested 72 hours before the proposed event.



(Ord. 1669, passed 12-19-88)



§ 92.68  ILLEGAL FIREWORKS; SEIZURE; INVESTIGATION.



   (A)   The presence of any fireworks within the jurisdiction of the
city in violation of this subchapter is hereby declared to be a common and
public nuisance. The Fire Chief is directed and required to seize and cause
to be safely destroyed any fireworks found in violation of this subchapter
and any member of the Fire Prevention division of the Fire Department or any
police officer of the city or any other duly constituted peace officer is
empowered to stop the transportation of and detain any fireworks found being
transported illegally or to close any building where any fireworks are found
stored illegally until the Fire Chief can be notified in order that such
fireworks may be seized and destroyed in accordance with the terms of this
section. Not withstanding any penal provision of this subchapter, the City
Attorney is authorized to file suit on behalf of the city or the Fire Chief
for such injunctive relief as may be necessary to prevent unlawful storage,
transportation, keeping, or use of fireworks within the jurisdiction of the
city and to aid the Fire Chief in the discharge of his duties and to
particularly prevent any person from interfering with the seizure and
destruction of such fireworks, but it shall  not be necessary to obtain any
such injunctive relief as a prerequisite to such seizure and destruction.



   (B)   The Fire Chief or any member of the Fire Prevention division
of the city is hereby authorized to enter any building where the unlawful
presence of fireworks is suspected in order to inspect the same for the
presence of such fireworks.



(Ord. 1669, passed 12-19-88)



§ 92.69  PUBLIC DISPLAYS.



   (A)   When permitted. The provisions of this subchapter shall not
apply to a public display of fireworks made under the terms and conditions of
this section and such a display shall be permitted, upon compliance with the
provisions of this section.



   (B)   Written application.  Any adult person or any firm,
copartnership, corporation, or association planning to make a public display
of fireworks shall first make written application for a permit to the Fire
Chief at least 30 days in advance of the date of the proposed display.
Provided, however, the City Council may authorize a lesser filing period by
approving an application filed within 30 days of such date.



   (C)   Investigation; issuance of permit. It shall be the duty of the
Fire Chief to make an investigation as to whether the display as proposed by
the applicant for a permit under this section shall be of such a character
that it may be hazardous to property or dangerous to any person and to report
his conclusions in writing to the City Council as soon as practicable. The
City Council shall consider the application at a meeting thereof to be held
as soon as practicable after receiving such report and shall by majority vote
of its members present and voting, in the exercise of reasonable discretion,
either grant or deny such application, subject to the conditions prescribed
in this section.  In the event such application is approved, the City
Council shall also specify by majority vote of its members present and
voting, the amount of insurance which the applicant shall be required to
obtain prior to the issuance of such permit, which  shall not be less than
that required by the applicable state statute or regulations of the State
Board of Insurance.  After proof of insurance in a form acceptable to the
City Attorney has been filed with the Fire Chief, he shall issue such permit
for a time to be specified therein; and such permit shall not be
transferrable.



   (D)   Insurance or bond required. In the event such application is
approved, the City Council shall also specify by majority vote of its members
present and voting the amount of insurance which the applicant shall be
required to obtain prior to the issuance of such permit, which shall not be
less than that required by the applicable state statute or regulations of the
State Board of Insurance. Such insurance shall include worker's compensation
for the applicant's employees and public liability insurance and shall be
issued by an insurance carrier licensed to do business in the state. Such
public liability insurance shall name the city as an additional insured.



   (E)   Aerial display permitted. Any fireworks display authorized
under this section shall be limited to an aerial display. The range of aerial
display shall not be more than 400 feet and the fireworks shall be discharged
vertically from steel tubes.



   (F)   Material not to be stored in city. The material to be used for
a public display authorized by this section shall not be stored within the
city limits, but shall be brought in on the day of the public display and
then shall be taken immediately to the place of display for further handling
and storage.



   (G)   Hazardous conditions prohibited.  No public display of
fireworks shall be of such a character and so located, discharged, or fired
as to be hazardous or dangerous to persons or property, and this
determination shall be within the sound discretion of the Fire Chief.



   (H)   Qualifications of persons handling fireworks. The persons
handling the display of fireworks under this section shall be competent,
adult persons, and experienced pyrotechnic operators approved by the Fire
Chief and possessing a valid and current license therefore issued by the
State Fire Marshal for Class B fireworks and no person not approved by the
Fire Chief shall handle fireworks at the public display. The names of the
experienced pyrotechnic operators shall be designated on the permit issued.



   (I)   Firefighters to be present. For each public display of
fireworks under this section, not less than two firefighters of the city
shall be in attendance during the display.



(Ord. 1669, passed 12-19-88; Am. Ord. 1766, passed 6-6-94)  Penalty, see §
10.99



EXPLOSIVES AND BLASTING AGENTS



§ 92.75  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BLASTING AGENT.  An agent used in blasting which is not subject to
detonation by heat, fire, penetration, shock, electric shock, explosion, or
friction generally possessing the characteristic of Nitramon.



   COMPONENT PARTS.  Any agency or agencies utilized in the detonation of
the blasting agent or explosive in the usual and customary manner.



   EXPLOSIVE.  Any agency of the nature of dynamite, nitrogel, TNT, or
any other agency of like nature and kind, with like characteristics.



('68 Code, § 14-76) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)



§ 92.76  MANNER OF HANDLING.



   All persons storing, transporting, using, keeping, maintaining, and/or
otherwise handling explosives or blasting agents with the city under a permit
to do so from the city shall at all times keep the explosive and blasting
agent, and the component parts utilized for detonation, separate and apart
from each other. Component parts utilized to cause detonation of explosives
or blasting agents shall at all times be kept in a container or containers
that are of sufficient nature as to prevent their detonation without the use
or intervention of some human agency.



('68 Code, § 14-77) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.77  LIABILITY OF HANDLERS.



   Should any person, keeping, maintaining, trans- porting, storing, or
using any explosive or blasting agent within the city have an explosion from
any such explosive or blasting agent or their component parts such person
shall be deemed to have been guilty of active negligence in failing to
exercise the care of an ordinary prudent person in the exercise of ordinary
care in the handling, storing, keeping, using, trans- porting, or detonation
of such explosive or blasting agent or their component parts, and shall be
liable for all damages to persons or property occasioned or proximately
caused by such detonation. The owner thereof shall not be excused from such
negligent act on account of any independent contractual relationship, the
duty hereinabove described being hereby declared to be nondelegable.



('68 Code, § 14-78) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.78  REPAIR OF TRANSPORTING MEDIA WHEN BY WATER.



   No person transporting any explosive or blasting agent or their
component parts by water shall permit the transportation media therefor to be
hauled from the water for repair without first having removed the blasting
agents, explosives, and/or component parts and safely storing same during
such repair work; nor shall repair work on such transportation media, where
there is any danger of explosion, be accomplished upon such transportation
media within the city without the explosive, blasting agent, and/or component
parts thereof being removed from such transportation media and storing the
same in a safe manner.



('68 Code, § 14-79) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.79  REVOCATION OF PERMITS.



   Any permit issued under the provisions of this subchapter may be
revoked by the city for the violation of any applicable provision of this
code, state law, or city ordinance, rule, or regulation by the permittee.



('68 Code, § 14-80)



§ 92.80  PERMIT TO HANDLE.



   (A)   Permit required.  All persons bringing explosives or blasting
agents, not including gasoline, butane, or other liquid petroleum products
into the city, or keeping, maintaining, storing, transporting from, or
otherwise handling within the city any explosives or blasting agents, shall
secure a permit to do so from the City Secretary. 



('68 Code, § 14-86)



   (B)   Application.  Before any permit required by the provisions of
this section shall be issued, the person desiring the same shall first make
application therefor with the City Secretary.  Such application shall as a
minimum, contain the following information:



      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;



      (2)   The type of explosive or blasting agent;



      (3)   Method of transportation, if any;



      (4)   Place to be stored, if any;



      (5)   Manner of transportation from the city;



      (6)   By whom such explosive or blasting agent is to be
transported;



      (7)   The maximum amount of explosives or blasting agents to
be kept within the city within any given 24-hour period of time; and



      (8)   The type of explosive or blasting agent involved or to
be involved. 



('68 Code, § 14-87)



   (C)   Grounds for denial.  In the event that the blasting agent or
explosive to be transported within  the city, or kept, maintained, or
transported from the city is of the nature that the same may be detonated by
fire, friction, shock, explosion, penetration, heat, or electrical shock
without being properly prepared for detonation, then in such event, the City
Secretary shall refuse to allow such explosive or blasting agent to be stored
within the city and shall deny a permit required by the provisions of this
subchapter.



('68 Code, § 14-88)



   (D)   Issuance.  Upon the compliance with all applicable provisions
of this code, state law, and city ordinances, rules, and regulations by the
applicant for a permit required by the provisions of this subchapter, the
City Secretary shall issue the same. 



('68 Code, § 14-89)



(Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.81  DETONATION PERMIT.



   (A)   Permit required.  No person transporting, using, storing, or
keeping any explosive or blasting agent within the city shall permit, cause
to be permitted, assemble, or cause to be assembled the component parts of
the explosive or blasting agent necessary to cause detonation thereof within
the city or within 3,000 feet of the incorporated city limits, without first
having secured a permit to do so from the City Secretary. 



('68 Code, § 14-95) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)



   (B)   Application.  Any person desiring a permit required by the
provisions of this section shall first make application therefor, which
application in the minimum, must contain the following:



      (1)   The name, address and business of the applicant;



      (2)   The area, if any, where detonation is to be accomplished;



      (3)   The total amount of explosive or blasting agent to be in
the area where such assembly is to be made;



      (4)   The type of explosive or blasting agent;



      (5)   The experience of the person to assemble same; and



      (6)   An outline of safety precautions to be employed.



('68 Code, § 14-96) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)



   (C)   Limitation on issuance.



      (1)   No permit shall be issued under the provisions of this
section whenever such total amount of explosive or blasting agent to be in
the area where assembly is to be made exceeds ½ ton, nor shall a permit be
issued whenever the proposed detonation is within 510 feet of any residence
or business establishment unless the written consent of all such residents or
business establishments is first had and obtained that are situated within
such distance.



      (2)   No permit shall be issued for the assembly or detonation
of any explosive or blasting agent within the Old Brazos River Channel within
the city.



('68 Code, § 14-97) (Ord. 1116, passed 5-3-65)



   (D)   Issuance.  Upon the compliance with all applicable provisions
of this code, state law, and city ordinances, rules, and regulations by the
applicant for a permit required by the provisions of this subchapter, the
City Secretary shall issue the same. 



('68 Code, § 14-98)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 93:  NOISE REGULATIONS



Section




General Provisions




   93.01   Unreasonable noise prohibited



   93.02   Enumeration of specific noises




Sound Amplifying Equipment




   93.20   Prohibited use of loudspeakers and amplifiers



   93.21   Affirmative defenses



   93.22   Permit required



   93.23   Application; fee



   93.24   Consideration of application; issuance



   93.25   Vehicular electronic sound generating devices



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 93.01  UNREASONABLE NOISE PROHIBITED.



   (A)   The creation at any place in the city of any noise specified
in any division of § 93.02 of this chapter under the circumstances specified
in such division, which is unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary is
hereby declared to be a public nuisance and prohibited.



   (B)   In any prosecution in the municipal court of the city or any
other court of competent jurisdiction for a violation of division (A) above,
proof of the creation of any noise specified in any division of § 93.02
under the circumstances specified in such division shall be prima facie
evidence that such noise is unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary.



(‘68 Code, § 20-1) (Am. Ord. 1816, passed 6-16-97)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 93.02  ENUMERATION OF SPECIFIC NOISES.



   The following noises are hereby declared to be unreasonably loud,
disturbing, and unnecessary noises:



   (A)   The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile,
motorcycle, bus, streetcar, or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a
danger signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control, or
if in motion only as a danger signal after or as brakes are being applied and
deceleration of the vehicle is intended; the creation by means of any such
signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of
such device for any unnecessary and unreasonable period of time.



   (B)   The use of a stationary loudspeaker or amplifier at any time
between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on one day and 7:00 a.m. on the next
succeeding day or on Sunday between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m.



   (C)   The use of any automobile, motorcycle, streetcar, or vehicle
so out of repair, so loaded, or operated in such manner as to create loud or
unnecessary noises such as spinning or squealing tires, grating, grinding,
rattling or other noise.



   (D)   The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary
boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a
warning of danger.



   (E)   The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam
engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle, or boat engine,
except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud
or explosive noises therefrom.



   (F)   The use of any mechanical device operated by compressed air,
except pneumatic drills, unless the noise thereby created is effectively
muffled and reduced.



   (G)   The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration,
or repair of any building in a residential or business district other than
between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays, except in case of
urgent necessity in the interest of public safety, and then only with a
permit from the City Council, which permit may be renewed for a period of
three days or less while the emergency continues.



   (H)   The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to
any school, institution of learning, or court while the same are in session,
or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the working
of such institution, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets
indicating that the same is a school, hospital, or court street.



   (I)   The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with
the loading or unloading of any vehicle or the opening and destruction of
bales, boxes, crates, and containers.



   (J)   The sounding of any bell or gong attached to any building or
premises which is reasonably calculated to disturb a person of ordinary
disposition if such person were in the vicinity thereof.



   (K)   The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers, and vendors
which disturbs the quiet and peace of the neighborhood.



   (L)   The use of any drum, loudspeaker, or other instrument or
device for the purpose of attracting attention by creator of noise to any
performance, show, or sale of merchandise.



   (M)   The playing of any musical instrument, radio, phonograph, CD
player, audio tape player or other electronic sound-generating device in any
public place or on any private premises in such manner, or with such volume,
as to create a noise which is disturbing to a person of ordinary
sensibilities under the same or similar circumstances who is either located
in a public place or at a private premises or habitation to which such noise
has carried.



(‘68 Code, § 20-2) (Am. Ord. 1816, passed 6-16-97)  Penalty, see § 10.99



SOUND AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT



§ 93.20  PROHIBITED USE OF LOUDSPEAKERS AND AMPLIFIERS.



   (A)   A person commits an offense if he operates or causes to be
operated any mechanical loudspeaker or sound amplifier in a public place or
upon any public sidewalk, street, alley or highway in the city if such
operation:



      (1)   Occurs between sundown of one day and 8:00 o’clock,
a.m., of the succeeding day within 150 feet of the property line of any
premises on which a single-family, duplex or multi-family dwelling is
located; or,



      (2)   Causes loud and raucous noises to be emitted which
interfere with the enjoyment of life or property or with the public peace and
comfort; or,



      (3)   Causes traffic congestion or the congregation of crows
that obstruct any public sidewalk, street, alley or highway; or,



      (4)   Occurs within 150 feet of any hospital, nursing home or
licensed adult personal care facility or any school or children’s day care
that is in session.



   (B)   If conduct that would otherwise violate this section consists
of speech or other communication, of gathering with others to hear or observe
such speech or communication, or of gathering with others to picket or
otherwise express in a nonviolent manner a position on social, economic,
political or religious questions, the person must be ordered to move,
disperse or otherwise remedy the violation prior to arrest or citation. Such
order may be given by a peace office, a fireman, a person with authority to
control the use of any affected premises or any person directly affected by
the violation.



(‘68 Code, § 20-13) (Ord. 1097, passed 1-6-64; Am. Ord. passed  - -96;
Am. Ord. 1802, passed 8-5-96)



§ 93.21  AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES.



   It is an affirmative defense to any violation of § 93.20 if:



   (A)   The circumstances require that an order to move, disperse or
otherwise remedy the violation be given and:



      (1)   No order was in fact given; or



      (2)   The order given was manifestly unreasonable in scope; or,



      (3)   The order given was promptly obeyed; or



   (B)   The mechanical loudspeaker or sound amplifier was being
operated:



      (1)   In a public place within an enclosed structure and was
not audible beyond the property line of the premises on which it was
operated; or



      (2)   By a law enforcement officer or member of the fire
department in the performance of official duties;



      (3)   For the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of
an emergency or danger; or



      (4)   In the performance of emergency work necessary to
restore public utilities, to restore property to a safe condition, or to
protect persons or property from imminent danger following a fire, accident
or natural disaster.



(‘68 Code, § 20-14) (Ord. 1097, passed 1-6-64; Am. Ord. passed  - -96;
Am. Ord. 1802, passed 8-5-96)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 93.22  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to use any sound amplifying
equipment within the city without having first obtained therefor a permit.



(‘68 Code, § 20-20)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 93.23  APPLICATION; FEE.



   (A)   Any person desiring a permit required by the provisions of
§§ 93.22 through 93.24 of this chapter shall make application to the City
Secretary on a form prepared for such purpose. Such application shall show
the date, place, time, and location where such equipment is to be used;
together with the name of the applicant and type of equipment to be used.



(‘68 Code, § 20-21)



   (B)   Every application for a permit required by the provisions of
§§ 93.22 through 93.27 of this chapter shall be filed with the City
Secretary at least 14 days prior to the date of the intended use of the sound
amplifying equipment.



(‘68 Code, § 20-22)



   (C)   Each application for a permit required by the provisions of
§§ 93.22 through 93.27 of this chapter shall be accompanied by an
application fee of $3.  Such fee shall be deposited to the general fund of
the city, and shall not be refunded if the permit is denied to the applicant.



(‘68 Code, § 20-23)



(Ord. 1097, passed 1-6-64)



§ 93.24  CONSIDERATION OF APPLICATION; ISSUANCE.



   The City Secretary shall either grant or deny the sound amplifying
equipment permit on or before ten days from the date the application therefor
is received.



(‘68 Code, § 20-24) (Ord. 1097, passed 1-6-64)



§ 93.25  VEHICULAR ELECTRONIC SOUND GENERATING DEVICES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, in either a public or
private place within the city, to operate an electronic sound generating
device from a vehicle in a manner so that the sound generated by such device
causes vibrations in any object or person which are noticed by a person
outside of the vehicle.



   (B)   In any prosecution under division (A) of this section, it is
an affirmative defense if:



      (1)   The sound generated by the electronic sound generating
device is human speech being broadcast from a vehicle by a loudspeaker as it
is being uttered by a person using a microphone, and the person using the
microphone to broadcast from a vehicle had not been warned earlier by a
police officer or an employee of the city that such broadcasting from a
vehicle within the city is a violation of this code and that charges will be
filed if the person continues to broadcast without obtaining a permit to use
sound amplifying equipment within the city in accordance with the applicable
provisions of § 93.22 of this chapter; or



      (2)   The electronic sound generating device contains sound
amplifying equipment, and a permit for the use of such sound amplifying
equipment has been obtained in accordance with § 93.22 of this chapter, and
is still in effect; or



      (3)   The electronic sound generating device is a horn being
used in the manner required by the TEXAS TRANS. CODE; or,



      (4)   The vehicle is an authorized emergency vehicle as
defined in the TEXAS TRANS. CODE; or



      (5)   The vehicle is in a parade which is included under one
of the categories for an affirmative defense listed in § 71.05; or



      (6)   The vehicle is being used for advertising and has
received a permit for such use under § 71.03.



   (C)   A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of
an offense under this section.



(Ord. 2006-2124, passed 6-5-06)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 94:  JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLES



Section



   94.01   Definitions



   94.02   Junked vehicles as public nuisance; exceptions



   94.03   Notice to abate nuisance; hearing



   94.04   Removal with permission of owner or occupant



   94.05   Disposal of junked vehicles



   94.06   Authority to enforce; application of chapter



   94.07   Unlawful to maintain or relocate nuisance after notice;
affirmative defense



   94.08   Relocation of junked vehicles does not affect abatement
proceeding; exception



§ 94.01  DEFINITIONS.



   All terms used in this chapter, unless specifically defined otherwise,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them by the Texas Transportation Code.
The following terms are specifically defined.



   ANTIQUE VEHICLE. A passenger car,  truck,  or motorcycle that:



      (1)   Is at least 25 years old;



      (2)   Is a collector's item;



      (3)   Is used exclusively for exhibitions,  club activities,
parades, and other functions of public interest;



      (4)   Is not used for regular transportation; and



      (5)   Does not carry advertising.



   CLASSIC VEHICLE. A motor vehicle that is at least 25 years old and that
has not been changed from the original manufacturer's specifications.



   COLLECTOR. A person who:



      (1)   Owns one or more antique or special interest vehicles:
and



      (2)   Acquires, collects or disposes of an antique or special
interest vehicle or part of an antique or special interest vehicle for
personal use to restore and preserve an antique or special interest vehicle
for historic interest.



   CUSTOM VEHICLE. A vehicle:



      (1)   That is:



         (a)   At least 25 years old and of a model year after
1948; or



         (b)   Manufactured to resemble a vehicle that is at
least 25 years old and of a model year after 1948; and



      (2)   That:



         (a)   Has been altered from the manufacturer's original
design; or



         (b)   Has a body constructed from materials not original
to the vehicle.



   DEMOLISHER.  Any person whose business is to convert a motor vehicle
into processed scrap or  scrap metal, or otherwise to wreck or dismantle
motor vehicles.



   ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY. Any peace officer or code enforcement officer
employed by the City of Freeport.



   JUNKED VEHICLE.



      (1)   A vehicle as defined in Item (9) of § 621.001 of the
Transportation Code that:



         (a)   Is self-propelled; and



         (b)   Is:



            1.   Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled,
or discarded; or



            2.    Inoperable and has remained inoperable for
more than:



               a.   72 consecutive hours,  if the vehicle
is on public property; or



               b.   30 consecutive days,  if the vehicle
is on private property.



      (2)   For purposes of this subchapter, JUNKED VEHICLE includes
a motor vehicle, aircraft, or watercraft.  This subchapter applies only to:



         (a)   A motor vehicle that displays an expired license
plate or does not display a license plate;



         (b)   An aircraft that does not have lawfully printed on
the aircraft an unexpired federal aircraft identification number registered
under Federal Aviation Administration aircraft registration regulations in 14
C.F.R. Part 47; or



         (c)   A watercraft that:



            1.   Does not have lawfully on board an unexpired
certificate of number; and



            2.   Is not a watercraft described by § 31.055,
Parks and Wildlife Code.



   PERSON.  Any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, or organization of any kind.



   SPECIAL INTEREST VEHICLE. A motor vehicle of any age that has not been
changed from original manufacturer’s specifications and, because of its
historic interest, is being preserved by a hobbyist.



(‘68 Code, § 17½-1) (Ord. 1235, passed 3-6-72: Am. Ord. 1362, passed
9-6-77; Am. Ord. 1811, passed 4-21-97; Am. Ord. 1874, passed 9-27-99; Am.
Ord. 2001-1940, passed 9-4-01; Am. Ord. 2005-2087, passed 7-12-05; Am. Ord.
2016-2127, passed 11-7-16)



§ 94.02  JUNKED VEHICLES AS PUBLIC NUISANCE; EXCEPTIONS.



   Junked vehicles which are located in any place where they are visible
from a public place or public right-of-way are detrimental to the safety and
welfare of the general public, tending to reduce the value of private
property, to invite vandalism, to create fire hazards, to constitute an
attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors, and
are detrimental to the  economic welfare of the state, by producing urban
blight which is adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of the
city, and such vehicles are, therefore, declared to be a public nuisance,
provided that this section shall not apply to:



   (A)   A vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within
a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or
other public or private property;



   (B)   A vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in a
lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a
licensed vehicle dealer or a junkyard; or



   (C)   An antique or special interest vehicle stored by a motor
vehicle collector on the collector’s property if the vehicle or part and
the outdoor storage area, if any, are:



      (1)   Maintained in an orderly manner;



      (2)   Not a health hazard; and



      (3)   Screened from ordinary public view by appropriate means,
including a fence, rapidly growing trees or shrubbery.



   (D)   It is unlawful for a person to maintain, possess, or locate a
public nuisance described in this section within the City of Freeport.
Provided, however, a person authorized to enforce this chapter may enter
private property to examine the junked vehicle or parts of a junked vehicle,
to obtain information to identify the junked vehicle or parts of a junked
vehicle, to remove or direct the removal of the junked vehicle or parts of a
junked vehicle authorized any person to remove a junked vehicle or parts of a
junked vehicles from any premises.



(‘68 Code, § 17½-2) (Ord. 1235, passed 3-6-72: Am. Ord. 1362, passed
9-6-77; Am. Ord. 1811, passed 4-21-97; Am. Ord. 2016- 2127, passed 11-7-16)



§ 94.03  NOTICE TO ABATE NUISANCE; HEARING.



   (A)   The Code Enforcement Officer shall give  not less than ten
days’ written notice to the last known registered owner of the junked
vehicle, any lienholder of record and the owner or occupant of the private
premises, public property or premises adjacent to the public right-of-way in
question, as the case may be, stating the nature of the public nuisance, that
it must be removed and abated not later than the tenth day after the date on
which the notice was personally delivered or mailed, and the date, time and
place of the public hearing required by division (B) of this section and the
continuance of such hearing to a date certain if such notice is returned
undelivered by the post office. If the post office address of the last known
registered owner of the junk vehicle is unknown, such notice may be posted on
such vehicle, or, if the owner is located, hand delivered. If such notice is
returned by the post office as undelivered, action to abate the nuisance
shall be continued to a date, not earlier than the eleventh day after the
date of such return, and the conducting of such public hearing to the first
day after such eleventh day on which the office of the City Manager, or his
designee, is open for business.



   (B)   A request for a hearing must be made not later than the tenth
day after the notice was personally delivered, mailed, or placed on the
public nuisance. The City Manager or his designee shall conduct the public
hearing if timely requested by a person described in division (A) of this
section who received a notice required by division (A) of this section.  The
hearing shall be held not earlier than the eleventh day after the service of
notice required by this division. At the hearing, the junked vehicle is
presumed to be inoperable, unless demonstrated otherwise. The order requiring
the removal of the public nuisance must contain a description, license plate
number, and identification number of the public nuisance, if available.



   (C)   Not earlier than the eleventh day after a certified copy of an
order of the City Manager, or his designee, made at the conclusion of the
public hearing, conducted pursuant to division (B) of this section and
requiring the removal of a junked vehicle or part thereof, has been delivered
to those entitled to notice under and in the manner specified in division (A)
of this section, if the nuisance described in such notice and order has not
been abated, the code enforcement officer may, at the direction of the City
Manger, or such designee, stated in such order,remove or cause the junked
vehicle creating the nuisance to be removed to a suitable storage area
designated by the City Manger, or such designee, as provided in § 94.05.



   (D)   It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any premises
on which there is located a junked vehicle or part thereof, with respect to
which an order for removal as a public nuisance has been made by the City
Manager, or his designee, pursuant to division (B) of this section, to remove
such junked vehicle or part thereof from such premises within ten days after
the delivery of a certified copy of such order as provided in division (C) of
this section, after which any person may file a complaint in municipal court
for the violation of maintaining a public nuisance on such premises by
allowing such junked vehicle or part thereof to remain on such premises.



   (E)   It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under
division (D) of this section if a decision favorable to the owner or occupant
in question has been rendered at the public hearing conducted pursuant to
division (B) of this section.



(‘68 Code, § 17½-3) (Ord. 1235, passed 3-6-72; Am. Ord. 1811, passed
4-21-97; Am. Ord. 2006-2131, passed 8-21-06; Am. Ord. 2016-2127, passed
11-7-16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.04  REMOVAL WITH PERMISSION OF OWNER OR OCCUPANT.



   If, within ten days after receipt of notice from the Code Enforcement
Officer, or his duly authorized agent, to abate the nuisance, as herein
provided, the owner or occupant of the premises shall give his written
permission to the Code Enforcement Officer, or his duly authorized agent, for
removal of the junked motor vehicle from the premises, the giving of such
permission shall be reconsidered compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.



(‘68 Code, § 17½-4) (Ord. 1235, passed 3-6-72)



§ 94.05  DISPOSAL OF JUNKED VEHICLES.



   (A)   Not earlier than the eleventh day after a certified copy of
any order of the City Manager, or his designee, made at the conclusion of the
publichearing required by § 94.03(B) has been delivered to those persons or
entities entitled to notice under § 94.03(A), if the nuisance described in
such order has not been abated, the Code Enforcement Officer, at the
direction of the City Manager, or his designee, expressed in such order,
shall remove or cause the junked vehicle, or part thereof, creating the
nuisance to be removed to a suitable storage area designated in such order by
the City Manager, or his designee.



   (B)   A junked vehicle, or part thereof, removed to a storage area
as required by division (A) of this section shall be stored in such storage
area for a period of not less than ten days during which period any party
owning or claiming any right, title or interest in such junked vehicle, or
part thereof, shall be entitled to claim possession of such junked vehicle,
or part thereof, by the payment to the city of the actual cost of the city
abating such nuisance. The Code Enforcement Officer may in such cases, if he
deems it necessary, require such person to post a bond of not more than $50
nor less than $25, conditioned that such person will not use such junked
vehicle, or part thereof, to create another nuisance in the city.



   (C)   After a junked vehicle has been removed to a storage area as
provided in this section, it shall not be reconstructed or made operable by
any person.



   (D)   Notice shall be given to the state Department of Highways and
Public Transportation within five days after the date of removal identifying
the vehicle, or part thereof, which was removed and stored.



(‘68 Code, § 17½-5) (Ord. 1235, passed 3-6-72; Am. Ord. 2006-2131, passed
8-21-06)



§ 94.06  AUTHORITY TO ENFORCE; APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.



   (A)   Any peace officer or Code Enforcement Officer or his agent,
may enter upon private property for the purposes specified in this chapter to
examine vehicles or parts thereof, obtain information as to the identity of
vehicles and to remove or cause to be removal of a vehicle or parts of
thereof declared to be a nuisance pursuant to this chapter. The municipal
court of the city shall have authority to issue all orders necessary to
enforce such chapter. (‘68 Code, § 17½-6)



   (B)   Nothing in this chapter shall affect ordinances that permit
immediate removal of a vehicle left on public property which constitutes an
obstruction to traffic.  (‘68 Code, § 17½-7)



(Ord. 1235, passed 3-6-72; Am. Ord. 2016-2127, passed 11-7-16)



§ 94.07  UNLAWFUL TO MAINTAIN OR RELOCATE NUISANCE AFTER NOTICE;
AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE.



   (A)   No person shall leave or permit any junked vehicle that is a
public nuisance to remain upon any public or private premises within the city
for more than ten days, after such person has been notified in writing by the
Code Enforcement Officer to remove the same, or for such person to relocate
such junked vehicle to another location within the city if such junked
vehicle constitutes a public nuisance at the new location.



   (B)   It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under
Division (A) of this section if the owner or occupant of such premises has
appealed such notice as provided in § 94.03 and such appeal has not been
heard or, if such appeal has been heard, a decision favorable to such owner
or occupant has been rendered.



(Ord. 1874, passed 9-27-99)



§ 94.08  RELOCATION OF JUNKED VEHICLES DOES NOT AFFECT ABATEMENT
PROCEEDING; EXCEPTION.



   The relocation of a junked vehicle that is a public nuisance to another
location in the city afer a proceeding for the abatement and removal of such
public nuisance pursuant to the provisions of this chapter has commenced has
no effect on such proceeding if the junked vehicle constitutes a public
nuisance at the new location.



(Ord. 1874, passed 9-27-99)



CHAPTER 95:  BOATS AND WATERWAYS



Section




General Provisions




   95.01   Definitions



   95.02   Speed limit



   95.03   Unlawful to operate vessel while intoxicated



   95.04   Discharge of garbage or refuse



   95.05   Docks, etc., in artificial waterways



   95.06   Fuel stored on vessels; affirmative defense



   95.07   Bulkheads abutting artificial waterways; construction and
maintenance; exceptions




Docking Concession Franchise Permit




   95.20   Definitions



   95.21   Grant of authority



   95.22   Indemnification



   95.23   Grantee rules



   95.24   Conditions of use



   95.25   Records of reports



   95.26   Termination and default



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 95.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BULKHEAD. A structure built along the bank of real property abutting a
waterway for the purpose of resisting pressure, preventing erosion or acting
as a restraining wall.



   GARBAGE or REFUSE.  Waste products, trash, or rubbish, including, by
way of illustration and not limitation, the discharge from such vessel of any
waste materials, oil, or other matter which tends to pollute the waterways
within the city.



   MARINE SERVICE STATION.  A facility at which marine fuels and other
marine related products are sold at retail to the general public.



   MEMBER OF A CREW.  Any person having duties to perform aboard a vessel
other than as a passenger thereupon.



   NAVIGABLE ARTIFICIAL WATERWAY.  Any waterway that has an average width
of thirty feet from the mouth up, other than a natural waterway, without
regard to the length of such waterway.



   SUBDIVISION.  A tract or parcel of land which has been divided into
two or more lots or parts for the purpose, whether immediate or in the
future, of building development.



   VESSEL.  Any boat, ship, barge, or craft which floats upon water
whether self-propelled or not.



(‘68 Code, § 9-1) (Ord. 1142, passed 9-11-67; Am. Ord. 1885, passed
2-7-00; Am. Ord. 2004-2036, passed 1-20-04)



§ 95.02  SPEED LIMIT.



   It shall be, and it is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person,
firm, or corporation to operate or cause to be operated, permit, or cause to
be permitted, any boat, ship, or vessel upon the water of the Old Brazos
River from the Missouri Pacific Railroad Bridge easterly within the
incorporated city limits, at a rate of speed greater than five miles per
hour, or at any speed which creates a wake that may cause damage to moorings
of vessels or floating structures.



(‘68 Code, § 9-2(a)) (Ord. 1142, passed 9-11-67; Am. Ord. 1222, passed
10-18-71; Am. Ord. 1392, passed 6-5-78)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 95.03  UNLAWFUL TO OPERATE VESSEL WHILE INTOXICATED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, move, or permit to be
operated or moved, any vessel upon the waterways situated within the city
while any member of the crew thereof is under the influence of any
intoxicating beverage, or any drug, whether narcotic or otherwise.



(‘68 Code, § 9-3) (Ord. 1142, passed 9-11-67)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 95.04  DISCHARGE OF GARBAGE OR REFUSE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or permit to be
discharged from any vessel into the waterways within the city any garbage or
refuse.



(‘68 Code, § 9-4) (Ord. 1142, passed 9-11-67) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 95.05  DOCKS, ETC., IN ARTIFICIAL WATERWAYS.



   (A)   No person shall construct or place in any navigable artificial
waterway in the city any dock or other structure, whether floating or on
pilings.



   (B)   It is an exception to the application of division (A) above if
such navigable artificial waterway is:



      (1)   Connected to another navigable artificial waterway; and,



      (2)   Located entirely within the boundaries of a single lot
depicted on the map or plat of a subdivision on file in the office of the
County Clerk of the county which is, according to such plat, adjacent to
another platted lot located in the same subdivision and owned by the same
person.



   (C)   It is an exception to the application of division (A) of this
section if the dock or structure is:



      (1)   Constructed or placed in a navigable artificial waterway
which is connected to the Old Brazos River, as defined in § 95.20 of this
chapter, at a point located downstream from the Velasco Drainage District
tide gate;



      (2)   Any vessel moored therein is not being used as a
dwelling in violation of Chapter 155 of this code;



      (3)   Any vessel moored therein is being moored for ten days
or less; or



      (4)   The City Council, upon written application therefor
filed with the City Secretary, giving the name and address of the applicant,
the name of the owner if different from the applicant, the description and
the official number of the vessel, the purpose for which such vessel is being
so moored, the arrangements that are being made for off-street parking,
security and water, sewer and other utility services for such vessel at such
location, and a description of the insurance coverage which the applicant or
owner will provide and maintain, has granted permission for such vessel to be
moored for a specified time in excess of ten days, taking into consideration
the necessity for such vessel to be so moored, the adequacy of off-street
parking, security and water, sewer and other utility services for such vessel
at such location, whether or not the owner has adequate insurance coverage to
protect the interests all persons and entities involved, the fee which should
be charged for the granting of such permission and other factors deemed
relevant by the City Council. Provided, however, no permit shall be issued by
the City Secretary until the fee designated by the City Council has been paid
by the applicant.  Provided further, after notice to the owner and hearing,
