the City Council may revoke such permit upon a finding that, during the
period for which such permission is granted, such vessel ceased to be moored
at such location or that the off-street parking, the security, the water,
sewer or other utility services for such vessel at such location or the
insurance coverage for the protection of the interests of all persons and
entities involved has ceased to be adequate.



(Ord. 1815, passed 6-16-97; Am. Ord. 2001-1943, passed 9-4-01)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 95.06  FUEL STORED ON VESSELS; AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE.



   (A)   No flammable liquids and no combustible liquids used or to be
used for fueling any vessel shall be stored on such vessel in containers
larger than 15 gallons while such vessel is docked in any navigable
artificial waterway adjacent to any premises within a subdivision located
adjacent to such navigable artificial waterway other than a marine service
station.



   (B)   It is an affirmative defense to a violation of division (A) of
this section if:



      (1)   All fuel which is stored on such vessel is stored in the
fuel tank of such vessel; and,



      (2)   Such fuel tank is no larger than the fuel tank with
which a commercially manufactured vessel of equivalent size is designed to be
equipped by the manufacturer of such vessel.



(Ord. 1885, passed 2-7-00; Am. Ord. 1904, passed 6-19-00)



§ 95.07  BULKHEADS ABUTTING ARTIFICIAL WATERWAYS; CONSTRUCTION AND
MAINTENANCE; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any real
property abutting on a navigable artificial waterway in the city, not having
a bulkhead, to fail to construct thereon a bulkhead adequate to prevent soil
from eroding into such waterway after receiving written notice to do so from
the Building Official.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any real
property abutting on a navigable artificial waterway in the city, having a
bulkhead, to fail to maintain such bulkhead in a manner that:



      (1)   Prevents soil from such real property eroding into such
waterway;



      (2)   Does not block the flow from a storm sewer or cause a
storm sewer to be blocked, either partially or completely by a buildup of
silt or debris; and



      (3)   Denies access to water which may accumulate behind such
bulkhead.



   (C)   Division (B) shall apply to bulkheads existing on the date the
ordinance adopting this section is adopted and to any bulkheads thereafter
constructed.



   (D)   In any prosecution for a violation of division (B)(3), it
shall be an affirmative defense if filling behind a bulkhead abutting the
real property in question has been forbidden by any state or federal agency.



   (E)   It is an exception to the application of this section if the
navigable artificial waterway in question is (1) the Gulf Intracoastal
Waterway or (2) intersects the Brazos River or the Brazos River Diversion
Channel or (3) surrounded by vacant land in a single ownership until any of
such land is developed.



(Ord. 2004-2036, passed 1-20-04)



DOCKING CONCESSION FRANCHISE PERMIT



§ 95.20  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   GRANTEE.  A current United States Coast Guard documented vessel owned
by a person, firm, or corporation which has a license and permit to do
business in the State of Texas.



   OLD BRAZOS RIVER.  The waterway so designated, extending from “the
Plug” upon which runs State Highway 288 separating the Brazos River
Diversion Channel from the watercourse of the Old Brazos River and which
meanders from said end of the river (the Plug) to the Intercoastal Waterway
to the Freeport Harbor Channel and thence on to the Gulf of Mexico, as
designated by government authority.



   RULES AND REGULATIONS.  All lawfully enacted orders, regulations,
rules, and laws of the city, the county, the state, the United States of
America and/or any lawfully constituted department, division, or section
thereof who has jurisdiction or authority over or analogous to any phase of
operation of this concession franchise, such as, but not limited to, the
United States Coast Guard.



(‘68 Code, § 9-5) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



§ 95.21  GRANT OF AUTHORITY. 



   The city, upon application and payment of a $500 per vessel per
calendar year franchise permit fee, shall grant the grantee, the right and
privilege to operate a sight-seeing vessel from a point of land in the
municipal park adjacent to the northeastern bank and end of the Old Brazos
River and northwest of the public dock thereon for purposes of recreation.



   (A)   This grant is nonexclusive and the grantee may only load and
unload passengers and tourists on this city property at times and under
conditions designated below.



   (B)   The grantee fully understands and agrees that the city does
not warrant the land as a quay, wall, or wharves to be safe for berthing or
mooring vessels, or for accepting and discharging passengers, and assumes no
responsibility as a wharfinger.



   (C)   This concession franchise grants or vests no right, title, or
claim for or to the land described and designated in the permit, being that
portion at the northeast bank at the end of the Old Brazos River between the
shell dock boating area at the Freeport Municipal Park and the city light
pole, north of three concrete pavilions on said land. Additionally, this land
and riverbank shall be designated on the ground by the city for this purpose.



   (D)   This franchise may be modified or suspended for special events
by the City Council.



   (E)   The grantee shall be solely responsible to maintain and
restore the boarding area or bank of the river.



(‘68 Code, § 9-6) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



§ 95.22  INDEMNIFICATION. 



   (A)   The grantee shall hold the city, its officers, boards,
employees, agents, and servants harmless from any liability, loss, claim,
expense, or demand, including personal injury, death, or property damage,
arising out of the grantee’s maintenance or operation of its recreational
sight-seeing tours under this franchise.



   (B)   The grantee agrees to keep in force a policy of insurance
approved by the City Council, covering liability and property damages while
afloat or docked with the minimum amount of liability thereunder as follows:
Not less than $1,000,000. The city shall be named the insured, and the policy
shall remain in effect during the term of this franchise.



   (C)   The grantee shall keep in effect all other forms of insurance
required by the state or federal government for its operation of this
franchise during the franchise term.



(‘68 Code, § 9-7) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



§ 95.23  GRANTEE RULES.



   The grantee shall have the authority to promulgate such rules,
regulations, terms, and conditions governing the conduct of its business as
shall be reasonably necessary to enable the grantee to exercise its rights
and to perform its obligation under this contract and to assure an
uninterrupted service to its customers and designated passenger pickup areas;
provided, however, that such rules, regulations, terms, and conditions shall
not conflict with provisions hereof or any local, state, or federal law or
procedure now or hereafter enacted.



(‘68 Code, § 9-8) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



§ 95.24  CONDITIONS OF USE.



   (A)   Use.  All structures, equipment, or improvements installed or
erected by the grantee within the city shall be installed and located, so as
to cause a minimum of interference with the proper use of public ways and
waters and with reasonable and safe convenience to citizens, boaters, and the
public who enjoy the recreational benefits of said public area and waterways.
The grantee shall provide service at all times to meet seasonal public demand
within the hours prescribed by park regulation.



   (B)   Improvements. All improvements contemplated herein, if any,
shall be at the expense of the grantee and subject to all policies, rules,
procedures, and regulations of the city. The grantee shall use its best
efforts to abate litter by its patrons at docking facilities or underway and
shall comply with all city directives and ordinances regarding signs,
parking, crowd control, wake, and litter.



   (C)   Maintenance and operation. The grantee shall at all times
comply with all applicable rules, regulations, and laws which affect and
govern the operation and maintenance of the franchise vessel.



   (D)   Sale of refreshments.  Sale of food, beverages, or any items
aside from tickets for passage, is prohibited when the franchised vessel is
docked at the municipal park.



(‘68 Code, § 9-9) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 95.25  RECORDS OF REPORTS.



   (A)   The city shall have reasonable access to and the right to
inspect and audit the grantee’s records, relating to the operations,
affairs, matters of safety, or property of the grantee with respect to this
franchise; however, such access shall be during normal business hours that
does not unreasonably interfere with the grantee’s operation; such records
are:



      (1)   All rules and regulations for operation and maintenance
of the franchised vessel.



      (2)   Customer complaints or governmental agency complaints on
the grantee and action taken.



   (B)   Any violation of division (A) of this section shall be deemed
a material obligation in this section.



(‘68 Code, § 9-10) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



§ 95.26  TERMINATION AND DEFAULT.



   Except as otherwise provided, the city may terminate this franchise in
the event of failure, refusal, or neglect by the grantee to comply with any
material obligation or provision contained in this subchapter. The city shall
comply with the following procedures:



   (A)   The City Council shall make a written determination that after
reasonable investigation it appears that the grantee has failed, refused, or
neglected to comply with the material provisions of this subchapter.



   (B)   If the Council finds good cause to make its determination on
the standards set forth above, then it shall give written notice to the
grantee stating its factual or legal basis for same. The grantee shall have
21 days after its receipt of such notice in which to comply with the
provisions and/or deficiencies. If the alleged violation is not remedied
within the 21-day period, the Council may cancel this franchise or set the
violation for discussion at the regularly scheduled meeting, at which meeting
the Council shall make a decision whether the alleged violations was in fact
a failure, refusal, or neglect by the grantee to comply with a material
provision of this chapter. If theCouncil determines such failure, refusal, or
neglect by the grantee was not in the public interest or in compliance with
the terms of this franchise, said franchise shall be terminated.



(‘68 Code, § 9-11) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



§ 95.27  MODIFICATION OF FRANCHISE; USE AS SECURITY, OR FOR INCUMBRANCE.



   This franchise may not be changed or modified, unless done in writing
by the City Council.  Additionally, this franchise shall not be assignable
or pledged or used as security or for an incumbrance.



(‘68 Code, § 9-12(a)) (Ord. 1623, passed 9-8-86)



CHAPTER 96:  AIRPORTS



Section



   96.01   Landing and takeoff of aircraft restricted



§ 96.01  LANDING AND TAKEOFF OF AIRCRAFT RESTRICTED.



   No person shall land or take off in any aircraft within the city limits
or from any area therein other than a public or private airport facility,
which is open and maintained as an airport facility.



(‘68 Code, § 4-1) (Ord. 1027, passed 5-2-60) Penalty, see § 10.99

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 97.01  ADOPTION OF STATE LAW RELATIVE TO STREET IMPROVEMENTS.



   The provisions of Chapter 106, 40th Legislature, the first called
session, Acts of 1927, commonly known as Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat., Art. 1105b, as
amended, are hereby adopted by the city as controlling the establishment,
construction, and repair of street and/or curb and gutter improvements within
the city.



(‘68 Code, § 32-1) (Ord. 217, passed 5-21-46)



§ 97.02  STREET NUMBERS FOR BUILDINGS.



   (A)   All buildings fronting on any street or alley in the city
shall be numbered in some conspicuous place, by the owner thereof, according
to the map made by the Building Inspector for such purpose and on file in his
office, all odd numbers being on one side of the street and all even numbers
on the other.



   (B)   Any person desiring to have a number to be put on his building
shall first apply to the Building Inspector for the proper number, and any
person failing or refusing to comply with any other requirement of this
section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



   (C)   House numbers for dwellings located on the south side of the
alley behind blocks 501, 531, 532, 630,631 and 668 of the Velasco Townsite
shall be as follows:



      (1)   Lots in the Mystery Harbor Subdivision:



Lot 1 shall be 610  Mystery Harbor Lane



Lot 2 shall be 524 Mystery Harbor Lane



Lot 3 shall be 514 Mystery Harbor Lane



Lot 4 shall be 504 Mystery Harbor Lane



Lot 5 shall be 414 Mystery Harbor Lane



Lot 6 shall be 404 Mystery Harbor Lane



Lot 7 shall be 314 Mystery Harbor Lane



      (2)   Lots outside the Mystery Harbor Subdivision:



Tr 5B, Ab 8, shall be 620 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 5I, Ab 211, shall be 614 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 5G, Ab 211, shall be 612 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 5G, Ab 211, shall be 612 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 5G, Ab 211, shall be 612 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 3, Ab 211, shall be 302 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 3A, Ab 211, shall be 222 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 3B, Ab 211, shall be 206 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 3C, Ab 211, shall be 202 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 2A1, Ab 211, shall be 116 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 2A2, Ab 211, shall be 104 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 2B, Ab 211, shall be Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 8, Ab 211, shall be 8 Mystery Harbor Lane



Tr 1, Ab 211, shall be 22 Mystery Harbor Lane



(‘68 Code, § 32-2) (Ord. 23, passed 1-7-19; Am. Ord. 2003-2004, passed
2-19-03; Am. Ord. 2005-2080, passed 4-4-05; Am. Ord. 2005-2093, passed
8-22-05)



§ 97.03  OBSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC WAYS PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city without
obtaining a permit to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter, or repair or to
permit the erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, or repair of
any fence, wall, hedge, structure, or any other character of obstruction:



      (1)   Over, on, or across any public property, way, alley,
street, sidewalk, or park.



      (2)   Between the property line of any lot and a public street
or alley line.



   (B)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this
section or fail to comply therewith shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The
owner or owners of any building or premises or part thereof, where anything
in violation of this section shall be placed or exist, and any architect,
builder, contractor, agent, or person assisting in the commission of any such
violation shall also be guilty of a separate misdemeanor.



(‘68 Code, § 32-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.04  OFFICIAL NAMES FOR STREETS, ALLEYS AND HIGHWAYS.



   (A)   Except as provided in division (B) of this section, the
official name for each public street, alley or highway opened within the city
prior to date of adoption of the ordinance adding this section to this code
shall be as stated on the official zoning map of the city adopted by  § 3
of Ordinance 1100, passed on April 3, 1964, and any amendments thereto or
replacements thereof subsequently adopted.



   (B)   The official names of the following public streets or
highways, or the designated portion thereof, are hereby changed as follows:



      (1)   The name of the portion of the public highway within the
city known as FM 1495, including but not being limited to the portion thereof
heretofore known as Pine Street, from its intersection with FM 523 to its
intersection with the Intracoastal Waterway, is changed to Navigation
Boulevard.



      (2)   The name of the alley located behind 501, 531, 532, 564,
565, 594, 595, 630, 631 and 668 of the Velasco Townsite, between Division
Street and Quintana Street, shall be known as Mystery Harbor Lane.



      (3)   The name of the drive providing access from Second
Street to the Brazosport High School baseball and softball complexes shall be
Exporter Drive.



      (4)   The roadways formerly known as County Road 723 and
County Road 241, located west of FM 1495 and south of the Louisiana-Texas
Gulf Intercoastal Waterway, shall be known, collectively, as J.P. Bryan Road.



      (5)   The roadway formerly known as County Road 750, which
connects FM 1495 with the citys Bryan Beach on the Gulf of Mexico, shall be
Bryan Beach Road.



      (6)   The name of the roadway passing in front of the Freeport
Library and connecting Quintana Street in the Velasco Townsite with
Brazosport Boulevard (State Highway 288) shall be Veterans Memorial Drive.



      (7)   The name of Second Street, as shown on the plat of the
Freeport Townsite on file in Volume 2, page 95 of the plat records of
Brazoria County, Texas, is hereby changed to Second Street/ Martin Luther
King Boulevard.



(Ord. 1851, passed 1-18-99; Am. Ord. 2003-2004, passed 2-19-03; Am. Ord.
2005-2080, passed 4-4-05; Am. Ord. 2006-2134, passed 9-11-06; Am. Ord.
2006-2143, passed 11-6-06; Am. Ord. 2006-2146, passed 11-20-06; Am. Ord.
2007-2171, passed 9-4-07; Am. Ord. 2015-2101, passed 12-7-15)



CONSTRUCTION



§ 97.15  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED FOR CONSTRUCTION; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct,
alter, repair, remove or move, or replace any sidewalk, driveway, or curb and
gutter, for the use of any character of vehicle, on or across any sidewalk,
parkway, or other space between any public road or right-of-way and any
private property without complying with the provisions of §§ 97.15 through
97.34 of this chapter, and the related standard specifications of the city.



(‘68 Code, § 32-15)



   (B)   None of the provisions of §§ 97.15 through 97.34 of this
chapter shall apply to any work done or to be done along or upon any street,
alley, sidewalk, or other place pursuant to any contract for improvements
authorized by the City Council, or work done by the city through any of the
employees of the city.



(‘68 Code, § 32-16) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.16  EFFECT OF APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION PLAT.



   The approval of a subdivision development plat by the City Council,
upon recommendation of the City Engineer, approving such subdivision and the
improvements therein contemplated shall constitute a permit for the
construction of the streets, alleys, driveways, waterlines, sewer lines, and
drainage facilities shown and indicated upon such plat and/or in the
specifications for such improvements. Nothing contained in the provisions of
§§ 97.15 through 97.34 of this chapter shall be deemed to have the effect
of repealing Chapter 154 of this code, or any other regulations of the city
established by ordinance.



(‘68 Code, § 32-17) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



Cross-reference:



   Subdivision regulations, see Ch. 154



§ 97.17  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct, alter,
repair, remove, or move or replace any sidewalk, driveway, or curb and
gutter, for the use of any character of vehicle, on or across any sidewalk,
parkway, or other space between any public road or right-of-way and any
private property without first having made application for and secured a
permit from the Engineering Department of the city.



(‘68 Code, § 32-18) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.18  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; ISSUANCE.



   (A)   The application for a permit required by the provisions of
this subchapter shall be in writing and shall be directed to the City
Engineer. Such written application shall show the location of the improve-
ments regulated by the provisions of §§ 97.15 through 97.34 of this
chapter, together with a map or plat or sketch drawn to scale, fully
describing the nature of the proposed improvements and the location thereof.



(‘68 Code, § 32-19)



   (B)   In the event that the application for a permit required by the
provisions of this subchapter complies with the regulations herein contained
and such other and further regulations concerning the matter as may be
provided hereafter, a permit therefor shall be issued by the Engineering
Department on a form established by the City Engineer.



(‘68 Code, § 32-20)



(Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.19  VARIANCES AUTHORIZED.



   Upon the showing that unusual circumstances exist, or that a need for a
driveway of greater width exists or some variance from the requirements set 
forth in §§ 97.30 through 97.34 of this chapter should be made, where such
variances will not be contrary to the public interest and that literal
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will result in unnecessary
hardship, such regulations may be varied by approval of the City Engineer,
provided in no instance shall any driveway opening be in excess of 45 feet in
width.



(‘68 Code, § 32-21) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.20  REQUEST FOR VARIANCE; ACTION.



   (A)   Any person requesting that the regulations in §§ 97.30
through 97.34 of this chapter be varied because of any unusual circumstance
shall file a written request therefor with the City Engineer setting forth
the circumstances to show that literal enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter will result in unnecessary hardship.



(‘68 Code, § 32-22)



   (B)   The City Engineer shall either approve or deny in writing a
request for such variance of the provision of this chapter within a
reasonable time, but in no event shall the City Engineer withhold his
decision for more than 30 days. 



(‘68 Code, § 32-23)



(Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.21  APPEAL.



   (A)   Any person aggrieved by the decision of the City Engineer
under the provisions of §§ 97.15 through 97.34 of this chapter shall have
the right to appeal to the City Council upon giving written notice to the
City Council within five days after the refusal of the application made by
him for a permit to construct such sidewalk, driveway, or curb and gutter, or
for the denial of any variance requested by such person.



   (B)   The City Council shall hear such appeal at or before the
second regular meeting following the receipt of such written notice of appeal.



(‘68 Code, § 32-24) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



DRIVEWAYS



§ 97.30  COMPLIANCE WITH SPECIFICATIONS REQUIRED.



   No driveway providing access from private property to any public
right-of-way shall be constructed  within the city unless substantial
evidence is produced, satisfactory to the City Engineer, that such approach
and drive shall be in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.



(‘68 Code, § 32-30) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.31  DRIVEWAY SPECIFICATIONS.



   (A)   Width. No driveway shall have a width measured along the
boundary line between the public right-of-way and the private property of
more than 35 feet; provided however, upon a request for a variance from the
provisions of this division (A), such driveway shall not be in excess of 45
feet in width.



(‘68 Code, § 32-31)



   (B)   Sidewalk section required. Every driveway shall be designed
and constructed so as to provide a sidewalk section.  This section shall
usually extend five feet from the property line and have a slope of ¼ of an
inch per foot. From the outside edge of this sidewalk section, the slope
shall be continuous to the proper or existing gutter grade. 



(‘68 Code, § 32-32)



   (C)   Curb return. The curb return on all driveways shall have a
radius of not less than three feet to the back of the curb; and the point
where the return falls tangent to the street curb shall be within the
property lines extended perpendicular to the street right-of-way line of the
property which the driveway is designed to service.  At street
intersections, the point where the return falls tangent to the street curb
shall be a minimum of ten feet inside the property line extended as above,
and at interior property lines the point where the return falls tangent to
the street curb shall be a minimum of 2½ feet inside the property line
extended as above. 



(‘68 Code, § 32-33)



   (D)   More than one entrance. Where more than one entrance along one
side of a private property is required, such entrance shall be separated by a
divide or island at least ten feet in length. The width and radii for such
divides or islands shall be governed by regulations set forth in other
divisions in this section, with a minimum width of four feet. 



(‘68 Code, § 32-34)



   (E)   One-fourth inch per foot fall required. Sidewalks shall be
constructed at an elevation so as to provide for a minimum of ¼-inch per
foot fall from the property line to the top of the curb.



(‘68 Code, § 32-35)



   (F)   Ramp section.  Where a ramp section of the driveway is to be
constructed, the ramp shall reach the grade of the sidewalk at a distance of
not less than five feet from the outside edge of the street curbline. 



(‘68 Code, § 32-36)



(Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.32  ESTABLISHMENT OF GRADE.



   The grade for all curbs, sidewalks, driveways, and ramps shall be fixed
by the Engineering Department.



(‘68 Code, § 32-37) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.33  CONCRETE.



   All driveway approaches, ramps, and sidewalks, constructed in
connection therewith shall be constructed of concrete having a minimum of
2,500 PSI in 28 days, shall have a minimum thickness of six inches, and shall
have reinforcing consisting of a minimum of six inches by six inches number
six wire mesh, or equivalent reinforcing bars. Concrete for curb and gutter
shall have a minimum of 3,000 PSI in 28 days.



(‘68 Code, § 32-38) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.34  INSPECTION.



   The Engineering Department shall inspect the excavation, forms, and
placement of reinforcing steel. The person to whom the permit is granted
shall be required to notify the Engineering Department when the work is ready
for inspection, and no concrete shall be placed until approval thereof has
been granted.



(‘68 Code, § 32-39) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



EXCAVATIONS



§ 97.45  ENFORCEMENT OF PROVISIONS.



   All excavations, cuts, refilling, or repairing done in pursuance of
this subchapter shall be made under the supervision and direction of the City
Engineer or his representative, and it shall be his duty either in person or
by representative, to supervise all such making and refilling of cuts and
excavations and the repairing of same, and to require same to be done in
compliance with the requirements of this subchapter, and of the contract and
such orders and rules as the City Council may from time to time establish.



(‘68 Code, § 32-50) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.46  PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to make, cause, or permit
to be made any cut or excavation in or under the surface of any street,
alley, sidewalk, or other public place in the city for the installation,
repair, or removal of any pipe, conduit, duct, tunnel, or other structure or
for any other purpose whatsoever, without first obtaining from the City
Engineer a written permit to make such cut or excavation; provided however,
the City Engineer shall not grant permits for the cutting or excavation of
such streets or sidewalks for main or trunk line pipes or conduits under the
public streets, alleys, or public places in the city unless permission has
been first secured therefor from the City Manager, but the City Engineer is
authorized to grant a permit to lay any lateral or service pipe where in his
judgment it will be safe to do so without the necessity of receiving the
approval of the City Council.



(‘68 Code, § 32-51)



   (B)   Exceptions. None of the provisions of this subchapter shall
apply to any work done or to be done along or upon any street, alley,
sidewalk, or other place, pursuant to any contract for improvement authorized
by the City Council, or work done by the city through any of the employees of
the city.



(‘68 Code, § 32-52) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.47  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.



   (A)   Every person desiring to make any cut or excavation under the
surface of a public street, sidewalk, or other public place in the city shall
file with the City Engineer a written application for a permit therefor,
which application shall contain the residence or business address of the
applicant; shall state in detail the location and area, length, and width of
each cut or excavation desired to be made, and the application shall also
state that the applicant obligates and binds himself to defend, at his own
cost and expense, any suit, action, or claim for damages which may be
instituted against the city for any loss, cost, expense, or damage charged or
imposed upon it, by reason of the granting of such permit or by reason of the
manner in which such excavation is made, or any work done in connection
therewith. Such application shall also state that the applicant obligates
himself to keep the excavated portion of such street in good repair for the
period of one year after such excavation has been made and refilled.



   (B)   Such application in all cases, shall be accompanied by a plat,
showing the location of such proposed cut or excavation proposed to be made
in any street, alley, sidewalk, or public place in the city, and the purpose
for which the same is to be made, and all such other details as the City
Engineer may require to be shown upon such plat; provided however, the filing
of the plat shall not be required when the cut or excavation is made for
service connection only, or for purpose of locating the trouble in connection
with the pipes already laid, or in making repairs thereon.



(‘68 Code, § 32-53) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.48  DEPOSIT; INSURANCE REQUIRED.



   (A)   When the application to cut or excavate any street, alley,
sidewalk, or other public place and the details shown upon the accompanying
plat when such plat is required, comply with the terms of this subchapter and
the requirements of the City Engineer have been complied with, the
application shall be approved by him and filed in his office as a public
record.



   (B)   The City Engineer shall, before the issuance of such permit,
require such applicant to deposit in his office a sum of money, either in
cash or represented by a certified check on some bank in the city, payable to
the city, such sums of money as the City Engineer may think sufficient to
restore such street, alley, or sidewalk, or other public place to its former
condition.



   (C)   When the work is completed, and the streets, alleys,
sidewalks, and other public places are restored to their former condition by
the applicant, which condition shall be approved by the City Engineer, it
shall be his duty to refund or cause to be repaid to the applicant, the
amount or sum of money so deposited by the applicant.



   (D)   In the event the excavation should be of such nature as to
cause an open excavation in any street, alley, or sidewalk, or for dirt to be
piled thereupon, or such street, alley, sidewalk, or other public property to
be obstructed for a period of more than eight hours, such eight hours being
the hours between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., then in such event, as a condition
to the issuance of such permit, the City Engineer shall require the person
seeking the permit to have liability insurance covering injury to person or
persons of not less than $100,000 for each person, nor more than $200,000
each accident and property damage of not less than $10,000 for each person or
$20,000 each accident, and to furnish contractual liability insurance in like
sums protecting the city from liability for damages to person or property
arising out of the excavation obstruction and use of the aforesaid streets,
alleys, or public rights-of-way and for public easements.



(‘68 Code, § 32-54) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.49  ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.



   When the chief executive officer shall approve the making of any cut or
excavation for main or trunk line pipe or conduits, under the streets,
alleys, sidewalks, or other public places, his approval shall be endorsed
upon an application addressed to the City Engineer, and upon application and
approval thereof, the City Engineer shall issue the necessary permit upon the
applicant complying with such restrictions and obligations as the City
Council may have attached to the granting of the same.



(‘68 Code, § 32-55) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.50  CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.



   (A)   Every permit for any excavation in or under the surface of any
street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place shall be granted subject to
the right of the city, or of any other person entitled thereto to use that
part of such street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place for any purpose
for which the same may be lawfully used.



   (B)   The granting of any permit hereunder, for the purpose of
locating or placing any pipe, conduit, duct, tunnel, or other structure shall
not be construed to grant to such person any fixed or vested right in such
location, but all the same shall be taken to the right of the city or of any
other person entitled thereto, to lay or place its pipe or pipes, conduit, or
other structures in or under such portion thereof under or across such pipe,
conduit, duct, or other structure as may have been laid, without cost or
charge being exacted by the installer at the prior location for which used.



   (C)   All persons receiving permits to put or place pipes, conduits,
ducts, or other structures under the surface of any public street, alley,
sidewalk, or other public place in the city thereby obligate and bind
themselves to move or change the location of their pipes, conduits, ducts, or
other structures whenever ordered or instructed to do so by the city, and
failure to do so, or interfering with any other person in the matter of
moving the pipe, conduit, or other structure under any street, alley,
sidewalk, or other public place shall constitute an offense.



(‘68 Code, § 32-56) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.51  EXCAVATION TO COMPLY WITH PLAT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to make, cause, or permit to be
made, any cut or excavation, or to install or maintain, or cause or permit to
be installed or maintained, any pipe, conduit, duct, tunnel, or other
structure under the surface of any public street, alley, sidewalk, or other
place at any location other than that described in the application and shown
on the plat by such applicant.



(‘68 Code, § 32-57) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.52  ACCESS.



   Free access must be provided to fire hydrants and water valves at all
times during the progress of any work performed under the provisions of this
subchapter. All materials excavated shall be laid compactly alongside of the
trench and kept trimmed up so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible
to the public traffic. If the street is not wide enough to hold the excavated
materials, without using a part of the adjacent sidewalk, the person by whom
the excavation is being done shall erect a tight board fence upon and along
such sidewalk and keep a passageway at least four feet in width opening upon
and along such sidewalk. All gutters shall be maintained free and
unobstructed for the full width of the adjacent curb, and for at least one
foot in width from the base of such curb to the gutter line. Whenever a
gutter crosses an intersecting street, an adequate waterway shall be provided
and at all times maintained and kept open.



(‘68 Code, § 32-58) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.53  REFILLING.



   After the excavation for which a permit has been obtained under the
provisions of this subchapter is finished, the work of refilling the same
shall be prosecuted with due diligence and so as not to obstruct or interfere
with the use of the street for travel thereon any more than is absolutely
necessary. If the work is not so prosecuted, or if the work of refilling does
not, in the judgment of the City Engineer, comply with the terms of this
subchapter and the contract of the party making such excavation, the City
Engineer shall notify the person named in the permit that such work is not
being prosecuted with due diligence, or that the refilling of such excavation
has not been properly done, and he shall require such person to proceed with
all diligence in the prosecution of the work.



(‘68 Code, § 32-59) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.54  LAYING OF PIPE.



   All pipes, conduits, tunnels, and other structures in or under the
surface of any public street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place, shall
be made and laid prior to the paving of such street, alley, sidewalk, or
public place.



(‘68 Code, § 32-60) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)



§ 97.55  MINIMUM DEPTH.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to install, cause, or permit to be
installed, any service pipe or main pipe, conduit, or duct, tunnel, or other
structure, except manholes, culverts, and catch basins, in any public street,
alley, sidewalk, or other public place, at a depth which would not allow a
minimum of four feet of fill below the finish grade above the line.



(‘68 Code, § 32-61) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.56  SAFETY WALKS; BARRIERS.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every person making any cut or
excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place, to maintain
a safe crossing for pedestrians and to maintain safe crossings for vehicles
and other traffic at all street intersections.



(‘68 Code, § 32-62)



   (B)   It shall be the duty of every person making any cut or
excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place, to place
and maintain suitable barriers at each end of such excavation to prevent
accidents; and to also place and maintain lights or flares at each end of
such excavation, and at distances of not more than 50 feet apart along the
line thereof from sunset each day to sunrise the following day until such
excavation is entirely refilled to the satisfaction of the City Engineer.



(‘68 Code, § 32-63) (Ord. 1055, passed 7-3-61)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 97.57  REPAIR OF UNDERGROUND UTILITIES.



   The repair of utilities located underneath the streets, alleys, and in
the right-of-way within the city shall be as follows:



   (A)   All utility companies, or other persons making repairs or
improvements within the street, alley, or right-of-way owned by the city,
shall comply with this chapter, unless otherwise excepted.



   (B)   Emergency cuts and repairs by utilities, or other authorized
persons within the right-of-way of the city streets and alleys, shall be made
as follows:



      (1)   Necessary repairs may be instituted after work hours and
on holidays and weekends by:



         (a)   Advising the City Police Depart- ment prior to
beginning repairs.



         (b)   Exercising safety provisions as outlined in this
code of ordinances and other applicable laws and regulations as to the type,
manner, and method of repair and protection of the workers, traffic, and
pedestrians.



         (c)   Backfilling all cuts and excavations with proper
sand and/or limestone mixtures for existing conditions prior to inspection by
the city.



         (d)   Apply for a permit for the emergency repairs by
10:00 a.m. on the next city workday which is not a Saturday, Sunday, or
holiday.



         (e)   Complete repairs pursuant to this chapter.



      (2)   All concrete cuts shall be squared up by concrete saw
prior to repaving and repairing of the street and/or curb.



      (3)   When emergency repairs are required and provided by the
utility or person making same, all bond, safety, warranty, and other
conditions contained in this chapter, being the responsibility of the using
or repairing entity, are and shall be in full force and effect; and this
emergency repair provision is and shall be a temporary emergency waiver of
permit requirements only until the city offices are regularly open for
business.



   (C)   Any residential sewer line, being positioned below a city
street with service connections to the household located under these streets,
will be repaired and maintained by the city from the curbline or pavement
edge forward to the main sewer line. This policy does not include or apply to
alleys or other areas.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person or utility to violate a
provision of this section and each day’s violation shall be a separate
offense.



(‘68 Code, § 32-64) (Ord. 1588, passed 7-16-84)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 98:  PARKS AND RECREATION



Section




General Provisions




   98.01   Curfew for Arrington Park



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 98.01  CURFEW FOR ARRINGTON PARK.



   Arrington Park shall be closed between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00
a.m. on a daily basis. It shall be unlawful for any person to be upon or in
Arrington Park during the hours the park is closed. This park may be opened
at other times upon recommendation of the Parks and Recreation Committee and
approval of City Council.



(Ord. 1705, passed 6-3-91)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 99:  USE OF EASEMENTS AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY



Section



   99.01   Definitions



   99.02   General provisions



   99.03   Registration of users and occupants



   99.04   Use and occupancy; regulation by the city



   99.05   Construction notification



   99.06   Construction work; regulation by the city



   99.07   Insurance requirements



   99.08   Plans of record



§ 99.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.  When
not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include
the future tense, words in the plural number include the singular number, and
words in the singular number include the plural number. The word “shall”
is always mandatory and not merely directory.



   CITY.  The City of Freeport, Texas.



   DEPARTMENT.  The city’s Public Works Department.



   DIRECTOR.  The Director of the Department or the designee of the
Director.



   EMERGENCY.  A reasonably unforseen situation presenting an imminent
hazard to personal or public health or to property.



   FACILITIES.  Personal property located in a right-of-way by a provider
of utility, telecommunica tions, cable television or other services,
including but not limited to pipe, conduit, ducts, cables, wires, lines,
towers, wave guides, optic fiber, microwave, laser beams, any associated
converters and other equipment.



   PERSON.  Natural persons (individuals), corporations, companies,
associations, partnerships, firms limited liability companies, joint
ventures, joint stock companies or associations, and other such entities, and
includes their lessors, trustees and receivers.



   PUBLIC NUISANCE.  A condition dangerous to the health, safety, peace,
comfort or convenience of the general public.



   REGISTERED USER.  A person who has complied with the registration
provisions of this chapter.



   RIGHT-OF-WAY.  The area on, below or above a public roadway, highway
or street, a public sidewalk, alley or waterway, or a utility easement in
which the city has an interest.



   USE AND OCCUPANCY.  The acquisition, installation, construction,
reconstruction, maintenance, repair or utilization of any facilities within a
right-of-way for any purpose.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.02  GENERAL PROVISIONS.



   (A)   No person shall use or occupy a right-of-way for the purpose
of providing utility, telecommunications, open video systems, cable
television services or any other services or for any other purpose without
the permission of the city.



   (B)   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the use and
occupancy of rights-of-way by a person under the authority granted by a
franchise agreement or ordinance or a license heretofore granted by the city
as if fully set forth in such agreement or ordinance or such license. The
express terms of this chapter shall prevail over conflicting or inconsistent
provisions in such agreement or ordinance or such license unless such
agreement or ordinance or such license was in existence prior to the
effective date of the ordinance adding this chapter to the city’s Code of
Ordinances.



   (C)   The provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed in
favor of the city in order to effectuate the purposes and objectives of this
chapter and to promote the public interest.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.03  REGISTRATION OF USERS AND OCCUPANTS.



   (A)   Registration required. All users and occupants of any
right-of-way shall register with the city pursuant to this chapter. For
existing users and occupants, such registration shall be accomplished within
30 calendar days following the date of the ordinance adding this chapter to
the city’s Code of Ordinances. Persons seeking to use or occupy any
right-of-way after such date shall register with the city prior to initiating
any such use or occupancy. For persons not having a current franchise
agreement or ordinance granted by the city, registration forms shall be
provided by the city.



   (B)   Purpose of registration. The purpose of registration under
this section is to:



      (1)   Provide the city with accurate and current information
concerning the users and occupants of the rights-of-way;



      (2)   Assist the city in the enforcement of this chapter; and,



      (3)   Assist the city in monitoring compliance with applicable
laws.



   (C)   Contents of registration. Registration shall include:



      (1)   The name, address and telephone number of the user and
occupant;



      (2)   The name, and if different, the address and telephone
number, of each person who will be a contact person for the user and occupant;



      (3)   The name, address and telephone number of any contractor
or subcontractor, if then known, who will be working in a right-of-way on
behalf of the user and occupant;



      (4)   The name(s) and telephone number(s) of an emergency
contact who shall be available 24 hours a day;



      (5)   Proof of insurance required in § 99.07 below; and



      (6)   A description of the type of facilities in any
right-of-way, for example, electric conduit, telecommunications cables, and
the like. This description shall include a statement of whether the applicant
is a certificated telecommunications provider as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov’t
Code, § 283.002(2), and, if so, whether the applicant is providing access
lines as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov’t Code, § 283.002(1).



   (D)   Renewal of registration. All registrations must be renewed
annually on or before January 31 of each calendar year. The city shall
provide written notification by certified mail, return receipt requested, to
any person who fails to re-register. If any person fails to renew the
registration of such person within 30 days after such written notice is sent,
the facilities of such person in the rights-of-way will be deemed to have
been abandoned.



   (E)   Current franchisees. For persons having a current franchise
agreement or ordinance granted by the city, such agreement or ordinance shall
be evidence of initial registration and, for so long as such agreement or
ordinance remains current, evidence of renewal.



   (F)   Franchise or license required of other users. In addition to
registering under the provisions of this chapter, prior to occupying or using
any right-of-way, all persons who are not certificated telecommunications
providers providing access lines, as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov’t Code,
Chapter 283, must also obtain a franchise or license when and if required by
the Home Rule Charter or ordinances of the city.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.04  USE AND OCCUPANCY; REGULATION BY THE CITY.



   (A) Temporary rearrangement or removal of aerial facilities. Upon
request, a registered user shall remove, raise or lower its aerial wires,
fiber or cables temporarily to permit the moving of houses or other bulky
structures. The expense of such temporary rearrangements shall be paid by the
person requesting them, and the registered user may require payment in
advance. The registered user shall be given 15 days notice to arrange for
such temporary arrangements.



   (B)   Right to trim trees. The registered user, its contractors and
agents, have the right, permission and license to trim trees upon and
overhanging the rights-of-way to prevent trees from coming in contact with
the registered user’s facilities. Registered users shall notify the city 48
hours prior to tree trimming activities beginning within the city and provide
an estimate of the duration of the tree trimming activity. All trimming shall
be done in consideration of the health of the trees. When directed by the
city, tree trimming shall be done under the supervision and direction of the
city or under the supervision of the city’s delegated representative. Any
tree trimmings generated by the registered user, its contractors or agents,
shall be removed within 24 hours. Should the registered user, its contractors
or agents, fail to timely remove such trimmings, the city may remove the same
or have them removed, and shall bill the registered user for all costs
incurred, which costs shall be promptly paid by the registered user. Nothing
herein shall be construed to grant to a registered user the right of access
to private property.



   (C)   Third party convenience. If the city requires a registered
user to adopt or conform its facilities, or in any way or manner to alter,
relocate or change its property to enable any other person, except the city,
to use, or to use with greater convenience, any right-of-way, a registered
user shall not be required to make any such changes until such other person
shall have undertaken with solvent bond, to reimburse the registered user for
any loss and expense which will be caused by, or arise out of such removal,
change, adaptation, alteration, conformance or relocation of the registered
user’s facilities; provided, however, that the city shall never be liable
for such reimbursement.



   (D)   Public safety. The city retains the right to move any
facilities within the rights-of way to cure or otherwise address a public
health or safety emergency. The city shall cooperate to the extent possible
with the registered user in such instances to assure continuity of service
and to afford the registered user the opportunity to make such relocation
itself.



   (E)   Abandonment of facilities. Whenever a registered user intends
to abandon any of its facilities within a right-of-way, the registered user
shall submit to the Director notification of intent to abandon, describing
the facility to be abandoned, and the date of the proposed abandonment. The
city may require the registered user, at its expense: to remove the facility
from the rights-of-way or to modify the facility in order to protect the
public health and safety. Unless notification is received or unless otherwise
provided in this chapter, a registered user shall remove all abandoned
above-ground facilities and equipment upon receipt of written notice from the
city and shall restore any affected right-of-way to its former state at the
time such facilities and equipment were installed, so as not to impair the
usefulness of such right-of-way. In removing any plant, structures or
equipment comprising a facility, a registered user shall refill, at its own
expense, any excavation necessarily made by it and shall leave all
rights-of-way in as good condition as that prevailing prior to such removal
without materially interfering with any electrical or telephone cable or
other utility wires, poles or attachments. The city shall have the right to
inspect and approve the condition of the rights-of-way, cables, wires,
attachments and poles prior to and after removal. The liability, indemnity
and insurance provisions of this chapter shall continue in full force and
effect during the period of removal and until full compliance by a registered
user with the terms and conditions of this chapter. Upon abandonment of any
facilities in place, a registered user, if required by the city, shall submit
to the city a written instrument, satisfactory in form to the city,
transferring to the city the ownership of the abandoned facilities in place
so long as it does not materially interfere with the use of the rights-of-way
or with the use thereof by any public utility, cable operator or other
registered user.



   (F)   City work. The city shall have the right at all times to lay,
and to permit to be laid, sewer, gas, water and other pipelines or cables and
conduits, as well as drainage pipes and channels, streets, alleys, curbs, and
sidewalks, and to do and permit to be done any underground or overhead
installation or improvement that may be deemed necessary or proper by the
governing body of the city, in, across, along, over or under any right-of-way
occupied by a registered user, and to change any curb or sidewalk or the
grade of any street or alley and to maintain all of the facilities owned by
the city located therein.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.05  CONSTRUCTION NOTIFICATION.



   (A)   Notification required.



      (1)   No registered user shall construct or install any
facilities in the rights-of-way without notifying the city in writing at
least five working days prior to the commencement of such construction or
installation. Notification must be given in the name of the person who will
own the facilities to be constructed or installed and must be signed by a
duly authorized representative of such owner.



      (2)   The phrase “construction or installation of structures
or facilities” does not include repair or maintenance of existing
facilities necessary to install service to a customer’s property, unless
such repair, installation or maintenance requires breaking of pavement, the
closure of a nonresidential street for a period to exceed four hours,
excavation or boring.



      (3)   The registered user has the burden to demonstrate in its
notification compliance with all requirements of this chapter and with all
applicable laws.



      (4)   All notifications shall include names and addresses of
persons authorized to act on behalf of the registered user with respect to
the notification and on behalf of the such owner.



      (5)   All notifications shall be made available by the city
for public inspection.



   (B)   Information to be required in notification.



   Notification will require the following information:



      (1)   The proposed, approximate location and route of all
structures or facilities to be constructed or installed and the registered
user’s schedule for right-of-way construction.



      (2)   A copy of construction plans for the proposed project in
accordance with accepted industry standards.



      (3)   Two sets of construction plans must be submitted on a
maximum 24”  x  36” media.



      (4)   A description of “the construction and installation
methods to be employed for the protection of existing structures, fixtures
and facilities within or adjacent to the rights-of-way and the dates and
times work will occur, all of which (methods, dates, times, etc.) are subject
to the approval of the Director.



      (5)   A statement that the insurance and bonding requirements
contained herein are met.



   (C)   Surety bond. The registered user shall file a surety bond that
will be valid prior the commencement of construction or installation through
three full years after the completion of the construction or installation
from a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Texas. The
surety bond shall be in the amount of the estimated amount of the cost to
restore the rights-of-way for the work anticipated to be done in that year
and shall guarantee the restoration of the rights-of-way in the event the
registered user or its contractor or subcontractor leaves a job site in the
rights-of-way unfinished, incomplete or unsafe. The surety bond requirement
can be waived upon proof of financial responsibility by the registered user.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.06  CONSTRUCTION WORK; REGULATION BY CITY.



   (A)   Existing facilities. Before initiating construction or
installation on any right-of-way, a registered user will make all reasonable
efforts to attach its new facilities to existing facilities, e.g. poles, and
to share existing conduit space, as appropriate. Nothing contained in this
chapter shall be construed to require or permit the attachment on or
placement in a registered user’s facilities of any electric light or power
wires or any facilities or other systems not owned by such registered user.
If the city desires to attach or place electric light or power wires,
communications facilities or other similar systems or facilities in or on a
registered user’s facilities, then a further separate, noncontingent
agreement with such registered user shall be required. Nothing contained in
this chapter shall obligate a registered user to exercise or restrict the
joint ownership or other wire space or facilities agreement with any person
authorized to operate in the rights-of-way.



   (B)   Traffic disruptions. A registered user shall endeavor to
minimize disruptions to the efficient use of the rights-of-way by pedestrian
and vehicular traffic, and rights-of-way shall not be blocked for a longer
period than shall be reasonably necessary to execute all construction,
maintenance and/or repair work. If traffic signs are required, such signs
shall be in accordance with the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices
issued by the Texas Department of Transportation.



   (C)   Utility/pole placement. All poles placed shall be of sound
material and reasonably straight, and shall be set so that they will not
interfere with the flow of water in any gutter or drain, and so that they
will not unduly interfere with ordinary travel on the streets, alleys and
sidewalks. The location and route of all poles, stubs, guys, anchors,
conduits, fiber and cables placed or constructed by the registered user in
the construction or maintenance of its facilities in the city shall be
subject to the lawful, reasonable and property control, direction and/or
approval of the city.



   (D)   Time for completion. If the work cannot be completed in the
time specified in the submitted schedule, the registered user shall submit a
revised schedule 48 hours prior to the end date of the original schedule.



   (E)   Prior notification. The Department must be notified 24 hours
in advance that construction is ready to proceed by either the registered
user, its contractor or other representative. All construction shall be in
conformance with all codes of the city and applicable local, state and
federal laws. The notification shall include the name, address and phone
numbers of the contractor or subcontractor who will perform the actual
construction, including the name and telephone number of an individual with
the contractor who will be available at all times during the construction.



   (F)   Signage. Information signs measuring a minimum of three feet
by three feet, stating the identity of the person doing the work, telephone
number and registered user’s identity and telephone number shall be placed
at the location where construction is to occur at least 24 hours prior to the
beginning of work in the right-of-way and shall continue to be posted at such
location during the entire time the work is occurring.



   (G)   Erosion and storm water controls. Erosion control measures
(e.g. silt fence) and advance warning signs, markers, cones and barricades
must be in place before work begins. The registered user shall be responsible
for storm water management erosion control that complies with city, state and
federal guidelines. Upon request, the registered user may be required to
furnish documentation submitted or received from federal or state governments
relating to erosion or storm water controls.



   (H)   Lane closures. Unless in the event of emergency, lane closures
on major thoroughfares will be limited to after 8:30 a.m. and before 4:00
p.m. unless the Department grants prior approval. Traffic control signs will
comply with the specifications of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control
Devices of the Texas Department of Transportation.



   (I)   Responsibility of registered users. Without affecting the
legal relationship between registered users and their contractors and
subcontractors, registered users are responsible for the workmanship of any
and all damages caused by such contractors or subcontractors. A responsible
representative of the registered user shall be available to the Department at
all times during construction.



   (J)   Damage to facilities. Registered user or its contractor or
subcontractor shall notify the Department immediately of any damages to the
facilities of the city or other occupant or user.



   (K)   Cuts. Unless in the event of an emergency, when a street,
alley, curb or sidewalk cut is required, prior approval must be obtained from
the Department and all requirements of the Department shall be followed.
Repair of any cut of a street, alley, curb or sidewalk shall be made promptly
to avoid safety hazards to vehicles and pedestrian traffic. In the event of
emergency repairs, the registered user shall notify the city as soon as
possible.



   (L)   City utilities. Installation of it facilities by a registered
user shall not interfere with city utilities, in particular, gravity
dependent utilities.



   (M)   Installed depth. New non-municipal facilities must be
installed at a depth as approved by accepted industry standards.



   (N)   Line locations. Registered users working in the rights-of-way
are responsible for obtaining line locations from all affected utilities or
other users with facilities in the rights-of-way prior to any excavation. Use
of the Geographic Information System or the plans or records does not satisfy
this requirement. Registered users shall be responsible for verifying the
location of all potentially affected facilities prior to any excavation or
boring, with the exception of work involving lane closures, as set forth
above.



   (O)   Manholes. Placement of all manholes and/or hand holes must be
approved in advance by the Department. Hand hole or manholes will not be
located in sidewalks, unless approved by the Director.



   (P)   Pumping. Construction that requires pumping of water or mud
shall be contained in accordance with the ordinances of the city and federal
and state law and the directives of the Department.



   (Q)   Restoration. The restoration of rights-of-way shall be to the
reasonable satisfaction of the Department, shall be made in a timely manner
as specified by approved Department schedules and to the satisfaction of the
Director. The registered user shall warrant all pavement repairs for a period
of one year after restoration has been completed. If restoration is not
satisfactory or is not performed in a timely manner, all work in progress,
except that related to the problem, may be halted and a hold may be placed on
any further work until all restoration as required herein is completed. The
restoration shall include, but not be limited to:



      (1)   Installation of all manholes and hand holes, as
appropriate;



      (2)   Trenches or any other holes shall be covered and fenced
as approved by the Director or filled daily, unless other safety procedures
are approved by the Department;



      (3)   Leveling of all trenches and backhoe lines to natural
ground to be maintained for a period of three months after leveling;



      (4)   Sweeping of streets shall be provided on a daily basis
during construction;



      (5)   Restoration of all landscaping, ground cover, and
sprinkler systems.



   (R)   Indemnity. The registered user shall indemnify and hold the
city, its officers and employees, harmless from all claims, lawsuits,
judgments, costs, liens, losses, expenses, fees (including reasonable
attorneys fees and costs of defense), proceedings, actions, demands, causes
of action, liability and suits of any kind and nature, including but not
limited to, personal or bodily injury (including death), property damage, or
other harm for which recovery of damages is sought that may arise out of or
be occasioned or caused solely by the registered user’s negligent act,
error, omission of the registered user, any agent, officer, director,
representative, employee, contractor or subcontractor of the registered user,
and their respective officers, agents, employees, directors and
representatives while in the exercise of or performance of rights or duties
under this chapter. The indemnity provided for in this division shall not
apply to any liability resulting from the negligence of the city, its
officers or employees, in instances where such negligence causes personal or
bodily injury, death, or property damage. In the event that a registered user
and the city are found jointly liable by a court of competent jurisdiction,
liability shall be apportioned comparatively in accordance with the laws of
the State of Texas, without, however, waiving any governmental immunity
available to the city under Texas law and without waiving any defenses of the
parties under Texas law. The provisions of this chapter are solely for the
benefit of the parties hereto and not intended to create or grant any rights,
contractual or otherwise, to any other person or entity.



   (S)   Notice. The city shall give the registered user prompt written
notice of any claim for which the city seek indemnification. The registered
user shall have the right to investigate, defend and compromise any such
claim. The registered user shall promptly advise the city, in writing, of any
claim or demand against the city or the registered user known to the
registered user related to or arising out of the registered user’s
activities under this chapter.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.07  INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   Certificate of insurance. In order to comply with the
registration requirements of this chapter, the registered user shall at the
time of registration furnish a completed certificate of insurance.



   (B)   Coverage amounts. A registered user shall obtain and maintain
in full force and effect for the duration of its use and occupancy of any
right-of-way, or of the work to be performed under the permit, respectively,
at the registered user’s sole expense, insurance coverage written on an
occurrence basis, by companies authorized and admitted to do business in the
State of Texas and rated A or better by A.M. Best Company and/or otherwise
acceptable to the city, in the following types and amounts:



 


Type

 

Amounts




1.   Worker’s Compensation Employer’s Liability

 
Statutory

$500,000/$500,000/$50,000



2.   Commercial General (public) Liability Insurance to include coverage
for the following:

 



   a.   Premises operations



b.   Independent contractors



c.   Products/completed operations



d.   Contractual liability



e.   Explosion, collapse, underground



f.   Broad form property damage to include fire legal liability

 
Combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage of $1,000,000 per
occurrence with an aggregate of $3,000,000 or its equivalent



3.   Business Automobile Liability

 



a.   Owned/leased vehicles



b.   Non-owned vehicles



c.   Hired vehicles

 
Combined single limit for bodily injury and property $1,000,000 per
occurrence ro equivalent



 



   (C)   Required provisions. All insurance contracts and certificates
of insurance shall contain:



      (1)   A cancellation provision in which the insurance company
is required to notify the city in writing not fewer than 30 calendar days
before canceling, failing to renew or reducing policy limits; and



      (2)   State the policy number, the name of the insurance
company, the name and address of the agent or authorized representative of
the insurance company, name, address and telephone number of the insured,
policy expiration date and specific coverage amounts.



   (D)   Self-insurance. With respect to the registered user’s
obligations to comply with the requirements for commercial general (public)
liability insurance coverage, the city may allow the registered user to
self-insure upon annual production of evidence that is satisfactory to the
city’s Risk Manager. With respect to the registered user’s obligations to
comply with the requirements for automobile liability insurance and for
workers’ compensation insurance, the registered user may self-insure,
provided the registered user tenders satisfactory evidence of self-insurance
as contemplated by the Texas Motor Vehicle Financial Responsibility Statute,
Tex. Trans. Code § 601.124, and the Texas Workers’ Compensation Act, Tex.
Labor Code §§ 407.001 et seq.



   (E)   Alternative for franchisees and licensees. Persons with
franchise agreements or ordinances or licenses issued by the city must meet
the above insurance and bonding requirements unless, in the opinion of the
city’s risk manager, their current franchise or license adequately provides
for insurance or bonds or otherwise provides an adequate indemnity in favor
of the city.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)



§ 99.08  PLANS OF RECORD.



   Registered users shall provide the Director with construction drawings
within ten calendar days of completion of facilities in the rights-of-ways.



(Ord. 1906, passed 8-21-00)

CHAPTER 110:  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES



Section

License to Sell

Statutory reference:

   Local option elections, Tex. Alco. Bev. Code §§ 251.01 et seq.



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 110.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purposes of this chapter and except for any and all definitions
set forth in this chapter, all definitions of words, terms, and phrases as
set forth in the Alcoholic Beverage Code of Texas, as the same now exists or
may hereafter be amended, are hereby adopted and made a part hereof.



(‘68 Code, § 5-1) (Ord. 79, passed 9-11-33; Am. Ord. 1768, passed 7-11-94;
Am. Ord. 2010-2269, passed 12-6-10)



Statutory reference:



   Definitions, Tex. Alco. Bev. Code §§ 1.04 and 11.49



§ 110.02  LOCATION RESTRICTED.



   (A)   Churches and schools. It shall be unlawful for any person to
sell or engage in the business of selling beer within the city, where the
place of business of such person is situated within 300 feet of any church or
school, the measurement of such distance for each church or school to be in
the manner specified in the Alcoholic Beverage Code as it now exists or may
hereafter be amended. As used herein, the term SCHOOL does not include any
educational institution offering a course of study beyond the twelfth grade.
As provided in the Alcoholic Beverage Code, the City Council may grant a
variance to this provision if the City Council determines that enforcement of
this provision in a particular instance is not in the best interest of the
public, constitutes waste or inefficient use of land or other resources,
creates an undue hardship or an applicant for a license or permit, does not
serve its intended purpose is not effective or necessary, or for any other
reason the City Council, after consideration of the health, safety, and
welfare of the public and the equities of the situation, determines is in the
best interest of the community.



   (B)   Public parks generally; other public property.



      (1)   It shall be and is hereby declared to be unlawful for
any person, firm, or corporation to sell, or offer for sale, any intoxicating
beverage, for con-sumption on the premises, whenever such premises from which
same is sold or offered for sale, lies within 200 feet of any property line
of any public park within the incorporated city limits.  Further, it shall
be, and is declared to be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to
sell or offer for sale any intoxicating beverage in or upon any public park,
right-of-way, or other public property of the city, without the consent of
the City Council.



      (2)   The public park situated between East and West Park
Avenue and any area contiguous thereto is hereby excluded from the
prohibition contained in division (B)(1) of this section.



(‘68 Code, § 5-2(a),(b)(1),(c)(1),(2)) (Ord. 79, passed 9-11-33; Am. Ord.
1409, passed 11-6-78; Am. Ord. 1410, passed 11-6-78; Am. Ord. 1605, passed
9-30-85; Am. Ord. 2010-2269, passed 12-6-10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   Authority to restrict location of sale of beer, intoxicating liquor,
see Tex. Alco. Bev. Code §§ 109.32 and 109.33



§ 110.03  HOURS OF SALE.



   (A)   Hours of sale of beer.  A person may only sell, offer for
sale or deliver beer within the incorporated limits of the city between 7:00
a.m. and 12:00 midnight, on any day except Sunday, and a person  may only
sell beer on Sunday between 12:00  midnight and 1:00 a.m. and between 12:00
noon and 12:00 midnight, except permittees or licensees authorized to sell
for on-premise consumption may sell beer on Sunday between 10:00 a.m. and
12:00 noon if the beer is served to a customer during the service of food to
such customer. Provided, the holder of a retail dealer’s on-premises late
hours permit may also offer for sale, and deliver beer between midnight and
2:00 a.m. on any day.



(‘68 Code, § 5-5) (Ord. 1246, passed 11-20-72; Am. Ord. 1768, passed
7-11-94; Am. Ord. 2009-2231, passed 10-19-09)



   (B)   Hours of sale of mixed beverages.  A mixed beverage permittee
may only sell and offer for sale mixed beverages within the incorporated
limits of the city between 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, on any day except
Sunday, and mixed beverages may only be sold on Sunday between 12:00 midnight
and 1:00 a.m. and between 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, except any alcoholic
beverage served to a customer on Sunday between 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon,
must be provided during the service of food to such customer. Provided,
however, the holder of a mixed beverage late hours permit may also sell,
offer for sale and deliver mixed beverages between midnight and 2:00 a.m. on
any day.



(‘68 Code, § 5-6) (Ord. 1480, passed 12-1-80; Am. Ord. 1768, passed
7-11-94; Am. Ord. 2009-2231, passed 10-19-09) Penalty, see § 10.99



LICENSE TO SELL



§ 110.25  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall manufacture, sell, distribute, or store any alcoholic
beverage or engage in any other activity with relation to which a license is
required by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, within the city, without first
obtaining a license so to do from the city. The fee for such license shall be
an amount equal to one-half the permit or license fee charged by the state
under the Alcoholic Beverage Code.



(‘68 Code, § 5-23) (Ord. 79, passed 9-11-33; Am. Ord. 1406, passed
10-2-78)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 110.26  PREREQUISITES TO ISSUANCE.



   No license required under the terms of this chapter shall be issued to
any person until he or she shows that he or she holds a state permit for the
particular phase of the liquor traffic in which he or she desires to engage
in the city and until the fee required by the city for such license has been
paid to the city.



(‘68 Code, § 5-24) (Ord. 79, passed 9-11-33)



§ 110.27  DURATION OF LICENSE.



   All licenses issued under the terms of this chapter shall expire at the
end of the calendar year following the date of issuance thereof. If the
license sought is issued for a period of time less than one year, only a
proportionate part of the annual fee based on quarters of a year, shall be
exacted and collected; provided, however, a fractional part of any quarter of
the year shall be counted as one quarter in calculating the fee which is to
be paid.



(‘68 Code, § 5-25) (Ord. 79, passed 9-11-33)



§ 110.28  DISPLAY OF LICENSE.



   The license required by § 110.25 shall be prominently displayed
alongside the state required license or permit issued to a licensee or
permittee selling alcoholic beverages within the city.



(Ord. 2012-2312, passed 6-18-12)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 111:  FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS

vendors, additional rules
